IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL COMPONENT The “Specific Pathogen Free 18 Baboon Research Resource” (SPF18BRR) is the only national research resource of adventitious virus free olive baboons (Papio anubis), their tissues and other biological materials, as well as the expertise to carry out research on this invaluable research animal. Scientist with NIH grants utilize virus free baboons to study the immunobiology of pig to baboon xenotransplantation, ways to develop or improve vaccines for SARS CoV-2, respiratory syncytial virus and pertussis, and to study the development of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. The goals of the SPF18BRR include provision of highly defined baboons and biomaterials to scientists, continued improvement of this animal resource, support to researchers requiring facilities and expertise to perform their studies, and training of the next generation of scientists, laboratory animal veterinarians, colony managers, and animal caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative: Although HPV has been identified as a necessary cause of cervical cancer (CVC), which accounts for ~10% of cancer-related deaths in women globally, the vast majority of HPV-induced pre-cancer lesions eventually regress, suggesting that unknown intrinsic factor(s) associated with the genetic/genomic alterations of the high-risk population play a critical role in HPV-induced neoplasia progression and CVC development. Our recent studies suggest that the disrupted YAP1-LATS2 negative feedback loop serves as a previously unprecedented mechanism underlying the progression of HPV-induced pre-cancer lesions and CVC development. Research results derived from the proposed mechanistic and preclinical studies will recognize the disrupted YAP1-LATS2 feedback loop as a key driver of pre-cancer lesion progression, expand our knowledge on the CVC etiology, and provide new targets and strategies to improve the prevention and treatment of human pre-cancer lesions and invasive cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative (Relevance to Public Health) Nicotine addiction and chronic pain are prevalent disorders that are highly comorbid and associated with negative affect, lost productivity, and significant health care costs. To address this co-morbidity, the proposed research will investigate dysregulation of brain ventral tegmental area – nucleus accumbens dopaminergic signaling and circuitry as a potential neurobiological mechanism for the association between chronic pain, pain-related negative affect, and nicotine use. The results will reveal essential causal mechanisms underlying chronic pain- associated abuse liability of nicotine and could contribute to the development of therapeutic interventions for patients with chronic pain and nicotine use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorder (SUD) is a costly and debilitating condition closely associated with poor decision making and elevated risk taking. Although significant strides have been made toward identifying the neural mechanisms by which substance use increases risk taking, the majority of this work is based on studies investigating the neural substrates of risk taking in males; consequently, we have an impoverished understanding of the neural substrates underlying risk taking in females, even before drug exposure. To begin to address this significant gap in knowledge, the proposed work seeks to elucidate the neurobiological mechanisms underlying hormone- dependent risk taking in females, the findings of which can then inform our understanding of how such mechanisms may be compromised after chronic substance use in females and lead to elevated risk taking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Wen, Li Project narrative We have found that gut bacteria V. dispar are significantly reduced in patients with type 1 diabetes (T1D) and these have immunoregulatory property when studied by mono-colonization of germ-free (GF) mice. The current application is designed to investigate the underlying mechanisms, which will help with the future therapeutic design for T1D and other autoimmune disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although gene therapy has shown great promise in a cat model of GM1-gangliosidosis by delaying symptom onset, reducing lysosomal storage in the brain and peripheral tissues, and prolonging lifespan, evaluation of its treatment efficacy in clinical trials is challenging due to the small and heterogeneous patient population as well as slow progression in the non-infantile patients. Recently, we discovered a pentasaccharide biomarker that was markedly elevated in biofluids from GM1-gangliosidosis patients and in the central nervous system (CNS) of the cat model and was reduced significantly in the CNS of the cat model in response to gene therapy, and thus the biomarker has potential as a pharmacodynamics/response biomarker. In this project, we will validate clinical assays for the biomarker in human urine, plasma, and CSF, and use these assays for assessing the efficacy of gene therapy in a clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health, because little is known about how nasal microbiome could affect natural-occurring immune protections in the nasal cavity of adults, which can affect the adult population’s risks for respiratory viruses such as coronaviruses, influenza, and rhinovirus. By studying nasal microbiome and these important types of immune response, this project will build new knowledge on the natural immune protection in adults against respiratory viral infections. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission to better understand and prevent infectious diseases, including those caused by influenza, coronaviruses (including SARS-CoV-2), and other respiratory viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biomedical engineering students require early, practical experience to develop the technical skills, knowledge of regulatory pathways, and training in teamwork necessary to solve unmet clinical needs as part of the biomedical engineering workforce. Our goal is to develop a core, sophomore-level, medical devices course in which students simulate the engineering teams found in industry in order to build workplace-ready skills. To accomplish this goal, we will implement innovative, scalable instructional methods that we expect will enhance students' professional engineering identities and develop their technical and professional skills, leading to enhanced retention and representation in the biomedical engineering workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Misregulation of human cell division can lead to uncontrolled cellular proliferation and carcinogenesis. The repertoire of enzymes and regulatory mechanisms that are necessary to carry out cell division with high fidelity are not completely understood. This proposal addresses this deficiency and will define the function of enzymes that are critical to cell division, which will increase our understanding of human cell proliferation and aid the development of novel therapeutics for proliferative diseases like cancer.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overall, this five-year project intends to demonstrate proof-of-concept of microarray patch technology for delivering long-acting antiretroviral drugs for pediatric HIV treatment. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative In this application we develop iFLAME, a fast, large area multiphoton exoscope optimized for in vivo label-free imaging of immune cell populations and their dynamics in human skin. We validate iFLAME performance by demonstrating its ability to discriminate immune cells in vivo and develop quantitative morphological, metabolic and dynamic imaging endpoints to assess immune infiltrates in human skin during the wound healing process. Completion of these studies will establish the practical utility and value of iFLAME as a non-invasive clinical research tool for monitoring immune responses at the cellular level in human skin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latino individuals, the fastest growing ethnic minority population in the United States, have a higher prevalence of type 2 diabetes and diabetes-related complications, and are more likely to report inconsistent use of diabetes medications than non-Hispanic White individuals. The proposed project will develop and test an interactive text message-based tool tailored to address barriers to taking diabetes medications that are relevant to Latino adults. If found feasible, acceptable, and usable, this intervention could serve as a scalable tool to improve diabetes management and reduce diabetes-related complications among Latino adults in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People living with HIV (PLWH) experience higher rates of stress-related conditions (e.g., substance use, depression, systemic inflammation), which puts PLWH at greater risk for accelerated aging-related chronic diseases (e.g., heart diseases, cancers, metabolic disorders). The brain’s central executive network plays a key role in exerting self-control, reappraising stressful stimuli, and managing unpleasant thoughts. This project will test whether PLWH who have greater functional connectivity in the brain’s central executive network are less likely to experience depression, substance use, and consequent systemic inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diseases of the aorta (the largest artery in the body) are increasingly responsible for death and disability in the United States, but fortunately life-saving surgical procedures are available. Such surgeries need to be timed appropriately, however, because either premature or delayed surgery can increase risk to the patient. This research is novel and important for we will develop and validate a new computer model-based approach that will help surgeons to optimally time surgery, thus improving patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of our project is to discover why adults 65 and older with new-onset epilepsy (late-onset epilepsy) are 2 to 3 times more likely to develop dementia and stroke than their peers without epilepsy. Understanding the role of vascular risk factors in the association of late-onset epilepsy with dementia and stroke will provide guidance for future strategies to mitigate the risks for these secondary neurological outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our laboratory has identified and characterized a family of evolutionarily-conserved endocytic adaptor proteins called epsins, which have crucial roles in coordinating endocytosis and signal transduction. In this project, we will use unique transgenic knock-out mouse strains and cell culture models to investigate the role of epsins in regulating vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) homeostasis and phenotypic switching in health and disease. The proposed experiments are expected to identify molecular targets that will provide the foundation for the development of novel therapeutics to treat atherosclerosis and other vascular diseases that represent a leading cause of death worldwide and remain highly-relevant to the mission of the NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Herpesviruses are important human pathogens for which no effective long-term remedies are available. A unique and critical component of the virus is the portal vertex through which the viral genome is packaged into the viral capsid as part of the process to assemble new virions. Our study aims to understand the organization and functions of the proteins that make up the portal vertex, and their interactions with each other, the capsid, and the viral DNA. This knowledge will form a framework for developing therapeutic molecules that are specific to the virus, effective in preventing infection, and target essential structures that are not amenable to changing for escaping the therapeutic effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Sleep disorders have a major clinical and economic impact in the U.S., with 10-15% of the U.S. population suffering from chronic insomnia. Molecular genetic studies that began in Drosophila have already allowed mutant orthologs of Period proteins, casein kinase 1, and Cryptochromes to be connected to certain inborn errors of human sleep including familial forms of advanced sleep phase and delayed sleep phase disorders. Given the impact of these earlier contributions, we believe our proposed genetic, cellular, and biochemical studies of Drosophila will continue to provide tools and discoveries relevant to our understanding of human sleep.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondrial Disorders are rare and often devasting disorders of the brain, muscle and other organs for which there are no proven laboratory markers for disease severity or progression and no proven treatments. They are difficult to study because both nuclear and mitochondrial genes are used to make mitochondria. We have modified conventional methods used to study nuclear genes to enable us to study both nuclear gene function and mitochondrial gene changes to improve understanding of Mitochondrial Disorders arise and, eventually, how to better diagnose, track, and treat them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Infections caused by Staphylococcus aureus are a major public health concern due to their high incidence and significant morbidity and mortality. Increases in antibiotic resistance, coupled with an incomplete understanding of the immunological response to the bacterium, have limited available treatment strategies. This proposal will investigate novel mechanisms by which S. aureus evades the immune response and adapts to nutrient restriction in the host with goals of improving our ability to rationally design anti-S. aureus therapeutics that cripple bacterial replication and promote robust immune responses during infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver cancer, a gastrointestinal cancer of poor prognosis, is rising among low-income Americans, who are more often diagnosed at late stages and experience lower survival. This research proposal is designed to disentangle the complex reasons that underlie the geographic clustering of late stage liver cancer diagnoses within communities of lower socioeconomic status. Our findings will contribute to the development of effective and tailored intervention strategies to increase the early detection of liver cancer in at-risk adults living in the most disadvantaged areas, and consequently, the important public health mission of achieving equitable cancer outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Many patients with borderline personality disorder (BPD) attempt suicide and up to 5-10% die by suicide, but clinicians find it difficult to judge which patients are at the highest risk of dying by suicide, and when. This study seeks to understand not only who is at risk, but also how the level of risk changes over years, days and even minutes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative A lack of diversity among investigators is a strong impediment to resolving national and global challenges related to substance misuse. Certain students face multidimensional historical and social factors that hinder access to adequate mentorship, quality instruction, focused faculty attention, and the financial support necessary to become a future substance misuse and addition scientist. The proposed program, the Substance Misuse and Addiction Research Traineeship (SMART), is a trans-disciplinary drug abuse research education program for undergraduate students dedicated to enhancing diversity in the next generation of substance misuse and addiction scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Cannabis involvement is heritable and is more common in those with psychosis-related behaviors and schizophrenia, but the contributions to this co-occurrence remain unclear. This proposal aims to better understand the specific variants, genes, and biological pathways that underlie these behaviors, test for a causal relationship using a genetically-informed design, incorporate transcriptomic and epigenetic data from human and rodent studies to prioritize genes and pathways for functional follow-up, and examine whether polygenic risk for cannabis use disorder and schizophrenia predicts psychosis-related behaviors in population-based and/or high- risk samples. This line of research will advance our understanding of the genetic etiology of these frequently- comorbid behaviors, train the applicant in the use of multi-omic approaches particularly related to cannabis and schizophrenia neurobiology, and ultimately produce translationally-relevant results informed by multiple lines of evidence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Metabolic dysfunction and the incidence of chronic disease increase markedly in women following menopause. However, the role of estrogen action in protecting against chronic inflammation and impaired metabolic homeostasis remains inadequately understood. We intend for our work to provide mechanistic insight into the aging-related changes in metabolism and immune health that occur in women following menopause in order to facilitate the development of novel strategies to combat metabolic-related chronic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NIH SBIR PA-18-871 w/o Clinical Trials A Safe and Compact Neonate to Adult Neuroimaging MRI System High spatial resolution brain magnetic resonance imaging is necessary to help predict neuro- developmental outcome in infants and adults by reliably mapping dynamic anatomical and functional connectivity. Vulnerable infants unstable to survive transport to the current remote MRI scanners can miss their window of therapy or clinical intervention intended to save lives. The overall goal of this SBIR project is to create a compact MRI system with strong connectome gradients and advanced receive RF coil technology, by combining innovations in patient-centric care and salient imaging technology for stat imaging small children and the adult brain in any hospital department.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Little is known how HIV affects the brain in the era of combination antiretroviral therapy, and how drug abuse, including cocaine and opiates, could be detrimental to the HIV infected brain. Our project, using human tissues from the Manhattan HIV Brain Bank, will explore genome organization and function in specific brain cells and neural circuits of the HIV infected brain in the context of opiate or cocaine abuse.

PHR: Narrative  Component A: Core Surveillance Nevada Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS): RFA-DP-21-001 Project Narrative The Nevada Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) will improve surveillance of maternal and infant health key indicators such as infant morbidity and mortality, access to prenatal care, and maternal behaviors during pregnancy and early infancy. Data obtained from this surveillance will be used to shape maternal and child health programs and policies in Nevada. PRAMS will advance the Nevada Division of Public and Behavioral Health (DPBH), Maternal, Child, and Adolescent Health (MCAH) Section’s mission to improve the health of mothers and infants statewide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Real-time PCR is the current gold standard in molecular diagnostics. A next-generation technique, digital PCR, offers important advantages over real-time PCR, but at the expense of being complex, expensive, and low-throughput—not well suited for use in a clinical laboratory or when dealing with large numbers of samples. The proposed emulsion digital PCR (edPCR) system addresses these limitations of current digital PCR and improves its performance by using variable volume droplets created simply by shaking the sample in the presence of PCR reagents and an oil/emulsifier mix to create an emulsion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Immune activation in the brain due to illness or injury increases risk for memory problems during aging and dementias including Alzheimer’s Disease. These long-term effects of inflammation on the brain raise the question of whether the COVID-19 global pandemic might cause a surge in Alzheimer’s disease cases in the decades to come. In this project, we will identify how a temporary sickness that mimics inflammation caused by mild COVID-19 cause long-term changes in brain function, memory impairments, and faster Alzheimer’s disease progression that emerge long after recovery from illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is the leading cause of death from gastrointestinal disease in premature infants, and for which there exists no effective cure. The current proposal has identified four major questions in the field of NEC which we now seek to answer, through a novel focus on identifying what causes NEC, how we can prevent NEC, how we can predict NEC, and how we can reduce the impact of NEC on causing long term complications on the brain, the gut and the lung.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Many human diseases result from malfunctioning of actin cytoskeletal components, including Arp2/3 complex, a 7-subunit complex involved in actin filament nucleation and branching. This grant addresses important gaps of knowledge of the mechanisms of Arp2/3 complex activation, inhibition, branch stabilization, and branch destabilization, and has both fundamental importance and the potential to accelerate the development of targeted therapies to treat human diseases such as cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to develop federated learning approaches for distributed research networks where data are heterogeneously fragmented and individual-participant data cannot be pooled. The proposed methods enable health policy researchers to maximally harness the power of big data by integrating Medicaid modeling results from eleven states. The focus dedicated to the handling of data heterogeneity will enhance statistical power and generalizability of findings and improve our understanding of treatment for opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Vascular dysfunction contributes to pathogenesis of stroke, myocardial infarction, hypertension and heart failure, which cause one-third of deaths worldwide; however, there have been no mechanistically novel treatments for vascular dysfunction in the past 30 years. Vascular dysfunction and human hypertension are associated with mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress which produce highly reactive cytotoxic isolevuglandins and inactivate a key of mitochondrial regulator, Sirtuin 3. In the proposed studies, we will define the novel role of mitochondrial isolevuglandins in Sirtuin 3 inactivation and vascular dysfunction, and we will establish the therapeutic potential of our new mitochondria-targeted blockers of isolevuglandins in vascular tissue isolated from hypertensive patients which can make a major impact on the development of new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects 10-15% of the population world-wide and is associated with high mortality. We propose to develop and validate polygenic risk scores for CKD and its subtypes to aid in the early detection of kidney disease, before its onset, providing orthogonal risk information to the traditional disease risk factors. This proposal will lay groundwork for potential use of polygenic predictors of kidney disease in a clinical setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this project, we propose to understand the role of 17β-estradiol in ameliorating urinary tract infection-induced delirium. Briefly, we will use our novel model of urinary tract infection-induced delirium, oophorectomized mice, state-of-the-art behavioral testing, and genetically modified mice to determine whether 17β-estradiol ameliorates the structural and functional phenotypes of delirium via the G protein-coupled estrogen receptor 1. Given the lack of evidence-based pharmacological treatments for delirium, the findings from this research could have widespread clinical implications, including providing novel pre-clinical justification for clinical trials using a short-term application of an existing drug, 17β-estradiol, to ameliorate UTI-induced delirium and quality of life for millions of older women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Broadly acting antivirals are desperately needed to fight emerging viruses and their development depends on understanding the mechanisms of broad-spectrum antiviral proteins such as ZAP. Our proposed studies aim to characterize both cellular and viral determinants critical for TRIM25-mediated ZAP translational inhibition using the alphavirus system. This research will elucidate key ubiquitination substrates required for ZAP activity and viral escape strategies, which will provide actionable insights into identification of therapeutic targets against multiple viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is highly relevant to public health as the elucidation of the regulation and functions of PTEN is expected to uncover key pathogenic mechanisms for tumorigenesis, and will therefore yield important opportunities to advance therapeutic options and improve outcomes for cancer patients. Thus the proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission to develop fundamental knowledge that will help develop the effective strategy for precision cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Abnormal sleep-wake cycles, manic depression, cancer, and seasonal affective disorder are all linked to circadian clock dysfunction. Increasing evidence suggests that they are either caused by genetic factors such as clock gene variants or desynchrony between the human body and its environment due to societal factors such as jetlag, shiftwork, and light pollution. The goal of the proposed studies is to define a fundamental feature of the clock mechanism that controls the phase, period and amplitude of circadian rhythms, which could ultimately serve as a molecular foundation to aid in the diagnosis and treatment of clock disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During an infection, animals display a stereotyped set of symptoms aimed at increasing survival, such as elevation in core temperature aimed to fight pathogens (fever), decreased activity and appetite. Advanced molecular and genetic technologies allow for the dissection of dedicated neural pathways involved in specific physiological and behavioral responses, providing novel targets for diagnosis and therapeutic development. This proposal aims to leverage cutting edge molecular and genetics approaches to uncover the specific neuronal populations and neural circuits underlying the generation of fever and associated sickness symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Plant-based diets are healthy dietary patterns that are consistently associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and CVD risk factors. The proposed research seeks to uncover the mechanisms underlying plant-based diets and CVD by comprehensively characterizing the proteome and methylome, and integrating multiple omics data from 3 large prospective cohorts. The proposed research will yield novel evidence on protein markers and epigenetic markers of plant-based diets, and pathways linking plant-based diets to CVD, thus providing a basis to formulate CVD prevention and treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative / Relevance This proposal's primary goal is to explore and demonstrate that selective regional vulnerability in Alzheimer’s disease and incremental hierarchical spreading of hyperphosphorylated Tau and deposition of NFT are associated and interconnected with changes in expression of small non- coding RNAs and chromatin architecture. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Anti-arrhythmia therapy remains a process of trial-and-error, because clinicians cannot predict in advance how a patient will respond to a specific drug. We have developed methods to predict the response of patients with rare genetic variations in the cardiac sodium channel. With this project, we will expand this approach to common variations and conditions to predict whether certain patients with ventricular arrhythmia will be well-treated with mexiletine therapy, which has fewer side effects than more commonly prescribed drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Dysregulation of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is indicated in a range of cancers, including basal-like breast cancer (BLBC). The project “Illuminating Dynamic Receptor Clustering in the Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Signal Transduction Pathway Using Plasmon Coupling” develops nanoparticle-based tools to resolve dynamic spatial receptor clustering and to control the spatial regulation of EGFR activity. Nanoparticle-based strategies that facilitate the regulation of EGFR signaling provide new opportunities for therapeutic intervention in EGFR overexpressing cancers and can improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Improving health literacy is an important national goal and necessary for achieving and maintaining health. The increased adoption of smart speakers and virtual assistants by consumers and in medical settings has created novel opportunities to educate the population by delivering health information through audio or audio combined with text. Because few (if any) tools exist to improve content and generate optimal audio, we aim to discover supportive and adverse features of audio/text information provision and create a free, online software tool for optimizing health-related text with demonstrated impact on information comprehension and retention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Predict to Prevent: Dynamic Spatiotemporal Analyses of Opioid Overdose to Guide  Pre-Emptive Public Health Responses NARRATIVE Novel spatiotemporal forecasting models that rely on massively linked administrative data are needed to forecast future opioid overdose spikes and assess public health intervention success. Guided by the social ecological model, we plan to develop a comprehensive approach to identify individual, interpersonal, community and societal factors that contribute to opioid overdose, efficiently detect overdose hotspots, and develop dynamic forecasting models for timely prediction and prevention of future opioid overdose epidemics. We will disseminate blueprints, visualization tools, and code to other jurisdictions to facilitate replication of our approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Building upon successful discovery and replication, we will sequence HLA/KIR/FcGR/IGHG genes in a prospective birth cohort, in which the seroconversion times have been precisely determined through frequent collection of biospecimens from all participants. Our objective is to estimate penetrance of discovered residues to the disease progression, and further to conduct mechanistic investigations. Success of this project will shed light on the genetic mechanisms underlying disease progression, and results will provide a roadmap to develop effective prevention and treatment strategies, decelerating and possibly reverting the disease development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative In the past decade, private equity firms have acquired numerous substance use disorder (SUD) treatment facilities. Similar acquisitions in other areas of health care have resulted in declines in quality and increases in mortality. This project examines the effects of private equity acquisition of SUD treatment facilities on treatments offered, the insurance mix of patients treated, opioid use disorder treatment quality and health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Keratoconus (KC) disease is the degeneration of the corneal stroma, which causes the cornea to slowly change from its’ normal curved shape to a more conical shape, leading to vision distortion. The role of the KC tear fluid has been widely explored for biomarkers, however the presence and impact of the tear Extracellular Vesicles (EVs) remains unknown. The proposed studies have potential to discover novel biomarkers and pave the way for new diagnostic/treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Protein-protein interactions (PPIs) are critical for cell signaling, growth, proliferation and apoptosis. The work will develop novel strategies that specifically disrupt medicinally relevant β-catenin/BCL9 and β-catenin/TCF PPIs, and thereby leading to a new generation of therapeutic agents with novel molecular framework targeting Wnt singling. The designing strategy could guide the development of a new class of unnatural peptidic foldamer targeting a myriad of medicinally relevant PPIs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapy is now first line treatment in recurrent or metastatic head and neck cancer, yet the majority of patients do not respond. The proposed research aims to elucidate how the composition and spatial architecture of the head and neck cancer tumor immune microenvironment impacts response to immunotherapy, and how it changes across time following immunotherapy exposure. This knowledge is critical to improve treatment selection, develop new therapeutics and ultimately, improve survival outcomes for patient suffering from Head and Neck Cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death in type 2 diabetic patients, which is directly associated with the degree of coronary disease. While impaired coronary function and hardening of the arteries have been well- studied contributors to coronary artery disease, the molecular mechanisms of coronary blood vessel function in diabetes-induced heart disease remains unknown. The proposed research will improve our fundamental understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying coronary blood vessel disease, and it will contribute to the identification of new treatments for diseases of the coronary circulation in diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Aspirin’s effectiveness in preventing heart attacks and strokes decreases as a person’s weight increases, but we do not understand the reasons for this. We will test whether higher doses of aspirin are better at producing anti-inflammatory molecules as body weight increases and whether levels of these molecules can predict heart attacks, strokes and death. Our results will improve our understanding of cardiovascular disease in overweight and obesity and may suggest new treatment strategies for the prevention of heart attacks, strokes and death in people with cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to enhance our mechanistic insights of vascular disease by focusing on a novel biological pathway, the sulfatase family, that contributes to the development of calcified arteries and plaque development in the blood vessels of humans. Furthermore, we aim to uncover new determinants of coronary artery disease using human genetic analysis. Success in identifying novel molecular and genetic pathways implicated in the development of calcification and plaque formation will provide new potential targets for the prevention and treatment of heart attacks, stroke, and peripheral arterial disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ERG oncoprotein is responsible for half cases of prostate cancer, the most frequent cancer and the second leading cause of cancer death among American men. Prostate cancer features a luminal cell identity which is effectively targeted by hormone therapy, but resistance invariably occurs, thus demanding a deeper understanding of the biology underlying the cancer cell identity. This proposal seeks to elucidate the mechanisms and vulnerabilities of ERG-driven luminal cell identity during prostate cancer formation, the completion of which may reveal new treatment paradigms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will allow better understanding of how gender- linked stress exposure and estrogen may interact to impact memory, peripheral inflammation, and neural activation and connectivity in women at risk for Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Knowledge gained from our study will provide a foundation for the further study of stress- and inflammation-based mechanisms of AD and will support the development of cost-effective AD risk reduction approaches for women that may decrease sex-based disparities in AD, which, in turn, should reduce the public health costs of AD. Our research plan aligns with the NIH priority of Advancing Science for the Health of Women, as well as the 2019-2023 Trans-NIH Strategic Plan for Women’s Health Research Strategic Goal 1 objective to identify immediate, mid-, and long-term effects of exposures on health and disease outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genome-wide association studies have identified over 200 independent loci that influence coronary artery disease (CAD) risk, yet determining the causal genes connecting genetic variation to disease susceptibility has lagged. Leveraging computational pipelines and machine learning models using large-scale functional genomic datasets, and scalable functional genomic screens with targeted validation, our study systematically identifies the functional regulatory elements that contain the risk variants and regulate the expression of target genes and phenotypic outcomes at CAD loci. Our results provide (1) novel insights into tissue/cell type-specific contributions to the genetic basis of CAD, and (2) an innovative computational and experimental framework for systematic variant-to-function discoveries.

PHR: Invasive aspergillosis is associated with high mortality rates in patients with suppressed or ineffective immune systems. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The optimal approach to predicting cardiovascular risk in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) is unknown. Emerging evidence suggests that global indices of cardiovascular functional capacity (VO2Peak) may offer a potential solution for better risk stratifying patients with CKD using state-of-the-art cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) technology. The present study will be the first to compare head-to-head CPET with clinically used diagnostic tools, and to develop a new risk stratification model for predicting cardiovascular outcomes in patients with advanced CKD stage 5D (on hemodialysis).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative We study how exposure to a major natural disaster affects health decision-making and outcomes: risky sexual behaviors (including transactional sex), whether to be tested for sexually transmitted infections (STIs), new STI infections, and COVID-19-related behaviors. In addition, we study how changes in preferences and psychological factors may mediate these effects, by taking measurements of risk preference, time preference, present bias, and motivated belief biases in our study population. Finally, we shed light on whether a public health program helps shield communities from the effects of the disaster on health decision-making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is a life threatening disease that results when T lymphocytes mount an aberrant autoimmune response that destroys insulin producing cells within the pancreas. However, it is now clear that B lymphocytes play an important role in supporting the activation of T1D inducing T lymphocyte responses. A B lymphocyte targeting strategy tested in a previous clinical trial was only partially effective as a possible T1D intervention approach, thus, the goal of the present proposal is to further identify developmental characteristics of T1D relevant B lymphocytes which may help identify a means to pharmaceutically eliminate or inactivate such cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Exercise stimulates robust changes in skeletal muscle transcriptional programs, resulting in complex physiological outputs that elicit improvements in body health and performance. PGC1a, a focus of previous studies, is the transient ‘on switch‘ promoting nuclear receptors PPARd and ERRg to activate the oxidative transcriptional program. In contrast, this renewal proposa l focuses on the missing ‘off switch‘ program mediated by the corepressor BCL6, a conserved exercise regulated cofactor, that restores the basal metabolic states that precede and follow exercise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance  Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) affects more than a million people in the United States, alone, and there is presently no cure, with limited preventive measures for this condition. We recently discovered that the inflamed mouse and human colonic epithelium produces extracellular vesicles containing IL-1 family cytokines, including IL-1 and IL-18, that exacerbate T cell-mediated colitis and cause anti-TNF therapy failure. This application aims to provide mechanistic insight into this pathogenic cross-talk between intestinal epithelial cells and T cells, and to identify potential targets to address anti-TNF therapy failure using murine colitis models and clinical specimens from IBD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Patients at high risk for acute kidney injury are often identified late and often do not receive recommended diagnostic and therapeutic interventions, with drugs being the most common cause; yet are potentially preventable. Clinical decision support to physicians in the form of automated alerts and pharmacist guidance for high-risk patients with drug-associated acute kidney injury (D-AKI) could dramatically improve risk assessment, medication use, and drug dosing in even non-drug-associated acute kidney injury. In this randomized control trial application, we will test whether adult hospitalized patients with D-AKI, cared for by physicians randomized to receive clinical decision support with an advanced pharmacist-led intervention, will have a lower risk for dialysis and premature death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Although increasing racial and ethnic diversity in the biomedical research workforce is a national priority, there is a dearth of evidence-based strategies to promote diversity. To address this important knowledge gap, we propose utilizing a positive-deviance methodology to identify strategies to promote the development of physician- scientist professional identity among medical students historically underrepresented in medicine by race/ethnicity. Results from our study have the potential to influence how medical schools train minoritized physician-scientists to build a more diverse biomedical research workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This project aims to develop catheter lock solutions containing a natural prodrug, S-nitrosoglutathione, to generate nitric oxide, a natural drug with potent antimicrobial and antithrombogenic properties. Nitric oxide releases from the catheter lumen as well as the exterior catheter surface, protecting the entire catheter from infectious and thrombotic complications. Our advanced formulations of S-nitrosoglutathione deliver safe and effective levels of nitric oxide to meet the locking needs of central venous catheters in applications such as hemodialysis and chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PUBLIC NARRATIVE Congenital cytomegalovirus (cCMV) infection is the leading infectious cause of birth defects in the US, causing long-term neurologic deficits, most commonly hearing loss, in up to 5,000 births each year in the US alone. This common infection, most dangerous to the fetus when acquired for the first time during pregnancy, is the cause of up to 25% of infant hearing loss. This project will use a unique cohort of 399 mothers acutely infected with CMV during pregnancy to define immune correlates associated with reduced fetal transmission and disease and define mechanistic impact of these responses in mathematical and placental organoid models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative We investigate the brain mechanisms that underlie the ability of normal-hearing listeners to navigate complex acoustic environments, shift their attention between different sources of sound, and comprehend conversations in noisy environments. A clearer understanding of the mechanisms underlying these abilities will reveal the origin of selective- listening difficulties, and may inspire the design of more effective hearing aids and cochlear implants. Furthermore, malfunctions of both the prefrontal and auditory cortex are associated with neurological diseases such as tinnitus, dyslexia, and schizophrenia; and therefore, our research contributes to the basic understanding of cognitive control and pathways underlying neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Increasing numbers of studies have indicated that, most fast food and common grocery items, contain large amount of phosphate-based food additives, which are highly absorbable. Our recent study in mice demonstrated that dietary phosphate loading that mimic the level of US consumption leads to reduced spontaneous locomotor activity, exercise capacity, and resting metabolic rate in normal mice by impairing skeletal muscle mitochondrial function and fat oxidation. Our current proposal aims to determine the relevance of animal observation in otherwise healthy humans, which may have a major public health implication in regard to optimal level of phosphate intake to maintain cardiovascular health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The goal of this study is to investigate how, in pancreatic islet beta cells, the networks of cytoskeletal polymers microtubules are built and regulated to optimize insulin vesicle biosynthesis, transport, and secretion. Deregulating microtubule networks causes abnormal insulin secretion in response to glucose stimulation and diabetes, which is indicative of their high physiological significance. We expect to uncover fundamental molecular mechanisms to help improve beta-cell function in our fight against diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atrial and ventricular cardiac arrhythmias are a major cause of morbidity and mortality. Reactive oxidative stress, mitophagy, fibrosis and electrophysiological abnormalities are known to contribute to cardiac arrhythmias, however, there currently is no imaging to visualize and understand their mechanisms in arrhythmogenesis. The overall objective of this proposed project is to use a 3D panoramic imaging system to visualize these processes in transgenic murine hearts with atrial and ventricular arrhythmias to develop new treatment strategies for humans with arrhythmias.

PHR: Project Narrative – MDRC Center Overview The MDRC oversees and provides research cores, enrichment activities and pilot and feasibility grant programs to support and enhance the national research effort related to diabetes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: NARRATIVE There is an ongoing effort to develop therapies for glycogen storage disease (GSD) but currently there is a lack of biomarkers to assess GSD progression and/or treatment efficacy non-invasively. We propose to develop a quantitative test for reporting glycogen load in muscle and brain using standard MRI equipment. This approach will result in a non-invasive tool for imaging glycogen changes in vivo with high spatial resolution and applicable to all glycogen storage diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The proposed research aims to assess the multiple forms and paths of stigma and substance use as they relate to pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) use for HIV prevention. How stigma and an evolving public health landscape impact PrEP use among BMSM who use substances is unknown. The current application focuses on addressing critical and novel questions to improving the essential building blocks of biomedical prevention approaches by providing crucial information for enhancing interventions to lower HIV prevalence among substance using BMSM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Recent studies in the mouse have shown that during development, epicardially-derived cells (EPDCs) contribute to the formation of the atrioventricular valves. When this process is perturbed, mice develop abnormal valves, that are very similar to those seen in humans with Myxomatous Valve Disease (MVD). Increasing our insight into how EPDCs contribute to the developing valves in health and disease may further our understanding of the pathogenesis of valve disease in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Developing a functional cure for HIV/AIDS requires further studies of HIV-1 and host interactions. We will investigate how HIV-1 RNA modifications regulate viral latency and persistence in CD4+ T cells from HIV-1- infected individuals on antiretroviral therapy. Understanding mechanisms of post-transcriptional regulation of HIV-1 RNA will help develop therapeutic strategies to target RNA modifications for inhibiting HIV-1 replication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Understanding how active mechanisms in the ear participate in signaling the occurrence of eye movements will shed light on how vision contributes to hearing. This work is relevant to both hearing disorders (e.g. sensorineural and age-related hearing loss), as well as a broad array of conditions involving communication deficits more generally (e.g. dyslexia, autism, and age-related cognitive impairments).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative This project will reveal how neural coding, plasticity and selective attention are organized within intermixed, non-topographic representations in cerebral cortex. Mouse somatosensory cortex is used as a model system. This basic research on cerebral cortex function will enable future investigation of neural circuit and coding deficits in neurodevelopmental disorders such as autism and ADHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To bring neurosciences to the forefront of STEM and health care research, Mentored Experiences to Expand Opportunities in Research version 3 (“METEOR v. 3”) will provide hands-on research experiences for local high school students and STEM teachers-in-training during the summer academic break with continued activities through the school year. METEOR v. 3 will immerse Washington, DC metro area high schoolers and future STEM teachers from diverse cultural, ethnic, and socioeconomic backgrounds into inquiry-based biomedical, behavioral, and clinical research at Children’s National Hospital and its Research Institute. With a comprehensive mentorship program and core curriculum, METEOR v. 3 will employ unique, research-based educational practices designed to stimulate interest and advance knowledge in the neurosciences, neurobiology, and related fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Humans with stroke lesion invading the cortico-spinal tracts (CST) suffer from the most severe and permanent motor deficits, which include loss of finger dexterity and muscle weakness. Here, we aim at designing a new deep brain stimulation therapy to treat post-stroke muscle weakness and motor paresis by targeting the motor thalamus, i.e., a subcortical relay with outgoing excitatory connectivity to sensory/motor cortices. For this, we will demonstrate that motor thalamus stimulation increases the excitability of the motor cortex and that these excitatory inputs can potentiate motor output in intact animals and animals with chronic lesions of the CST both when anesthetized and during behaving motor tasks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our research goal is to understand how neuronal dendrites in the mammalian retina compute motion signals. A comprehensive understanding of motion detection at the dendritic level is a critical first step towards understanding normal visual motion detection, and treating visual dysfunction that occurs in diseased states. Furthermore, the knowledge gained from the proposed study will have broader implications as it will address the general principles of neural computation in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Skilled movement is believed to emerge from the learned dynamical patterns of neural activity in motor control brain regions. However, movement related activity in the cerebellar neurons is best understood at the cellular level. Therefore, we will test the hypothesis that cerebellar Purkinje cells also employ a population code that synergizes spike rate modulation and synchronous firing to produce robust disinhibition of recipient neurons in the cerebellar nuclei leading to kinematic alterations of learned, dexterous motor behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early detection of HIV using a self-testing kit at home can save lives of millions of HIV-infected patients and their partners by enabling early intervention and treatment options preventing spreading and maturation to AIDS. This project defines a novel approach to detect HIV RNA based on engineered CRISPR/Cas12a system coupled with an automated microfluidic-based device. To make it amenable to the resource-constrained settings, our proposed diagnostic approach will follow the ASSURED (Affordable, Sensitive, Specific, User-friendly, Rapid and robust, Equipment-free and Deliverable to end-users) criteria as recommended by the World Health Organization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Adeno associated virus (AAV) vectors can be used to deliver broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) against human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) to permanently suppress virus in animal models, making them promising candidates for HIV prevention and therapy. In this proposal, we will determine which aspects of AAV vectors cause the development of immune responses against the delivered bNAbs and engineer new AAV vectors to avoid this. This work will enhance our understanding of the mechanisms vector immunogenicity and contribute to the development of future HIV cure strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Critical for maintaining blood glucose homeostasis, G6PC1 activity lies in the pathological crosshairs of diabetes and glycogen storage disease type 1a. Our methodological approach seeks to define the mechanistic underpinnings of G6PC1 activity as well as the consequences of disease-associated mutations on the functional cycle and enzyme stability. Completion of the proposed aims will lead to the most comprehensive description of G6PC1 functional dynamics to date, which will inform the rational design of targeted therapeutic strategies that alleviate the complications arising from metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The common deletion variant of the GSTM1 gene has been associated with kidney disease progression in several human cohorts. Deletion of the gene augments kidney disease in mouse models. The current proposal will investigate the transsulfuration metabolic pathway that governs the effect of GSTM1 deletion in both mice and humans, and has therapeutic implications in an individualized and precision medicine approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance: The goal of this project is to develop radiomic-image (Rad-I) maps of spatial tumor extent on clinical MRI scans and histopathologically validate their efficacy in non-invasively distinguishing (a) viable/infiltrative tumor from vasogenic edema and (b) tumor recurrence from treatment-related effects, in glioblastoma tumors. Our proposed multi-institutional validation will demonstrate the clinical utility of Rad-I maps as a noninvasive alternative to stereotactic biopsies in identifying the tumor extent, ultimately paving the way for tailored surgical and post-treatment response management, thereby improving long-term outcomes in patients with glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project is relevant to the NIH’s mission and to public health because successful completion of this work will finally unveil the two-decade-long promise of using small RNAs as anti-cancer agents. Here, using a relevant ligand and receptor pair, coupled to an endosomal escape agent and a fully modified miRNA that has increased stability and targeting, we will succeed in generating the first anti-cancer small RNA therapeutic. Indeed, the benefit to cancer therapeutics will be enormous through simply (and finally) including all these essential components into an easily synthesized, all-encompassing agent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Neuroscience is one of the fastest growing areas of biomedical research, with many unanswered questions about the basic mechanism of brain function and how dysfunction at the genetic, cellular, and systemic levels leads to neurological diseases and disorders. All of these areas of research are increasingly incorporating cutting-edge computational research techniques, yet women and other historically underrepresented groups (HUGs) are less common in computational fields. This nine-week summer training program will enhance the research career trajectories of HUG undergraduates through a coordinated set of elements focused on neuroscience research, building computational fluency, and professional skills development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative.  In the United States ~750,000 patients/year develop sepsis syndrome. In these patients, the overall mortality rate is 28.6% (~215,000 deaths/year). The proposed studies will provide a mechanistic understanding of a critical role of epigenetic modification of macrophage transcriptional factors and effectors in the development of sepsis. This is a new and novel conceptual work to elucidate how macrophage transcriptional factors and effectors regulate immune function and target these important effectors will improve the survival outcome of sepsis patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Despite years of effective suppressive antiretroviral therapy (ART), latent HIV-infected cells can persist in people with HIV (PWH) and reintroduce disseminated HIV infection after cessation of ART, preventing the functional cure of PWH. The anti-HIV immune response in most PWH is inadequate to effectively eliminate reactivated latent infected cells, necessitating the development of strategies to boost the anti-HIV immune response to enable it to clear the reservoir after reactivation. We propose to develop cell-specific lentivector particles that can be injected into PWH to direct in vivo generation of T cells expressing anti-HIV therapeutic genes (CAR- chimeric antigen receptor and/or bNAb-broadly neutralizing antibodies, respectively) in PWH to provide them with sustained and robust anti-HIV CAR-T cell and antibody responses which will enable them to achieve sustained ART-free remission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most deadly of all brain tumors, and many patients die within one year of diagnosis. Our proposal will identify how the beta2 isoform of the nuclear receptor ESRRB, which is expressed at higher levels in longer-term GBM survivors, works as a potent inhibitor of GBM. These studies will provide powerful preclinical evidence for a future novel therapeutic strategy for GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stiffening of the elastic arteries occurs during midlife and contributes to late life risk of Alzheimer's disease. Through this project, we will determine whether midlife arterial stiffness contributes to cognitive aging through an increase in cerebrovascular pulsatility and subsequent loss of brain tissue integrity. Overall, this project will identify the earliest mechanisms linking vascular aging to the loss of brain tissue integrity leading to new targets for interventions aimed at preventing age-related cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work is focused on the advanced integration of HIV NAAT locked and stored in hydrogels and detected electrochemically with boron-doped diamond sensor microelectrode arrays. Each spot will individually readout amplification in what is essentially a novel, digital, electrochemical lateral flow assay. The successful completion of this project will deliver a demonstrator platform for the semi-quantitative readout of HIV viral loads at home.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative: Gut dysbiosis in early childhood might cause or contribute to early-onset type 1 diabetes (T1D). Here we propose to develop and implement analytic methods to investigate temporal changes in gut microbiota in relation to the onset of islet autoimmunity and T1D using data from The Environmental Determinants of Diabetes in the Young (TEDDY) study. Our goal is to identify microbial biomarkers of islet autoimmunity and T1D, profoundly improving understanding of T1D etiology and potentially leading to the development of microbiome-based therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Emerging and re-emerging respiratory viruses are a significant threat to public health and the global economy. While a dysregulated immune response is believed to cause acute lung injury and severe pneumonia following SARS-CoV-2 and other pathogenic human coronavirus infections, the basis for such deleterious host response is not well understood. Here, we will investigate the role of SARS-CoV-2 structural proteins/viral RNA and myeloid cell-intrinsic TLR-ERK1/2 activation in causing excessive lung inflammation and pathology and test the therapeutic potential of blocking ERK1/2 signaling in reducing lung pathology and providing improved protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Hepatic encephalopathy (HE) is a serious complication of chronic liver diseases, observed in nearly 70% of patients with cirrhosis and is one of the most common reasons for hospitalization and increased mortality rates in these patients. With the rising costs associated with managing HE and the lack of effective treatment options, gaining an understanding of the mechanisms that cause HE can potentially lead to therapeutic interventions to help improve the outcome of patients with this syndrome. This proposal investigates how changes in brain cholesterol, which occurs in other neurological disorders, can influence HE with the aim to target cholesterol as a potential therapeutic option.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant for public health as it develops and tests a novel method to improve the sleep of individuals with opioid use disorder through a health equity lens. The overdose epidemic is a national problem, and the majority of individuals in treatment for opioid use disorder also have insomnia. The goal of this project is to develop and test a brief behavioral treatment for insomnia in persons with opioid use disorder and to determine if this novel treatment also helps individuals abstain from substance use in addition to improving their sleep.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) affects 8.7 million people globally and 1.6 million in the US, and as many as 4-5 million Americans are at risk of developing T1D. T1D results in destruction of beta cells and loss of insulin, prompting an urgent need for regeneration and replacement of fully mature, functional beta cells. Here, I am developing unique genetic tools to elucidate the final crucial steps in human beta cell differentiation, understanding that will allow both generation of fully functional replacement human beta cells, and also identification of druggable targets for beta cell regeneration, highly required for treatment of people with T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Environmental exposures may be important in the etiopathogenesis of psychiatric diseases involving reward processing deficits. This proposal examines the role that per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) may have in psychiatric risk, especially for an anhedonia phenotype with relevance to depression. Given widespread exposure to PFAS (detectable in most human blood), it is critical to examine whether and how exposures may influence the risk of neurological disease and to determine whether those with high PFAS levels should be monitored for heightened reward processing deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The field of neuroscience and regenerative sciences needs ongoing innovation to address the challenges of understanding brain function and brain-related disorders, and a diverse workforce increases the perspectives from which to draw from to solve these challenges. The University of Wisconsin Eau Claire – Mayo Clinic Regenerative Neuroscience Scholars (ReNS) Program enables undergraduates from backgrounds underrepresented in STEM to obtain high-quality training in regenerative neuroscience research. Using innovative and coordinated approaches in recruitment, research, curriculum, and mentoring, this program will prepare students for success in careers in research and Ph.D. training in neuroscience and regenerative sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative: The Carolina Summer Fellowship Program (CSFP) at UNC has helped several undergraduate students from underrepresented (UR) backgrounds matriculate into careers in research. To address the disparity in representation in neuroscience research careers, we propose the CSFP-Neuro program, which utilizes our well-established summer research infrastructure to increase the number of UR individuals in neuroscience research. By providing top-level summer research experiences in the neurobiology of disease by trained mentors, coupled with career mentoring and professional development that continues beyond the summer, students will be well prepared for successful careers in neuroscience research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This project is aimed at developing safe and effective smart lipid siRNA nanoparticles to regulate long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) associated with cancer metastasis and drug-resistance in triple-negative breast cancer patients. Tumor- specific silencing of cancer-promoting lncRNAs with the nanoparticles offers a novel therapy to treat invasive breast cancer with minimal side-effects, to enhance the efficacy of chemotherapy and/or immunotherapy, and to eventually eradicate the disease and improve the survival of cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Elimination of glucagon receptor signaling shortens lifespan and healthspan in mice. Preliminary data presented in this proposal suggests that increasing glucagon signaling can improve metabolic and physical function in aging mice. Herein, we propose to extend these preliminary findings to investigate the potential to enhance glucagon signaling to extend healthspan and lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to develop a new approach to inhibit androgen receptor (AR) activity and stop the growth of prostate cancer cells that have developed resistance to standard anti-androgen agents using peptoid conjugates that potently inhibit AR activity while simultaneously eliciting an innate immune response that can be leveraged to induce immune cell killing of the drug-resistant tumor. By combining the development of peptoid conjugates that inhibit AR activity with an investigation of their potential to elicit an immune response that can be leveraged for tumor killing, our research has the potential to make significant contributions to prostate cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Our understanding of the connection between housing relocation interventions and mental health remains limited by a lack of high-quality studies assessing projects with effective implementation strategies. Our proposal integrates and addresses these needs, linking geographic and psychological expertise with established community partnerships to study the impact of such an intervention on a discrete sub-population of residents in Flint, Michigan, via a longitudinal assessment of the natural experiment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Acute kidney injury (AKI) remains a very important and growing global unmet need with lack of effective therapies. In addition to the adverse effects on patient morbidity and mortality associated with AKI it has long term consequences, leading to chronic kidney disease. Our goal is to understand the mechanisms of kidney injury and repair to be able to develop therapies for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a prevalent cause of heart failure and death. Many cases of DCM have a well-defined genetic basis, and this genetic knowledge holds great promise for developing mechanism-based treatments to halt or revert disease progression. Using models of inherited DCM, we identified a set of candidate therapeutic genes, and this renewal application will investigate their potential utility as drug targets using human in vitro models, human population genetics, and a mouse in vivo model of DCM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We previously identified dual leucine zipper kinase (DLK) and leucine zipper kinase (LZK) as promising neuroprotective targets in retinal ganglion cell (RGC) degenerations/optic neuropathies like glaucoma. More recently, we have used chemical genetic and clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeat (CRISPR)-based screens in RGCs to identify a set of sterile 20 (STE20) kinases that regulate DLK/LZK. In this proposal, we explore novel mechanisms by which STE20 kinases regulate this key neuronal injury pathway and exploit this knowledge to develop robust neuroprotective and neuroregenerative strategies that we then test in rodent models of glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative With nearly 6 million Americans live with heart failure (HF) with 670,00+ cases added each year, HF is a relentlessly progressive disease that is associated with an unacceptably high death rate. SERCA2a, SDF-1, and AC6 have been tested in randomized clinical trials showing no significant efficacy, calling for the identification and characterization of a new molecular target of HF therapeutics. Based on the extensive preliminary studies, we here propose that fortilin, abundantly expressed in the heart, is an excellent molecular target of HF therapeutics and test the hypothesis using molecular, cellular, whole-animal methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This research addresses our recent discovery revealing that pancreatic beta cells have an unusual glycomic profile relatively deficient in the expression of sialic acids. Supporting data reveal that mice bearing augmented expression of immune tolerogenic sialic acids among pancreatic beta cells are protected from insulitis, hyperglycemia, and the immunological destruction in a mouse model of Type 1 diabetes. This proposal will investigate these findings that may explain the susceptibility of pancreatic beta cells to immune attack in triggering autoimmune disease and how to inhibit this disease process.

PHR: Our proposed studies aim to understand the cellular communication in the heart and the cross-talk between the heart and brain in heart failure to further our understanding sympathetic nerve activity regulation in heart failure. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Astrocytes serve critical roles in the function of the brain, such that disruptions to astrocytes underlie several neurodevelopmental disorders, making it crucial to improve our understanding of the signals that direct astrocyte development. This proposal will investigate primary cilia, signaling antennae present in almost every cell with critical roles in development, to determine how they regulate different stages of astrocyte development. This work will inform novel functions of astrocyte cilia and advance our fundamental understanding of ciliary signaling in developing astrocytes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Drinking becomes excessive when it causes or elevates the risk for alcohol-related problems or complicates the management of other health problems. The alarming prevalence of excessive alcohol use (EAU) among veterans is concerning and the vigilance and action to identify veterans with EAU is of importance. The consequences of under-detection of EAU, thus delayed intervention are serious because the potential consequence of adverse alcohol-related health conditions is increased with the quantity and duration of alcohol consumed. In this application, we propose to systematically study novel and mechanism-based biomarkers as the screening tool for EAU. Further, we will determine the diagnostic performance of a risk model for EAU prediction using statistical mechanics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorder directly affects over 16 million individuals in the United States alone and presents a tremendous burden on society. The neuronal circuits that drive the negative affective state associated with alcohol dependence are only beginning to be understood. The present proposal will seek to gain a better understanding of the role of the basolateral amygdala to ventral subiculum circuit in a rodent model of alcohol dependence in an effort to identify novel neural substrates for the development of more effective treatments for alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Connections between neurons are sculpted during brain development by the complement system, a network of proteins that normally works with immune cells throughout the body to help fight infection and cleanup damaged tissue. We are investigating the function of the Sez6 gene family to determine if it controls abnormal complement activation in the brain and whether this contributes to the incorrect connections between nerve cells that can give rise to autism spectrum disorders (ASD). By understanding how this contributes to ASD we hope to design treatments in the future that repair this pathway to protect the brain from ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this project is to induce localized immune tolerance to transplanted human beta cells derived from renewable stem cell sources as a treatment for type 1 diabetes. This project presents a significant step forward in the development of alternative, renewable, and off-the-shelf sources of insulin producing cells for current cell replacement therapy efforts. This project addresses the key technical challenge of systemic administration of immunosuppressive drugs to protect beta cell grafts through introduction of a highly localized immunomodulation and as such, represents the highest level of translational innovation.
