IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because vascular deficiencies are among the leading causes of cardiovascular disease and disorders, but their causes and underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. The results of the proposed studies will significantly contribute to a better understanding of the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying the role of paracrine signaling derived from the vascular system in the regeneration and repair of ischemic tissues via activation of tissue-specific stem cells and stem cell niches. Thus, the proposal is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission and is likely to lead to the identification new targets and therapeutic strategies for improving vascular repair and tissue regeneration in affected patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Mosquitoes employ their olfactory receptors to detect and prey on humans, transmitting grave diseases that kill over a million people yearly; however, the molecular mechanism by which olfactory receptors interact with odorant molecules remains elusive. The proposed research program will provide the first structural and mechanistic characterization of insect olfactory receptors bound to odors, including human-emitted volatiles. This work will shed light on the basic biochemical mechanism of odor detection and enable the development of novel insect repellents that bind to olfactory receptors and prevent human host-seeking, addressing the relentless spread of insect-borne diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the K23 proposal is to provide necessary training in cultural adaptation, implementation science, and social network analysis to determine whether a social network-focused lifestyle intervention, based in a primary care setting, is feasible and acceptable for immigrant men from South Asia and West Africa and whether health behaviors will improve among participants’ social networks. The proposed work aims to develop a community-informed program, based on evidence-based lifestyle programs, adapted for the specific needs for immigrant men and to understand the diffusion of health behaviors among participants’ social networks, a potentially untapped resource for lifestyle behavior change.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Research has established that compounds aimed at CRF receptors are protective against dependence-induced alcohol drinking, and our recent findings show that compounds targeting CRF receptors are also protective against excessive binge-like drinking in mice when targeted to regions of that modulate stress and emotional behaviors. Expected results in the current application will significantly expand our recent observations by showing the CRF circuits linking stress and reward centers in the brain modulate binge-like ethanol drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will explore MRI markers that can objectively identify individuals as early as possible who have brain abnormalities and would therefore benefit from therapeutic interventions in congenital heart disease (CHD). It will also determine relative effects of deleterious genetic variants and oxygenated cerebral blood supply on abnormal cortical development and will inform us potential causes and mechanisms of the abnormalities in CHD. Our quantitative markers may be useful for evaluating the impact and success of therapeutic interventions and understanding the efficacy and mechanisms of action of the interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The computerized spinal stability assessment, for patients who have cancer that has spread to their spine, will offer more accurate prediction of the need for spine surgery to the patients, and with a much greater likelihood that the patients and their families can get the evaluation done promptly near their home, saving them time, expense, and inconvenience. The recommendation for non-surgical treatment will be made with increased assurance that the risk of a spine fracture is low, and the analysis methods will provide additional guidance on allowable, safe levels of their activities of daily living, which typically stratify out to household ambulation, community ambulation, and various levels of exercise and load bearing activities (e.g., carrying grandchildren, groceries, laundry, yard work). Those patients, who do need surgery, will be offered minimally invasive surgical techniques that will shorten their hospital stay and recovery time, and allow them to return home to their families sooner.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The National Academies of Science (NAS) and several other entities have identified a critical shortage of veterinarians in research, and the NIH has identified a need for increased emphasis in clinical and translational research. These issues have a direct bearing on the health and welfare of the US public - most notably veterinary scientist contributions to animal models of human health and disease and most critically, in zoonotic diseases. The proposed training program addresses both these essential needs by increasing the pool of veterinarians with exposure to careers in research, and based on the history of the program, it is anticipated that a significant number of these trainees will pursue advanced training in research.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: The vervet/African green monkey (AGM) is a valuable nonhuman primate model for studies of aging and  Alzheimer's disease, cardiometabolic disorders, infectious disease and vaccine development,  neuroscience, and genetics. The Vervet Research Colony (VRC) is the only NIH-supported biomedical  research resource dedicated to providing animals, biological samples, and data, as well as training  and consultation on the use of vervets/AGMs for translational research. Continued genetic and  phenotypic characterization of the vervet, along with the maintenance and expansion of the VRC data  archive and biological sample repository are all critical for meeting the needs of the scientific  community.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The perinatal period presents a `window of opportunity' for environmental stressors and caregiver mental health to impose risk to infant offspring; however, the mechanisms underlying these pathways are not fully understood, especially in the context of a large-scale disaster such as the COVID-19 pandemic. The fundamental scientific premise of the proposed study is that perinatal stress, enhanced by an unprecedented pandemic, is linked to caregiver posttraumatic stress and emotion dysregulation, which in turn shapes the early caregiving environment influences infant stress reactivity and dysregulation through biobehavioral processes, including DNA methylation and cellular aging. This time sensitive work is critical for identifying and driving novel approaches to prevention and intervention in vulnerable populations, especially during times of crisis.

PHR: Our team has developed a library of CB1 negative allosteric modulators (NAMs) and found one such NAM RTICBM-74 dose-dependently reduces alcohol consumption without inducing anxiety-like behaviors in rats. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative This project is designed to determine if a computer-delivered cognitive-behavioral treatment can improve the otherwise poor alcohol use disorder treatment outcomes for individuals with a co- occurring anxiety disorder. In the past, we showed that this treatment does improve outcomes for these individuals when delivered by a therapist. If the present work shows that the computer- delivered version is also effective, it would provide an inexpensive program with virtually unlimited scalability to enable access to the treatment by many more individuals than is currently the case.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Persons who inject drugs (PWID) represent a key `superspreader' population for HIV/AIDS that drives the epidemic in the US and other countries and it is exceptionally difficult to identify and reach these high-risk populations with existing intervention strategies (e.g., ART and PrEP). This proposal will develop and test a novel gene-drive concept to target the high-risk superspreaders who most need therapy. Gene drives would be particularly useful for treating PWID and those who engage in injection drug use in resource-limited settings, including the rural US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-Hispanic Black women have higher rates of preterm birth (< 37 completed weeks gestation) compared with non-Hispanic White women. Preterm birth is the leading cause of infant mortality among Black infants. We will examine biological aging as a marker of social factors (e.g., experiences of racial discrimination) and biomarker indicating risk of preterm birth among Black women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pneumonia causes high rates of patient morbidity and mortality, through poorly understood mechanisms. We recently discovered a novel infection-dependent mechanism of lung injury and end organ dysfunction, where pathogens interact with the endothelium to elicit production of cytotoxic tau variants. Here, we examine mechanisms of pneumonia-elicited endothelial cytotoxic tau production and assess the role of cytotoxic tau in end organ dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Therapeutics such as Taxol are indicated for the treatment of patients with breast, ovarian and lung malignancies; however, resistance frequently emerges and/or patients develop toxicities that limit the duration of treatment. We have engineered novel Taxol-like molecules that cause both apoptosis and durable senescence in therapeutically recalcitrant tumors and will use chemical, molecular and biological methods to optimization these molecules for therapeutic efficacy and tolerability. The long-term goal is to generate best-in- class Taxol-like molecules rigorously evaluated to meet pre-clinical efficacy and toxicity benchmarks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Viral pneumonia, often due to infection with influenza A virus and SARS-CoV-2, represents the leading infectious cause of death worldwide. Regulatory T (Treg) cells coordinate recovery from viral pneumonia, but a subset of Tregs known as induced Tregs (iTregs) have the potential to become unstable and lose their suppressive and reparative functions. We aim to identify mechanisms through which iTregs become unstable and target these mechanisms to promote their utility in hastening recovery from viral pneumonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Malaria and other vector-borne diseases impose devastating impacts on global health and human welfare, and new tools are now urgently needed to combat these rebounding scourges. We have been leaders in developing gene-drive or "active genetic" technologies to disseminate favorable traits throughout populations such as factors blocking transmission of malarial parasites by Anopheline mosquitoes. We propose to advance these game-changing tools to develop next-generation drive systems and corresponding neutralization elements required to move this promising technology forward to practical implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the prevalence and incidence of dementia appears to be stable or declining in high-income countries, South American countries (SAC) face the opposite scenario, with increased dementia prevalence, probably triggered by a combination of genetic and socioeconomic status (SES) factors. This proposal aims to create the first SAC-based multicenter initiative to study dementia, by combining genomic, neuroimaging, and behavioral (cognitive, clinical, socioeconomic) data. This project constitutes an unprecedented opportunity to foster regional synergy and multilevel research towards the harmonization of global strategies to fight dementia in SAC.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans are at higher risk for chronic respiratory diseases (CRDs), including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and interstitial lung disease, relative to the general population due to deployment-related and occupational exposures and increased rates of smoking. Although early diagnosis and treatment can improve outcomes, no screening programs for the early detection of CRDs currently exist – as a result, many CRDs are detected late, often when symptoms are severe. Unlike for CRDs, screening programs for lung cancer using low-dose chest computed tomography (CT) scans do exist and changes in the lungs due to CRDs can be detected on these studies. This project will use specialized computer software to analyze chest CT scans obtained for lung cancer screening to detect changes in the lungs due to CRDs. These computer measurements will be used to develop a tool to help identify undiagnosed CRD among Veterans so that they may receive timely, personalized care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Soil transmitted helminths (STH) are a major public health problem worldwide, disproportionately affecting the poorest and most vulnerable communities. Intensive animal-human mixing with livestock and companion animals combined with poor hygiene and sanitation in these communities can lead to transmission of zoonotic infections as well as result in zoonotic sources of infections. Most epidemiological surveys and mathematical models of STH do not account for or measure the risk of infections acquired from zoonotic sources either by direct contact with animals or animal feces or indirectly from the environment. Our program aims to use a One Health framework to examine the interconnectedness between human, animal and environmental reservoirs of STH by integrating epidemiological, environmental and qualitative research data with state-of- art molecular techniques into species-specific transmission models to better inform monitoring and elimination strategies for this neglected tropical disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) affects over 20% of aged adults and is very common among Veterans due significant tobacco use. PAD is due to the progressive blockage of peripheral arteries, predominantly to the legs, and results in intermittent claudication (IC) or recurrent muscle pain with activity secondary to insufficient blood supply. Those with PAD and IC experience a progressive decline in walking and poor quality of life. There is no effective medical treatment for PAD and IC. Metformin is a safe and effective treatment for Type 2 diabetes but it can also reduce inflammation, oxidative stress, and improve energy requirements as well as improve blood flow to the legs. Therefore, we will test the ability of Metformin to improve overall functional status, reduce PAD progression, and reduce systemic inflammation in Veterans suffering from PAD and IC in a randomized, placebo controlled trial: Metformin BenefIts Lower Extremities with Intermittent Claudication (MOBILE IC) Trial. The success of this trial may identify a safe and effective treatment for PAD and IC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) afflicts approximately 32 million people worldwide and the five year mortality and readmission rates from HFpEF are 75.7% and 84%, respectively. Pulmonary hypertension is very common in HFpEF (PH-HFpEF) and portends worse prognosis, yet no treatment exists to date. This proposal seeks to establish mitochondria targeted antioxidants as a potential treatment in PH-HFpEF and pave the way for large human studies to enhance health and reduce illness from PH-HFpEF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative These proposed studies have direct applicability to patients who fail to respond to palbociclib. Importantly, there are a variety of pharmacological inhibitors that are currently available targeting multiple components within the newly discovered signaling pathway that mediates palbociclib-induced senescence of lung cancer cells, some of which are clinically used for the treatment of non-cancer related diseases. Positive findings from the proposed research will lead to the identification of novel senolytic targets that can be used to circumvent palbociclib resistance, resulting in decreased tumor progression and improved overall survival in lung cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Using a patho-epidemiology approach, we will address the overarching hypothesis that senescent stromal fibroblasts, especially if they elicit an inflammatory response, promote lethal prostate cancer. Our proposed work is designed to inform the pressing clinical need for identifying which men’s, including Black men’s prostate cancers are very likely to kill and, equally important, which ones are very unlikely to kill. Further, our proposed work is designed to inform novel therapeutics (senolytics) that eliminate senescent stromal fibroblasts in men at risk for progression to or already harboring metastatic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Thoracic aortic aneurysm is a disease process involving degenerative dilation of the aorta leading to eventual rupture and death unless treated with complex surgical intervention. The proposed work aims to delineate the pathogenesis of aortic aneurysm at the cellular level while also exploring the pro-regenerative properties of extracellular matrix hydrogel in an animal model. Our ultimate goal of this research is to improve screening and surveillance of this patient population while also investigating potential regenerative therapies that halt the process of aneurysm formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a dramatic increase in use of telehealth for cancer care, which has facilitated access to care for many Americans, particularly rural individuals. We do not yet know on a national level where and for whom telehealth has potential to improve cancer care access, which we will examine, along with what patient, provider, or referral network factors are associated with actual telehealth use, and how telehealth use in cancer care impacts outcomes. Then we will estimate when telehealth use is most likely to improve cancer care equity for rural areas, and the diverse populations within those areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatitis B virus (HBV) remains a major global health problem and a leading cause of liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. While antiviral therapies achieve long-term viral suppression, they can rarely clear infection or induce a state of long-term control of infection after treatment is discontinued. Efforts to identify strategies to eradicate or induce treatment-free long-term HBV remission are critical.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chemical and toxic substances, such as herbicides and pesticides pose some of the most common threats to environmental and human health. Our studies are designed to identify effects of prenatal pesticide exposure on child neurodevelopment and the role of the gut microbiome in mediating pesticide-induced adverse health effects. Findings of our study will ultimately result in precision risk assessment and precision prevention strategies to improve human health worldwide.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The increase in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) among veterans in recent years presents a significant clinical problem in the VA healthcare system. Major concerns for IBD veteran patients are the increased disease morbidity and risk of therapies. Further research is needed to develop safe and effective agents that enhance mucosal repair and reduce immune-suppression. Previous work from our lab has indicates that mitochondrial respiration promotes ulcer healing. This finding led us to postulate that increasing mitochondrial respiration constitutes a novel therapeutic goal in IBD. To improve mitochondrial function in IBD, we developed AuPhos, an oral agent that enhances mitochondrial electron transport that potentiates mitochondrial bio-energetics and mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (mtROS) production. The current project will ascertain the impact of this novel gold compound (AuPhos) on mitochondrial function and ulcer healing in mouse models of colitis as well as biopsy tissue explants from veterans with IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project focuses on mesenchymal BMP signaling in regulating fetal lung morphogenesis and its relevance to congenital pulmonary airway malformation, a human disease with perinatal mortality ranging from 9% to as high as 49%. In particular, novel mechanisms by which mesenchymal BMP signaling pathway regulates airway smooth muscle cell growth, elastin expression, and epithelial progenitor commitment during lung development will be determined in new mouse models, which are impossible to be studied in human patients. Our proposed project will not only reveal the pathogenic mechanisms underlying prenatal pulmonary cysts, but also lay the foundation for future development of intervention and prevention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anorexia nervosa (AN) is a severe and treatment-resistant psychiatric illness of unknown etiology, with pernicious and alarming symptoms such as driven exercise. This study is novel in its use of decision tasks and neuroimaging to index reward and reinforcement learning among adolescents with AN, specifically in an effort to elucidate biobehavioral factors that determine for whom and why driven exercise may arise and be maintained. A mechanistic understanding of the processes that contribute to heterogeneity in AN symptomology will assist in informing precision treatment development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with dementia represent the fastest growing population of hospice users in the U.S. and account for a quarter of all hospice spending. Behavioral symptoms such as agitation, anxiety, and hallucinations are nearly universal in advanced dementia and, despite limited evidence to support their use, the mainstay of such symptom management in hospice is off-label use of psychotropic medications. Given the growing number of patients with dementia enrolling in hospice services, a better understanding of 1) the factors that influence psychotropic prescribing in hospice (including patient and caregiver preferences), and 2) the intended and unintended outcomes of such use, are critical in order to inform caregiver, provider, and policy decisions regarding appropriate use of psychotropic medications in end-of-life care for dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) reveals that SETD2 mutation is associated with poor prognosis and survival in ccRCC patients, and although there are links to genome instability and DNA methylation, the direct connection between SETD2 mutation and ccRCC remains unclear. This project aims to use chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by sequencing (ChIP-seq) studies of ccRCC cell lines and patient derived xenograft (PDX) models along with an array of biochemical and cellular assays to determine if loss of SETD2 protein is molecularly distinct from loss of its enzymatic activity. A deeper understanding of whether the specific location of a chromatin-modifying protein plays a critical role in determining the physiological outcome of the mutation will facilitate progress towards patient-tailored and genotype-specific drug therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: During obesity, visceral fat tissue expands causing oxidative stress and the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines that can cause insulin resistance and cardiovascular complications. This project explores the antioxidant bilirubin in molecular detail as a signaling molecule to reduce adiposity and insulin resistance and improve metabolic health. A comprehensive investigation of the signaling preferences for bilirubin may open new avenues for potential new therapeutics for obesity and insulin resistant diabetes, and for cardiovascular diseases in humans.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE mTOR plays a critical role in integrating cues from the immune microenvironment to regulate T cell activation, differentiation and function. In this proposal, we will dissect the role of a novel mechanism by which the immune microenvironment regulates mTORC1 in T cells. Our studies have important implications not only for basic T cell biology but also for vaccine development as well as the development of novel immunotherapies for cancer.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The clinical, social, and financial impact of ineffectively treated Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) are enormous. New pharmacological interventions in combination with first-line trauma-based psychotherapy such as Prolonged Exposure (PE) carries great potential to address the limited efficacy of current pharmacological options. This project will conduct a randomized clinical trial investigating the efficacy and safety to use small doses of the anesthetic ketamine to augment PE therapy among veterans with PTSD. The goal of this intervention is to accelerate the reduction of PTSD symptoms and commonly co-occurring symptoms such as anxiety and depression.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Healthcare providers still rely heavily on opioid narcotics for post-operative pain control despite growing evidence of their risks of longer-term problems. Several novel brain stimulation technologies including transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) are beginning to demonstrate promise as treatments for a variety of pain conditions including perioperative pain. Another non-pharmacologic approach to pain management with minimal risks and good potential benefit is cognitive behavioral therapy for pain (CBT-P). CBT-P has consistently demonstrated solid empirical support as an effective treatment for chronic pain, but it is less well- studied in perioperative settings. Accumulating data from our group suggest that tDCS of the prefrontal cortex may augment the analgesic effects of cognitive-behavioral (CB) interventions for acute pain. The proposed study will be the first ever to determine the effects of combining tDCS with a brief cognitive-behavioral intervention on post-operative pain, opioid use and functioning following TKA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While it is suggested that a functional role of sleep is to stabilize and improve visual learning, its underlying neural mechanism is poorly understood. Using advanced non-invasive neuroimaging techniques and careful behavioral measurements, we aim to better understand the mechanisms. Successful research results may give us insights into how learning can be improved through sleep and how vision declined or damaged due to aging, injury or diseases could be improved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Conventional DBS is an effective therapy for Parkinson's disease (PD), but its therapeutic effects decay rapidly once stimulation is turned off, underscoring the fact that it masks symptoms but does not reverse underlying circuit dysfunction. Based on foundational research into the cell-type organization of basal ganglia circuits, this proposal develops and tests the therapeutic efficacy of electrical stimulation protocols designed to selectively recruit therapeutic cell populations within the external globus pallidus (GPe) of the basal ganglia. The collaborative project will test the efficacy and therapeutic duration of novel stimulation protocols in mouse and primate models of PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fasciola hepatica causes a zoonotic infection reported from 81 countries around the world associated with anemia, stunted growth, and liver disease. Despite being targeted as a neglected tropical disease by WHO very little progress has been made in control, diagnosis, and surveillance. We propose using a comprehensive one-health approach to disentangle human transmission studying the spatial temporal associations between multiple hosts and environmental conditions considering factors affecting control such as lack of diagnostics and surveillance tools, drug efficacy, and infection susceptibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Since approximately 2010, the scale of clinical cancer predisposition genetic testing has increased dramatically; however, the ability to evaluate and classify DNA sequence variation reported from that testing has not kept up. The difference between the rate of testing and the rate of sequence variant classification has resulted in a rapidly increasing number of sequence Variants of Uncertain Significance (VUS), causing problems in patient counseling and management. Completion of the studies proposed here will improve rigor in the system used for evaluation of VUS in cancer susceptibility genes, enabling higher throughput VUS evaluation and improving confidence in the resulting classifications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The consequences of inadequately treated vitamin A deficiency (VAD) in premature neonates includes increased risk for bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD), which is associated with poor clinical outcomes in these fragile patients and requires costly long-term care. Advent Therapeutics is developing an aerosol formulation of its proprietary optimized, water miscible vitamin A palmitate (vitA) for non-invasive delivery of the drug to preterm infants, enabling dosing via inhalation and thus obviating the need for intramuscular (IM) injection; direct delivery to the lung (a direct-to-target-organ treatment for BPD) should increase effectiveness, while simultaneously providing systemic vitamin A availability, important for treating VAD and its related complications (not only BPD, but also retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) and sepsis). Dosing vitA by inhalation should overcome current hurdles limiting vitamin A supplementation use in the NICU, enabling much higher vitamin A utilization, with potential to decrease risk and cost of BPD in preterm infants.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Relevance Prostate cancer is the leading cause of cancer related death in veterans. Although significant progress has been made in treatment, “exceptional responses” are rare and there is currently no way to personalize care for men with this disease. This study will test the effectiveness of carboplatin, a drug with early evidence for exceptional responses and lower toxicity, against the standard of care chemotherapy drug in veterans with specific mutations in their cancer which would predict for effectiveness. If successful, this study could provide a means of predicting which veterans could benefit from more effective and less toxic therapy for metastatic, resistant prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: T cells help stimulate B cells to produce autoantibodies in many autoimmune diseases, yet the signals that regulate whether and how T cells can stimulate B cell responses remain unclear. In this project, we study the role that a specific transcription factor, the aryl hydrocarbon receptor, plays in regulating the generation of B cell-helper T cells. This work may help understand how the aryl hydrocarbon receptor can be modulated to dampen autoimmue T cell-B cell interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Disease in blood vessel leads to either reduction or stoppage of blood supply to the organ leading to organ malfunction or even death. The common examples are heart attack due to myocardial ischemia and paralysis due to stroke. Using experimental animal models we will investigate the mechanism involved in the development of atherosclerosis (fat deposition in blood vessels) and will identify ways to protect the vascular function and health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal addresses the significant burden of respiratory disease by investigating how a prevalent airway commensal, Prevotella melaninogenica, contributes to lung health. A protective phenotype identified for P. melaninogenica in humans is recapitulated using an animal model to investigate the specific bacterial factors, host cells, and innate immune receptors required to promote clearance of Streptococcus pneumoniae, the dominant cause of bacterial pneumonia, from the lung. The goal of these studies is to define the mechanistic basis for such clearance, which is the next step toward designing new probiotic-based immunotherapeutic strategies to enhance protection against bacterial pneumonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prostate cancer remains the second leading cause of deaths due to cancer in North American men. Defining the communication pathways that operate within prostate cancer cells, which is to say, how proteins talk to each other, reveals vulnerabilities that can be exploited therapeutically. We discovered a communication pathway in prostate cancer cells, and propose to determine how it works, and if pathway inhibition with a new drug (in clinical trials) can kill prostate cancer cells.

PHR: Diversity among scientists increases our ability to solve the problems facing society. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will identify novel factors that regulate Paneth cells, a key group of cells in the intestine that support the antimicrobial barrier of the gut. Importantly, abnormal Paneth cell function has been linked to several gastrointestinal disorders in which this antimicrobial barrier is impaired (i.e. Crohn’s disease, necrotizing enterocolitis, and graft-versus-host disease). Identifying factors that enhance the function of these cells has the potential to lead to novel therapies for a spectrum of gastrointestinal disease, directly supporting the stated mission of the NIDDK.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sickle Cell Trait (SCT) - which affects 1 out of 13 African Americans - is associated with high risk of sudden death and serious complications under stressful condition, which makes people with SCT vulnerable in cases of chlorine industrial accidents that happen frequently (every 2-3 days in the United States). Therefore, this study will test if humanized SCT mice are more vulnerable to death and serious organ injury following chlorine inhalation and if post-exposure haptoglobin injection negates the effect of chlorine exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poor adherence to medications for treating opioid use disorders threatens to limit the public health benefit of improving access to these life-saving medications. Co-morbidities such as chronic pain and depression often co- occur in patients with opioid use disorders and their families, which may play an important role in medication adherence and patient outcomes in real-world clinical practice. The purpose of this project is to train the recipient to generate new knowledge about the role of the household in adherence to buprenorphine for the treatment of opioid use disorders and associated serious adverse events, with the goal of helping to achieve optimal public health outcomes with medications for opioid use disorders and reduce costs.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative  Excessive accumulation of lipid droplets (LDs) leads to obesity and many metabolic diseases and dynamics of lipid droplets (LDs) on endoplasmic reticulum are tightly regulated by enzymatic proteins. This study will investigate the novel function of an ER targeting protein named Dynamin-Related Protein 1 (DRP1) on LD budding. Insights into the key role of DRP1 shed new light on potential strategies to treat diseases associated with abnormal lipid accumulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this project is to resolve the molecular mechanisms of how a shared mutation in the “driver” oncogene PIK3CA, among the most commonly mutated human cancer genes, can elicit a specific immune response. Studying the structural, biophysical, and cellular response to this shared neoantigen will enable an entirely new class of precision immunotherapies targeting a genetic alteration that causes cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The proposed Center provides resources, training, data and statistical expertise for the study of alcohol-related health, mental health and social problem disparities in the US arising from differences between racial/ethnic and socioeconomic group and sexual identity and rurality. Research projects will provide insights in to the drinking of those with alcohol-related health conditions, racial/ethnic and socioeconomic disparities in alcohol-related problems, the role of inflammation in associations between alcohol use and mental health issues, disparities in access and utilization of screening for alcohol problems, use of pharmacotherapy and treatment completion, co- use of alcohol and other drugs, and events involving high-intensity drinking and drinkers who participate in them. Knowledge gained will further understanding of alcohol-related disparities and will strengthen the design, implementation and targeting of interventions to address these.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a disparity illness afflicting 100,000 Americans, most of whom are Black, and is more costly per-capita than any other chronic disease. The proposed work aims to improve SCD care by 1) developing reliable, valid retinal metrics to measure disease severity and predict long-term complications and 2) improving our understanding of how cellular mechanisms correspond to clinical phenotypes. As novel therapies for SCD continue to emerge, these data are urgently needed to personalize choice, initiation and dosing of therapies to ensure the best outcomes for individuals with SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Although electronic health records (EHR) data represent a huge opportunity for cost-effective clinical and public health research, care is needed since it typically not collected for that purpose. Among the many challenges that researchers face in using EHR data, missing data poses a substantial, complex and yet unappreciated threat to validity. Motivated by our teams experience in conducting research of long-term outcomes following bariatric surgery, this proposal aims to develop a suite of novel, innovative statistical tools for dealing with missing data in EHR-based studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The implementation of the 2024 National Alcohol Survey will deepen our knowledge of how to collect high quality survey data and biological samples, responding to contemporary survey research challenges. Expanding the NAS series to 45 years will provide us with new data to develop and examine up-to-date trends in alcohol use and problems, and potential disparities in the risk for alcohol-related problems across gender, socioeconomic and racial/ethnic groups. We will also learn whether inflammation partially explains alcohol's effect on psychological distress, and address disparities in these effects among racial/ethnic groups, level of education, and neighborhood status.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a disease caused by mutations in the contractile proteins. Early in HCM the blood vessels also fail to function correctly, but this aspect is poorly understood. We aim to study the mechanisms that underlie the loss of vessel function and its role in HCM disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Huntsman Cancer Institute (HCI) Cancer Genetics, Epigenetics, Models, and Signaling (Cancer GEMS) Training Program will support six PhD candidates each year. Students will participate in a two-year training program consisting of a combination of mentored research, didactic courses, career development activities, seminars, and conferences, all aimed at preparing these young scientists for the next stage of their careers in cancer research. This program will produce a cadre of new scientists capable of working with physicians to develop improved and individualized methods of cancer prevention, early detection/interception, and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accidental exposure to the halogen gas, chlorine (Cl2), causes fatal lung injury characterized by profound airway inflammation, pulmonary edema and acute respiratory failure. Survivors often display persistent reactive airway disease and progressive pulmonary fibrosis. This study will determine if mitochondria DNA damage underlies Cl2 toxicity and whether repairing mitochondrial DNA can reduce morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE A large segment of the US population lives with chronic conditions adversely affected by drinking. Given our integrative approach, study findings will uniquely contribute to the knowledge base for multi-faceted interventions that can simultaneously address harmful drinking and other risk behaviors to help improve disease management, treatment adherence and overall health of individuals with alcohol-related health problems. Our results concerning disparities in knowledge and behaviors across demographic subgroups will help identify those at high risk for continued drinking with health conditions and inform contextually-relevant interventions targeted at them.  .

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health and the mission of NIH because the development of bioethics scholars in underdeveloped countries is critical to the health and well-being of its citizens. The COVID-19 pandemic has heightened the need for bioethics experts to address the many ethical issues before them: staffing requirements to care for the public, triage and allocation of scarce resources, public health infection control measures, and end-of-life issues, among others. We will train a total of 6 doctoral candidates to address the critical shortage of highly trained bioethics scholars to address the demand in Tanzania and the region at large.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastrointestinal functional and motility disorders affect ~15% of the US population, resulting in chronic morbidity, disruptions in quality of life, loss of productivity and high healthcare costs. Gastrointestinal motility is a complex process that is ultimately executed by the smooth muscle cells. This proposal targets the molecular mechanisms involved in the function and dysfunction in smooth muscle cells, and has the potential to significantly advance basic understanding and potential to provide novel diagnostic approaches and drug targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accurate longitudinal monitoring of glaucoma, the leading cause of irreversible blindness in the United States, is critical to identifying disease progression and initiating treatment to prevent permanent visual disability. Current methods used to identify glaucoma progression at the patient level are error-prone due to high variability and infrequency of testing, which can lead to a significant delay in detecting progressive disease. By constructing statistical models enhanced by electronic health record data, this proposal seeks to improve the physician’s ability to rapidly recognize disease progression, thereby enabling early intervention to prevent irreversible vision loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Public Health Relevancy Statement: The proposed research is intended to provide physicians with an entirely new molecular imaging tool that will essentially “paint” the tumor area that needs to be sensitively and specifically identified during and after surgical resection. We recently discovered that the FDA-approved dyes used for coloring of foods, drugs and cosmetics have a multitude of useful imaging properties that are ideal for incorporating into nanoparticles and could be used for highlighting tumors. This approach has great potential to be clinically translated and could significantly improve cancer detection, tumor resection, and identifying the most effective treatment options for the patient; thus, impacting overall therapeutic outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Unhealthy drinking and alcohol use disorder (AUD) together affect more than one of every four American adults and are a leading cause of preventable death, with tremendous economic and social costs. This study seeks to increase understanding of gaps in the quality of alcohol-related care received among unhealthy drinkers and persons with AUD, and how this is changing with health reform. Based on analyses of national survey and specialty treatment data, study results may help to stimulate efforts of clinicians, healthcare administrators, treatment providers, and policymakers to improve access to quality alcohol-related care for all.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Levodopa is the primary treatment for Parkinson’s Disease, a neurodegenerative disease that afflicts 1 million Americans. Unfortunately, levodopa has serious side effects and loses its efficacy over time. Using Sinopia Biosciences’s computational drug discovery platform, we identified a small molecule that we subsequently tested and validated in relevant rodent and primate models, providing a unique mechanism for treating Parkinson’s Disease. This proposal will complete preclinical drug development for this compound in order to advance to the clinic.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a common consequence of combat that can result in trauma-related hyperarousal and sleep disturbances. Poor sleep, one of the most common complaints in Veterans with PTSD, can be distressing, impair concentration and memory, and contribute to physical health conditions, such as metabolic syndrome, inflammation, and cardiovascular disease. The orexin neuropeptide system underlies both sleep and stress reactivity. Suvorexant, a drug that reduces orexin, improves sleep in civilians, but has not yet been tested in Veterans with PTSD. This study will test whether suvorexant can improve sleep disturbances and PTSD symptoms in Veterans. Suvorexant may benefit Veterans by improving sleep quickly while also reducing PTSD symptoms over the long term, and with fewer side effects that were common in previous medications used to treat these conditions. Improving Veterans' sleep and PTSD symptoms could lead to better emotional and physical well-being, quality of life, relationships, and functioning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE This work will broaden our knowledge of both the precursors to and the outcomes of high-intensity drinking (HID) at various points over the life course, also estimating the public health burden attributable to high alcohol intake. This research project is poised to improve HID measurement, track HID trends over time, and enhance theory by contextualizing intensity within an individual's overall drinking pattern, drinking history, event-level characteristics, and individual and environmental influences. Finally, this research promises to aid in improving prevention and treatment strategies by better identifying suitable target subgroups (in particular women and disadvantaged populations disproportionately impacted by alcohol problems), and provide information to help shape design of future interventions aimed at reducing harmful drinking intensities among a range of adults, from young adults to middle-aged and older Americans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) is a common cause for admission and mortality within the Veterans Affairs (VA) Health Care System. Currently its treatment is based on therapeutic targeting of a limited number of receptors and pathways. Our team has shown that the Vanilloid 2 subtype of the Transient Potential Receptor superfamily (TRPV2) modulates cardiac function and we have used probenecid, a generic, globally available drug with an extremely safe profile as a TRPV2 agonist. Our work has demonstrated probenecid to be a potent inotrope without significant adverse effects in animal models and in patients with HFrEF. The objective of this study is the treatment of outpatient veterans with HFrEF with probenecid to improve systolic and health function. If successful, this study will provide a novel therapeutic option for patients with HFrEF and will provide event rates for a larger study with hard endpoints.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: This work is directly applicable to the health, well-being, and functional independence of disabled Veterans suffering from a devastating and currently incurable neurological condition called Parkinson’s disease – a neurodegenerative disorder, affecting about 10 million individuals worldwide, including approximately 80,000 US Veterans. Our goal is to define the most effective therapeutic approach utilizing deep brain stimulation and address balance and falls in Parkinson’s disease. Our top-down approach will unravel the anatomical pathways and physiological processes through which we will better understand multi-sensory governance of motion perception critical for spatial navigation, and maintenance of balance and prevention of falls in Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescence is a period of considerable development, making the adolescent brain particularly vulnerable to negative effects of cannabis and alcohol use. The proposed research will test an innovative intervention among adolescents seeking-treatment for substance use that aims to modify automatic approach biases for cannabis and alcohol, which are hypothesized precipitating and maintaining factors for adolescent substance use. The modification of implicit cognitive biases via training may be a useful adjunct to existing interventions and could reduce the consequences associated with adolescent substance use.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Shoulder pain in people living with spinal cord injury is a serious threat to public health, with implications for functional independence, quality of life, caregiver burden, and healthcare utilization. To better understand shoulder pain, researchers have used musculoskeletal models to understand how muscle tendons may be injured during daily activities. Our investigation will use secondary analysis of existing data to understand the relative impact of anatomy versus movement patterns of the shoulder on the muscle tendon during wheelchair propulsion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: Chronic pain affects nearly one-third of the United States population, costing approximately $600 billion, more than the annual costs of heart disease, cancer, and diabetes combined. The current proposal aims to improve chronic pain treatment by examining the contribution of central pain inhibition to chronic pain and patient-to-patient heterogeneity of treatment response. Novel brain and behavioral measures developed in this proposal may predict treatment response to established analgesics, personalizing chronic pain management and allowing the study of novel analgesics in phenotypically-defined patient populations.

PHR: Project Narrative Enhancing health and healthcare for gender and sexual minority (GSM) youth in the U.S. is a national public health priority. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the longstanding dogma that premenopausal women are commonly viewed as protected from hypertension and cardiovascular disease (CVD), compelling evidence establishes that obesity abrogates the protective effects of female sex and predisposes women to obesity-associated hypertension (OAH) though, through sex specific mechanisms. The source of this sex difference in mechanisms is unknown. The proposed study aims to uncover the underlying origin of the mechanisms for sex differences in OAH by investigating role for sex chromosome complement and will test whether human female adrenals are more sensitive to leptin- mediated aldosterone production than that of males.

PHR: Project Narrative Xenotransplantation of composite islet-kidneys (I-K) containing autologous islets, has the capacity to cure both renal failure and diabetes for patients suffering from end-stage diabetic nephropathy, which is currently an unmet medical need. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding patterns of human genetic variation is critically important for the design, analysis, and interpretation of disease mapping studies. This project will develop methods to identify and study DNA sequences in humans that have been inherited from archaic ancestors, such as Neanderthals and Denisovans. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: NARRATIVE Cancers have readily-defined characteristics often referred to as “hallmarks”; however, the question of how the sequence of cancer development progresses -- from normal tissue to carcinogen-damaged tissue to precancerous lesion and finally to malignant tumors – remains unanswered. Classically, these steps are attributed to the sequential acquisition of discrete genetic events such as driver mutations, but the clonal dynamics governing cancer development happen over years, remain largely invisible even in model systems, and have been difficult to link to specific molecular changes. Our long-term goal is to apply ecological and evolutionary principles to cancer initiation and development in order to test whether the hallmarks of cancer are acquired in three distinct phases each with distinct selective pressures and manifestations of cell competition and cooperation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Micro-ribonucleic acids (miRNAs) are crucial for normal lung development, lung health, and have been identified as potential therapeutic targets for Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). miRNAs interact with other biological molecules, such as transcription factors proteins and messenger RNAs (mRNAs); these interactions may be impacted by changes in the underlying DNA sequence, such as the disease-associated genetic variants identified through genome wide association studies (GWAS). In this project, we will model the regulatory roles of miRNAs in COPD using blood and lung tissue sequencing data, investigate how regulation may be altered in response to known COPD GWAS variants, and compare the results with publicly available drug response data to hypothesize potential new treatments for COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mammalian SWI/SNF ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling complexes are multi-subunit macromolecular machines that play critical roles in the regulation of chromatin architecture. However, the mechanisms by which mSWI/SNF complexes target to specific sites and engage specific features of the chromatin landscape genome- wide, and how these binding interactions impact catalytic activity remain unknown. Owing to their frequent perturbation in human disease, with genes mutated in >20% of human cancers and several intellectual disability syndromes, defining the mechanisms governing mSWI/SNF targeting and activity will enable an understanding of disease-specific biology and may provide a powerful foundation for the identification of new therapeutic strategies.

PHR: Ocular toxoplasmosis is a relapsing disease and a major cause of visual loss. Current treatment does not affect visual outcome. We plan studies that will identify how molecular events determine whether selective autophagic targeting of Toxoplasma gondii takes place and may identify therapeutic targets against ocular toxoplasmosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative High density of intratumoral high endothelial venules (HEVs) has been associated with Th1 immunostimulatory tumor environment, favorable response to chemotherapy, and cancer survival. It is thought that these specialized blood vessels serve as gateways for lymphocyte recruitment. We will determine the precise role of tumor HEVs in shaping immune landscape and the importance for immune checkpoint inhibition therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative It has been shown that neural stimulation with infrared radiation is more spatially selective than electrical stimulation and could result in more independent channels to encode acoustic information in cochlear implants. Psychophysics experiments have shown that more independent channels available for encoding acoustic information will result in better music appreciation and performance of cochlear implant users in noisy listening environments, or during the use of tonal languages. While the parameters for infrared neural stimulation have been established in animal models, the proposed experiments are to translate the results into the clinic by validating the results in humans in acute tests during a translabyrinthine tumor resection surgery and to fabricate and test an first prototype of an optical cochlear implant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this proposal is to develop immune cell engineering approaches for the monitoring and treatment of T cell-mediated autoimmune diseases such as Type-I diabetes (T1D). We will compare three functionally distinct T cell populations engineered to express 5MCARs for their ability to prevent autoimmune diabetes and ask if the 5MCAR platform can enable sensitive detection of autoimmune T cells early in the progression of diabetes. Finally, we will test additional biomimetic modifications of the 5-module design as we work towards the development of 2nd generation 5MCARs with improved function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Clinical sequencing has become a frontline strategy for diagnosing rare disease, particularly in pediatrics where 10% of pediatric admissions and up to 20% of infant deaths derive from Mendelian disease. However, the capability for generating sequence data far outstrips the capability to accurately interpret these data, and over half of patients with suspected genetic disorders do not currently receive a genetic diagnosis. Our Center will share data broadly and contribute substantially to the establishment of a comprehensive catalog of the genetic causes of Mendelian diseases, thus improving diagnosis rates as well as building the biological understanding needed to develop more effective therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) are currently considered as one of the leading causes of dementing illness. However, the underlying molecular and cellular mechanisms of VCID are not well understood, and no effective treatment strategy has been developed to date. This study will utilize a mouse model of VCID to investigate chronic cerebral hypoperfusion-induced white matter and hippocampal damage, and subsequent cognitive impairment . Understanding the VCID-related brain pathophysiology is crucial for the development of future therapeutic strategies .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There exists a critical need in resource-limited settings to identify new strategies to reduce newborn deaths, many of which result from antenatal malaria infections with Plasmodium falciparum. We hypothesize that a strategy of screening pregnant women in malaria-endemic areas in the first trimester with a high-sensitivity rapid diagnostic test for parasites followed by treatment if positive with Artemether-Lumefantrine will reduce the risk of a negative pregnancy outcome. We will test this hypothesis in a clinical trial in Western Kenya and the Democratic Republic of the Congo, as well as study the pharmacokinetics of these antimalarials in the 1st trimester and estimate the incremental benefits of alternate approaches, in order to collectively identify a new strategy to improve pregnancy outcomes and newborn health in malaria-endemic areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Analysis of the complex cellular system in transplanted hearts is critical for understanding the mechanisms of chronic graft failure in heart transplant patients. This project aims to develop and apply novel single cell multi- omics methods to dissect donor and host cell chimerism and delineate the origins of pathogenic cell types. The project will deliver a powerful technology and several computational tools for studying cell lineages and cell fates and the research outcome will greatly benefit research of cellular systems of human organs and diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE (Public Health Relevance) Tobacco is the leading cause of preventable death in the United States. Although half of these deaths is due to cardiovascular (CV) disease, the molecular mechanism of how tobacco leads to increased CV mortality is not well understood. Studies proposed in this application will investigate how specific information in the human genome interacts with molecular actions of tobacco smoke to determine individual risk for developing CV disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dual use of electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS) and combustible cigarettes is the most common pattern of tobacco use among young adults. However, little is known about the basic behavioral processes that underlie dual use and the degree to which these processes are shared between products. The current project aims to examine behavioral underpinnings of ENDS use and tobacco dual use and craving among young adults in laboratory and naturalistic settings - focusing on cue reactivity, attentional bias, and negative affect - so that such knowledge can inform future research and intervention efforts to reduce the public health burden associated with tobacco use in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The overall goal of this proposal is to determine the role of selenium (Se) and Scly-mediated Se recycling in selenoprotein synthesis and degradation in brown adipocyte adaptive thermogenesis. Because: a) the role of the antioxidant micronutrient selenium in brown adipocytes is unclear; b) the mechanism of Se recycling and selenoprotein degradation is largely understudied; and c) nutritional guidelines only consider dietary Se, neglecting its cellular recycling process as a source when Se availability is limiting; this study has the potential to impact future nutritional guidelines, clarifying the importance of Se in energy expenditure, ultimately improving our understanding of obesity development, a condition affecting millions of people worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physical activity can positively affect aging adults, including prevention of or reduced severity of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias and improved functional, well-being, and social outcomes. Given the increased risk for early-onset Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, feasible and effective strategies and programs to increase physical activity levels are urgently needed for adults with intellectual disability. This project seeks to refine and test the feasibility of a multi-level physical activity program for adults with intellectual disability that utilizes self-management strategies to increase physical activity across home and community settings with a long-term goal of examining long-term effects of prevention of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: In this proposal, we will develop computational and experimental methods to maximize the power of high-throughput, microscopy-based phenotypic screens. Our studies will increase the power of phenotypic profiling by harnessing screens performed across the world, providing a rational approach for maximizing the chance of discovering hits for diverse pathways in future screens, and identifying novel compounds that expand our ability to perturb cancer-relevant pathways. Our proposal is designed to accelerate the pace of early drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Adipose/fat tissue plays essential roles in maintaining whole-body metabolic homeostasis and its dysregulation causes obesity and many associated metabolic disorders. In this proposal, we will define the identity of a novel population of adipocytes that exist in various fat depots and exhibit potentially high metabolic and thermogenic properties. We will also assess overall impacts of these adipocytes on adipose tissue function, whole-body metabolic homeostasis, and protection of obesity. Results obtained will not only provide new insight into the biology of adipocytes, but also implicate these adipocytes as an important cell source and a therapeutic target in the treatment of obesity.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: There is large body of evidence demonstrating that Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is associated with alterations in the stress hormone cortisol. There is also evidence that medications that block cortisol may be beneficial for treating PTSD and depression. The VA recently completed a study of a mifepristone, a medication that blocks cortisol and progesterone hormones, and found some benefit for veterans who did not have a history of traumatic brain injury. The proposal will test a medication from a new class of cortisol blockers which have no effect on progesterone. The proposed study will test the drug CORT108297 for treatment of PTSD and will establish a safety profile that will inform the design of future studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The Cardiothoracic Surgical Trials Network has conducted several clinically important randomized trials in heart valve disease, coronary artery disease, and heart failure, and has observed clinical practice related to infections following heart surgery. It is now embarking on a new paradigm whereby a well-established primary program will affiliate with a center located in an area of exceptionally high cardiovascular disease burden, with large numbers of people with diabetes, high blood pressure, obesity, and strokes. Further, it intends to expand into the area of implementation research, where it will identify strategies to bring proven therapies to clinical practice, thereby improving the treatment of patients with cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Through research resources and services, education, and clinical and translational science research, Tufts Clinical and Translational Science Institute supports the entire spectrum of translation to help meet the promise and the public’s needs of biomedical science. This includes the translation of preclinical investigation (“T.5”), into bench research into bedside care (“T1”), into effective clinical practice (“T2”), into wide care delivery and public health (“T3”), and into health policy (“T4”). By doing this, we support clinical and translational science and research that will have impact on health and health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS) is common and associated with cardiovascular diseases through heterogeneous mechanisms, and our recent studies suggest two subtypes of EDS-sleep propensity and sleep fragmentation. We will use sleep metrics and multi-omics data to understand the physiology and genetic basis of each subtype of EDS, and study their associations with CVD. This study will improve our understanding of the heterogeneity of EDS and inform future interventions for both EDS and CVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This application seeks to develop chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T regulatory cell-based strategies for therapeutic targeting and immunomodulation of pancreatic islets and antigen presenting cells, particularly in expanding our understanding of how Treg from T1D individuals might be different from normal and what strategies might be used to make Treg more effective. Successful completion of studies here could lead to strategies to deliver targeted immunosuppressive agents to prevent type 1 (T1D) in high risk patients, to suppress autoimmunity and preserve β-cell mass in patients with recent-onset T1D, and to deliver therapeutics to the pancreas for β-cell protection, functional enhancement or regeneration in established T1D. The islet- targeting and APC-targeting approaches developed through this proposal could rapidly become a scientific foundation for clinical trials in T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE More than six million children in the U.S. have asthma, a chronic disease that disproportionately affects lower-income, urban and racial/ethnic minority populations. Accountable care organizations are designed to support interventions that address the social and medical complexity of childhood asthma in ways traditional healthcare models are not, but the effects of the accountable care ‘experiment’ on childhood asthma clinical care, outcomes, and disparities remain largely unknown.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Chemokine receptors CXCR4 and ACKR3 play critical roles in cell migration during immune responses, organ development and homing of hematopoietic stem cells, through coordinated responses to a shared ligand, the chemoattractant CXCL12. Although they are promising drug targets, the structural mechanisms underlying their individual functions and their cellular crosstalk is poorly understood. The proposed studies will reveal general principles of CXCR4 and ACKR3 activation, inhibition, and functional interplay, which will inform strategies for the development of single or combination CXCR4/ACKR3 therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator : Guirgis, Faheem Wagid Lipids and lipoproteins (cholesterol and lipid metabolites) are present in sepsis and are highly biologically active regulators of inflammation, but currently the changes in lipid and lipoprotein homeostasis during sepsis are not well understood. This project will investigate the changes in lipid and lipoprotein function, oxidation, metabolites, and changes in gene expression to further our understanding of dysregulated lipid and lipoprotein metabolism in sepsis. We will analyze a bank of samples and make associations with important clinical outcomes (early death, chronic critical illness and sepsis recidivism) as supported by our published work, and will confirm our findings in a small prospective cohort of sepsis patients. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE O6-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) plays a prominent role in DNA adduct repair that limits the mutagenic and cytotoxic effect of alkylating agents. The goal of this research project is to apply biodegradable small-sized polymer for targeted delivery of DNA MGMT inhibitor with combination of TMZ and radiation therapy for real time monitoring of response to the treatment. Success in our study in preclinical animal tumor models should provide us with novel DNA inhibitors and methods to further develop clinical applications of such therapy options for the improved treatment of brain tumors.

PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this Mid-Career Investigator Award in Patient Oriented Research is to provide support for mentoring and research in the study of cardiovascular disease and chronic kidney disease. IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Although antiretroviral drugs have revolutionized the management of HIV, they still need to be taken for life, new infections and deaths continue to occur the fast-track strategy to control the epidemic by 2030 may not be met. New tools are required to get the world on track to bring HIV infection under control in sub-Saharan Africa and globally and the most impactful advance would be development of an HIV cure using HIV gene therapy which is the frontrunner today but also in line with NIH priorities of research to develop next generation of HIV therapies and discovery of a cure for HIV/AIDS. A cure strategy that prevents reinfection would revolutionize HIV management, and constitute a onetime intervention with high impact on quality and quantity of life with phenomenal clinical, economic and social value.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Making healthy decisions and engaging in healthy behaviors are important for public health broadly. The current project aims to examine social and emotional influences on health decision making and behavior in older and younger adults with a focus on physical activity and its consequences for mental, physical, and cognitive health. Results of this project will have useful policy and intervention implications for the public health sector.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Through examination of the molecular mechanisms of chronic pain at anterior cingulate cortex, a major area involved in processing pain sensation in the brain, the research team aims to elucidate how our brain perceives pain and how this can be altered through changes in the function of an ion channel named acid-sensing ion channel 1a, or ASIC1a. The proposed research combines the complementary strengths of two laboratories using innovative and the state-of-the-art techniques. Chronic pain is a debilitating medical problem, affecting millions of people, to which current clinical therapy has only limited efficacy; the proposed project is expected to shed lights on new ways to treat chronic pain.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE One of the earliest events in development is the replacement of maternal biomolecules like RNA with new ones made by the embryo. A major question is how the embryo distinguishes old, maternal RNAs from the new, embryonic RNAs. Here, we will explore a new conceptual framework whereby the experiences of maternal RNAs during oogenesis prime the biomolecules for removal during early embryogenesis, thus ensuring proper development of the embryo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inherited degenerative diseases of the retina, which affect over two million individuals worldwide, represent a genetically and phenotypically heterogeneous group of visual disorders characterized by progressive photoreceptor cell loss. Many forms of inherited retinal degeneration are associated with defects in the formation of the light-sensitive outer signet compartment of rod and cone photoreceptor cells. Studies described in this application aim to elucidate the most fundamental molecular mechanisms responsible for the outer segment morphogenesis, thereby providing scientific basis for developing effective strategies for disease treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intestinal dysmotility disorders and obstructions are under-researched and associated with enormous management costs and life-long adverse outcomes. To expand our understanding of these disorders, we investigate how mechanosensors in the gut control bowel motility, allowing each bowel segment to sense and respond to stretch. We believe that this project may have essential findings in studying this group of patients and may also have therapeutic implications.
