IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Each year 7 million patients seek care in U.S. Emergency Departments for chest pain. Most moderate-risk patients undergo hospitalization for expensive testing aimed at identifying a heart attack, which costs the healthcare system more than $3 billion annually without a clear improvement in patient outcomes. Our study will compare rapid outpatient vs hospitalization management to determine the best strategy (based on patient- centered measures and safe, equitable, and efficient resource use) for evaluating these patients.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Testing a Cardiovascular Ambulatory Rapid Evaluation for Patients with Chest Pain (CARE-CP)

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The number of older Veterans with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) seeking care within the Veterans Affairs (VA) health care system is increasing and is expected to increase more rapidly as Vietnam era Veterans age. The cognitive effects of MCI and subsequent neurodegenerative disorders can adversely affect a Veteran’s ability to function independently and failure to provide appropriate intervention can result in an increased need for healthcare services and VA benefits in the future. The VA currently spends over $19,000 annually per patient to care for Veterans with dementia (Zhu et al., 2009), and delaying the onset of dementia even by one to two years will result in substantial financial savings to the VA and quality of life gains for the Veteran. Since present pharmacological interventions have demonstrated limited efficacy, alternative treatments are needed. Therefore, an evidence-based cognitive training intervention that optimally addresses the needs of older Veterans with MCI is of critical importance to the VA patient care mission.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative This research will advance fundamental knowledge in the diagnosis of concussion and generate practical insights for equitably operationalizing baseline testing to improve health outcomes for those at risk of concussion. Through multi-disciplinary collaboration and wide dissemination of our findings, this research can transform how clinicians and athletic trainers approach concussion diagnosis for those who may be under- represented in the development of existing clinical guidelines, leading to more timely and accurate diagnosis of concussion.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: This project, "Ukraine HIV Research Training Program” will build capacity to address the gaps in HIV treatment and prevention that have emerged following the initiation of the conflict with Russia. This will be carried out in partnership with the School of Public Health at National University of Kyiv-Mohyla Academy, linked with a research NGO, Ukrainian Institute for Public Health Policy. The public health relevance is that these research capacity building efforts will be designed to minimize HIV-related morbidity and mortality in the midst of a humanitarian crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer is a major public health problem in the United States (US), with more lives lost due to lung cancer than to breast, prostate, and colorectal cancers combined. Despite the US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation for annual lung screening among high risk current and former smokers, it is underutilized (3- 14% uptake) across all racial/ethnic groups. As this disease disproportionately affects African Americans due to late-stage diagnosis and poorer lung cancer survival than whites, there is an urgent public health need to address systemic barriers contributing to disparities in lung cancer between African Americans and whites. Interventions that address multiple barriers are needed to reduce disparities in the uptake of cancer screening. I will use my K99 training to inform the development of a provider- and patient-level intervention that will be tested in the R00 phase to improve lung screening awareness, screening completion overall, and to achieve equity in screening rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The overall goal of this project is to develop first in class radiotracers to study in vivo how immune cells mobilize granzymes to combat deadly pathogens. This project will span new probe development and application to clinically relevant animal models of viral or bacterial infections and conclude with late stage preclinical studies to establish the long term feasibility of human imaging for this novel probe class. If successful, this project will confer new translational tools to begin probing the emerging non-cytotoxic functions in host defense for this enigmatic enzyme class.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Long-range chromatin interactions are fundamental to gene regulation. This project seeks to address some of the most critical statistical and computational deficits in studying long-range chromatin interactions. It develops novel statistical methods that can reduce noise and amplify true biological signal in noisy high throughput chromatin conformation data of single cells and innovates integrative models that can leverage model-organism multi-omics data to elucidate long-range interaction-mediated impacts of noncoding association variants on genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By screening cellular mutations induced by VSV infection which allow for escape from viral replication, we identified a cellular protein, CSDE1, as a major co-factor of VSV replication. Here, we will define how CSDE1 mediates replication of VSV, how compensatory mutations in the virus are induced to recover viral fitness in virus-resistant cells, and how we can exploit our discovery of CSDE1 as a critical co-factor for VSV replication to generate CSDE1-expressing VSV with enhanced efficacy as both vaccination and oncolytic platforms. Our studies will have significant impact in understanding VSV/host cell interactions, in defining pathways by which viruses can usurp anti-viral mutagenic pathways to seed escape-competent quasi species and will inform development of novel, improved VSV for vaccination and oncolysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Relevance Recent studies indicate that individuals with sickle cell disease (SCD) are susceptible to the development of somatic clonal hematopoiesis (CH) mutations, which may predispose to multi- organ failure in early adulthood. We will analyze a multi-center SCD cohort to determine the prevalence of CH mutations and their association with the development of heart, lung or kidney disease, which increase the probability of premature death. By defining the genetic profiles that impact the severity of SCD, we aim to design individualized therapies to safely and prospectively inhibit the development of life-threatening organ damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dystonia, the third most common motor disease, is debilitating at all ages, but its onset in children is a growing crisis because the causative mechanisms create unique long-term health concerns. Although recent efforts have discovered brain areas involved in dystonia, the current study addresses a major gap in knowledge by identifying a genetic cue that instructs the formation of a core dystonia circuit. This proposal tests how dystonia-causing circuits develop in order to pinpoint new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Epilepsy is a serious neurological disorder that can develop as a consequence of viral infection and traumatic injury to the brain. NG2-glia are a major glial cell-type that regulate inflammation, scar formation, and neuroplasticity changes following injury, yet their role in the development of epilepsy remains unknown. It is envisioned that these studies will lead to new hypotheses and treatment strategies regarding the development of epilepsy following viral infections and brain injury in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hypertriglyceridemia is a major metabolic disorder that frequently precedes or co-exists with metabolic and cardiovascular diseases. This project will identify a stress-induced secreted protein factor, named CREBH-C, which can boost triglyceride metabolism and thus mitigate hypertriglyceridemia and the associated metabolic disorders. Delineating the molecular mechanism and functional significance of this novel protein factor will have a major impact in the prevention and treatment of human metabolic and cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ATP-sensitive potassium (KATP) channels regulate membrane excitability according to the energetic state of a cell, and dysfunction of these channels underlie a number of devastating human diseases. The goal of this project is to understand the structural mechanisms governing the activity of various KATP channel subtypes found in different tissues in order to design better drugs to treat diseases caused by channel dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The main aim of this project is to uncover molecular and physiological mechanisms of ultradian (shorter than a day) rhythms in the brain. To do so, we will focus on the glia that displays simultaneously ultradian and circadian (24 hr) rhythms. Understanding how ultradian rhythms are generated and their physiological outputs has obvious implications for human health, especially given the role of biological rhythms in sleep disturbances, mental illness and many other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The workforce in hematology, the science of blood, has been in decline for two decades due to a variety of reasons. NHLBI has called in published articles for new research training plans for hematologists to align with the changing landscape of clinical and research hematology, including expansion of clinical-translational training. In this proposal, we leverage the extensive portfolio of clinical-translational degree programs and informal training opportunities at the University of Pittsburgh to meet the needs announced by NHLBI.

PROJECT_TITLE: Multidisciplinary Research Training in Hematology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neurodegenerative diseases are imposing an increasing health and financial burden given the rapid increase of the aging segment of the population. For many neurodegenerative diseases there are no disease modifying therapeutics, including Alzheimer’s disease (AD), frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and sporadic amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The successful demonstration that NEAT1 is altered in diseases characterized by STAU1 overabundance will lead to new potential therapeutic targets for AD, FTD, ALS and other disorders with abnormal nuclear paraspeckle function, deeper understanding on the significance of NEAT1 and STAU1 to neurodegenerative disease, and will further support STAU1 as a therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We developed a novel metric of a person’s pace of biological aging, DunedinPoAm4x, by first tracking declines in multiple biomarkers in the cardiovascular, metabolic, pulmonary, renal, hepatic, immune, and dental systems of 1000 participants at ages 26, 32, 38 and 45 years, and then using machine-learning to convert our new metric to a new measure that can be exported to any human research sample that has blood methylation data. In this project, we will test if faster DunedinPoAm4x predicts cognitive decline, frailty, disease, and mortality, plus dementia diagnosis and MRI measures of structural brain aging; if DunedinPoAm4x is accelerated in people who grew up in adversity; if DunedinPoAm4x slows in response to beneficial lifestyle changes; and if genes relate to DunedinPoAm4x. We will deliver a reliable, valid, open-access method to measure how rapidly a person has been aging, which will be useful for basic aging research and also for testing whether a therapeutic treatment has slowed a person’s pace of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The nuclear envelope is a double lipid bilayer that separates the cytoplasm from the nucleoplasm. Proteins in the nuclear envelope are essential for maintaining nuclear structure, gene expression and chromatin organization. We study the functions of a muscle-specific nuclear envelope protein NET39 in skeletal muscle maintenance and pathogenesis of Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy (EDMD). We hope to use these insights to develop new therapeutic strategies for EDMD and related skeletal muscle diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how the lymphatic system contributes to inflammatory and cardiovascular diseases remains significantly unexplored; however, recent evidence underscores important emerging roles of the lymphatic system in obesity and metabolic syndrome. This application will 1) identify the specific contribution of dysfunction of the lymphatic vasculature to metabolic dysfunction in diet-induced obesity; and 2) will test and propose novel therapeutic strategies targeting overactive Transient Receptor Potential Vanilloid 4 (Trpv4) ion channels and the Plasminogen Activator Inhibitor-1 (PAI-1), an important biomarker for disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Emperipolesis is an understudied cell-in-cell interaction whereby bone marrow neutrophils transit through the cytoplasm of megakaryocytes. The PI found that emperipolesis is dramatically increased during inflammation, resulting in exchange of proteins and membrane between lineages and thereby to egressing neutrophils. This project aims to investigate how neutrophil function is modulated by emperipolesis, and to define the physiological consequences of emperipolesis in health and with inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Proteins play leading roles in the drama of life and as “actors” they mediate many critical activities such as sensing light, transporting critical nutrients, or moving muscles. Many diseases are caused by the failure of proteins to “act” appropriately and biomedical intends to understand the structures of proteins to devise strategies to correct their role in disease. This technology development project will provide novel tools to understand structures faster and more cheaply, driving accelerated research towards cures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative About a decade ago we and others have exploited the simplicity for re-programming of target recognition of the RNA-guided DNA nucleases encoded by type II CRISPR-Cas immune systems (Cas9). This biotechnological application have revolutionized the study of human genetic disease and it is a testament to the importance of characterizing the molecular mechanisms of this prokaryotic immune response. In this proposal we will investigate the mechanisms of spacer acquisition of type III CRISPR-Cas systems. We believe that the knowledge generated could expand the spectrum of CRISPR-based biotechnological applications to benefit both basic and translational science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: MOLECULAR MECHANISMS OF THE DYSREGULATED IMMUNE RESPONSE TO EBOLA VIRUS OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ebola virus disease (EVD), formerly known as Ebola hemorrhagic fever, is characterized by an immune response that is incapable of controlling the virus but produces inflammation that runs out of control. Our program project will provide a comprehensive picture, which is not possible with individual small projects, of how this immune response in EVD goes wrong. This will help in the search for new drugs that can improve the outcome of Ebola virus-infected individuals and may also help us understand and manage other severe hemorrhagic fevers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Work proposed here will combine genetically encoded biosensors in a multiplexed screening assay in live cells to identify small molecule probes capable of inhibiting glucose uptake and metabolism in kinetoplastid parasites in order to develop tools for exploring this important yet incompletely understood metabolic pathway. The proposed work is impactful, as it will pioneer a new self-validating screening methodology that will yield useful tools for understanding glucose metabolism at the cellular level in a group of important early-branching eukaryotes and could also be adopted for use in other organisms. Additionally, outcomes from the research have the potential to advance treatment of neglected tropical diseases that, in some cases, have currently inadequate therapies.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed capacity-building training program is expected to have far-reaching effects on strengthening ethical research in Pakistan. There is tremendous potential of the training imparted during this program to translate into improvement of the research culture towards greater respect for participants and communities engaged in research. The aim of research ethics is to protect and respect participants, make them partners in the research ventures, and ensure equity and accessibility in sharing of research benefits; this project will be a step in that direction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of our research is to understand the role of specific immune cells in the development of type 1 diabetes. Insights obtained from this project will improve our understanding of regulatory T cells that respond to insulin in both health and type 1 diabetes, thereby providing pathways and molecular targets to enhance regulatory T cell function to prevent type 1 diabetes onset.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For the past 25 years, we have investigated the genetic bases of familial and sporadic Alzheimer’s disease (AD) in the Caribbean Hispanics. Despite identifying many genetic variants, the function of only a fraction of the relevant genes is fully understood. In this new proposal, we intend to conduct a genetically driven, epidemiological inclusive integration of AD in Caribbean Hispanics using deep molecular phenotyping: epigenomics, transcriptomics, proteomics and metabolomics to investigate genetic variants perturb pathways leading to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many youth purchase nicotine and cannabis vaping products from brick-and-mortar retailers (e.g., vape shops and dispensaries) which are disproportionately located in more disadvantaged neighborhoods; however, it is unknown whether density of tobacco and cannabis retailers around adolescents’ homes and schools is associated with youth vaping initiation and dependence, and whether associations are exacerbated for youth living in areas densely concentrated with both tobacco and cannabis retailers. This K01 award will use multiple existing data sources and new data from store observations to investigate the impact of the tobacco and cannabis retail environment and neighborhood disadvantage on adolescent nicotine and cannabis vaping. This work can inform regulations to prevent vaping and its harms for youth and will prepare the PI for independent R01 research that examines geospatial and regulatory determinants of youth nicotine and cannabis use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Novel drugs are in development to treat patient-specific forms of heart failure and arrhythmias and require a suitable patient specific context for testing. Through this work, we will develop an advanced tissue engineering platform, which is able to assess arrhythmias and changes in contractility in human-derived heart-like tissue structures in the dish, in order to evaluate the cardiac effectiveness of novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a degenerative brain disorder imposing an increasing societal health burden and currently presents no effective options for clinical treatment or prevention. This proposal will investigate the role of cell-type and sub-type specific noradrenergic receptors within the brain following long-term stimulation of the locus coeruleus in AD. The outcomes of this project will reveal significant biological unknowns concerning the pathogenesis and potential treatment of AD and aide in future development of novel therapeutics and neurotechnology for disease therapy.

PHR: This proposal is a continuation of the currently funded Research Ethics Education Program in Jordan with activities expanding to the Middle East and North Africa region with a more robust education initiative offered through a Master of Bioethics and the first online RCR training certification in Arabic. Graduates of this program will advance research and the next generation of researchers and be leaders in responsible conduct of research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Positron emission tomography (PET) is a powerful imaging modality to visualize molecular activities in the human body. In this project, we aim to dramatically improve the imaging resolution of PET by developing a novel positron detection mechanism that will bring ultrafast coincidence time resolution (CTR) of 10ps. If successful, the 10ps CTR PET will enable dynamic PET imaging to probe human physiology, and we will investigate this possibility for neurochemistry-specific functional brain imaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to understand the fundamental genetic, molecular, and cellular mechanisms that induce a “hangry” state in animals in response to food odor. Lack of a specific nutrient often dramatically changes physiology and behavior, including social behaviors, across animal species, but the underlying neuronal mechanism is largely unknown. Understanding how neuropeptides (small molecules used for communication between brain cells) change the way the brain interprets food odors is an important step in disentangling the complex relationship between smell, hunger, and behavior in the human brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Aggregation of the RNA binding protein TDP-43 has been reported in almost every age-dependent neurodegenerative disease, including frontal temporal dementia (FTD), ALS, Alzheimer's disease (AD), and in ~100% of a recently recognized AD-like dementia in the oldest of the elderly. We now seek to identify how acetylation of TDP-43, a modification that inhibits its RNA binding and drives its separation into liquid-like droplets and subsequent aggregation. We will also develop a potential therapeutic approach for TDP-43 proteinopathies by identification and use of synthetically evolved single chain antibodies to aggregated TDP-43 to catalyze its proteasome-mediated degradation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functional and cognitive recovery after traumatic brain injury (TBI) is highly variable and poorly understood. Better TBI prognostic models are urgently needed for individual patient care and prognostic stratification for TBI clinical trials. This career development award led by Amelia W. Maiga, MD, MPH will (1) create a better prognostic model with time-varying clinical data, image-based biomarkers, and TBI-specific biomarkers, and (2) describe distinct trajectories of functional and cognitive recovery after hospitalized TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The single most significant obstacle to total HIV clearance and therefore, a “cure” for HIV in humans is presence of a reservoir of silent HIV genomes that are not targeted by the immune system or by any available antiviral drug. We propose a strategy for the comprehensive cataloging of genes involved in HIV latency maintenance based on a novel technology for high throughput and versatile screening of 10s of thousands of genes in combination with other drugs. The goal is to find targets that more broadly activate HIV from latency while at the same time providing a greater degree of specificity for the virus in order to guide HIV elimination efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The majority of rheumatoid arthritis and juvenile idiopathic arthritis patients experience episodic arthritis flares, causing them to require life-long medications to control their disease. We have identified tissue resident memory T cells (TRM) that remain in the joint during remission and act as key mediators of arthritis flares. Understanding how TRM form in the joint will help us design new therapies that can prevent arthritis flares.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Genome instability is a common feature of multiple human diseases. This project focuses on the signaling mechanisms of Polo-like kinase 1 at chromosome centromeres that are required to maintain stability. By understanding chromatin-based signals, it will be possible to develop a basic mechanistic understanding of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic kidney disease (DKD) is highly prevalent and is associated with substantial morbidity and mortality. This project will define patterns of autophagy in human DKD, identify associations of autophagy with histopathology and kidney function, and validate blood and urine biomarker signatures reflecting kidney autophagy. Overall, this work will yield novel insights into the role of autophagy in human DKD and facilitate future investigation of kidney autophagy, paving the way for mechanism-focused diagnostic, prognostic, and therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Peripheral artery disease, atherosclerotic occlusive disease of the lower extremities, occurs in nearly a quarter of a billion people, disproportionately affects women and individuals with diabetes, and commonly leads to amputations. Current therapies are inadequate. This application is relevant to public health because it has the potential to discover new approaches to decrease the burden of peripheral artery disease in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Francois Jacob, the pioneering molecular geneticist, said that "The dream of every cell is to become two cells". This dream is challenging to achieve. For example, in humans the 6.2 billion DNA letters that encode the information for building and maintaining our bodies are organized into 46 chromosomes that must be copied and then precisely distributed to produce two identical daughter cells. Errors in the distribution of chromosomes cause birth defects and contribute to the ability of cancers to develop and evade treatment. The goals of this project are to address how cells achieve the Jacobian dream, preserving the integrity of their genomes through the process of division.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  The goal of this project is to evaluate repurposing the FDA-approved drug spironolactone (SP) currently used to treat a range of conditions, e.g., heart failure and hypertension, for inhibition of HIV. We have shown in cultured cells that SP blocks HIV gene expression and propose to evaluate this potential in the humanized mouse model of HIV infection, either alone, or in combination with another HIV gene expression inhibitor, dCA. We expect to gain valuable insight into the benefits of adding HIV transcriptional inhibitors to current antiretroviral therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE DNA damage by endogenous and environmental agents to nuclear and mitochondrial DNA has been identified as a causative factor in cancer, neurodegeneration and inflammation. In this project, we will determine how mitochondria deal with DNA damage, provide new insights into the relationship between mitochondrial DNA and energy metabolism and elucidate differences in how cancer and non-malignant cells respond to mitochondrial dysfunction. The results of these studies will advance our understanding of the causes of mitochondrial dysfunction and guide the development of novel therapeutic strategies for human diseases associated with mitochondrial dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative One of the most intriguing questions in science is how developmental pattern formation is executed so robustly despite unavoidable cell-to-cell variability in gene expression. We will investigate the mechanisms buffering this variability during vertebral segmentation. We will also elucidate how the transcriptome-level reorganization (expression levels and variability of thousands of genes) is controlled by cell signaling gradients. These information will be significant for understanding and potentially preventing vertebral malformations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE One of the most pressing needs to combat the HIV pandemic is a vaccine that can elicit antibodies that can neutralize the virus. The genetics of antibodies is remarkably complex, and understanding how they develop during vaccine responses in humans has only been possible in recent years. The goal of this grant proposal is to conduct genomic sequencing of the antibody region in rhesus monkeys that are used in HIV vaccine studies, and build a database to provide this data to the scientific community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance Statement This study will evaluate the impact of internet-based cognitive behavioral therapy on symptoms of insomnia in adult survivors of childhood cancer. We will also examine the impact of improved sleep on neurocognitive impairment, emotional distress, cardiovascular risk, and quality of life in a large sample of adult survivors of childhood cancer. Results will inform current standard-of-care as few efficacious interventions are available for the remediation of these relatively common and highly comorbid late effects in long-term survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Ewing Sarcoma Family of Tumors (ESFT) are bone and soft tissue cancers that affect children and young adults. Despite aggressive treatments with surgery, radiation and multi-agent chemotherapy, patients with advanced disease have a 5-year survival rate of less than 30%, and thus, there is a need for new ESFT therapy. This study will investigate our discovery that ESFT cells are dependent on the FEN1-nuclease for viability to provide a comprehensive pre-clinical evaluation of FEN1-inhibitors as novel and rational therapeutics for treating ESFT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Slicer Shape AnaLysis Toolbox (SALT) was developed as an open-source, free comprehensive software that allows biomedical scientists to precisely locate shape changes in their imaging studies. This proposal is designed to increase the continued success of SALT by recognizing that shape models and dynamic anatomical changes are challenging to interpret despite quantification of the geometry of physical objects. We will address this need by incorporating state-of-the-art and interpretable shape statistics methodology into SALT and new driving biological problems to illustrate their utility while continuing to provide effective user support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Herpesviruses infect the majority of the world’s human population by establishing lifelong latent infections that can periodically reactivate, causing a variety of ailments, including cold sores, blindness, encephalitis, and cancers, along with fatal conditions in newborns and the immunocompromised. The spread of infection relies on the ability of the virus to produce and release new infectious viral particles in a process termed nuclear egress and is the focus of this proposal. As there is no cure for herpesvirus infections, the goal of this proposal is to formulate a comprehensive mechanism as to how the nuclear egress complex, required for nuclear egress, mediates this process and determine how it can be inhibited to provide innovative routes for therapeutic approaches aimed at preventing the spread of infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spinal cord injury is a devastating problem that affects about 300,000 people in the United States, with 17,000 new cases each year. The diaphragm muscle (DIAm) is the most important inspiratory muscle, and its role in breathing and/or airway protection is seriously impaired in many cases of cervical spinal cord injury (cSCI). The proposed studies will use two well established animal models of cSCI (C2 hemisection – C2SH and C4 contusion injury – C4CI) to provide exciting, new information on the role of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) signaling through its high affinity receptor (TrkB) in the mechanisms underlying recovery of inspiratory function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Islet transplantation is a β-cell replacement therapy; however, 60-70% of islets are lost immediately following transplantation due to hypoxia, toxic metabolites from the liver, a pro-inflammatory environment and an instant blood-mediated inflammatory reaction (IBMIR). In this proposal, we will create a clinically translatable bioscaffold platform which combines multiple technologies that work together to provide sustained oxygen and nutrients to islets, while also restoring their bioenergetic profile via mitochondrial transfer from mesenchymal stem cells, until they can fully engraft and re-establish their own blood supply. Our studies will validate our technology at extra-vascular sites of transplantation and ensure there is no adverse inflammatory and foreign body reaction that will result in long term fibrosis, thereby paving the way for future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid addiction has been declared a public health crisis by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services and more than 130 people in the United States die daily after overdosing on opioids. Chronic pain is a long-term disability that causes motivational-affective changes in the brain and about 21-29% of patients prescribed opioids for chronic pain misuse them. Investigating how pain changes motivational-affective brain circuitry and influences opioid addiction risk will help scientists and doctors devise treatments that consider affective-motivational aspects of pain to prevent future drug abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The overall goal of this proposal is to accelerate advances in human health by engaging multiple stakeholders in the translation of scientific discoveries to drive improvements in health and reduce inequity among diverse populations. Our proposal will improve clinical research through high quality and efficient methods/processes, develop a trained workforce skilled in team science, and disseminate research findings into real-world implementation to improve health and healthcare for patients, our diverse communities, and our nation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many older adults living in nursing homes experience loneliness or social isolation. The impact of social isolation on the health and well-being of nursing home residents needs to be better understood. The COVID-19 pandemic restricted visitors to the homes and socializing within nursing homes. This study will examine the extent to which social isolation occurs in nursing homes, how it impacts health and well-being, and what factors may reduce social isolation and increase social connectedness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite evidence pharmacy closures disproportionately affect predominately Black and Hispanic neighborhoods, and Medicare Part-D policies and practices are a fundamental cause of such closures, the impact of pharmacy closures on persistent disparities in medication adherence among older adults is not known. The proposed project will evaluate the extent and impact of pharmacy closures on medication adherence among chronically ill Medicare Part-D beneficiaries and identify subgroups most at-risk for non-adherence post-closure. Our findings will contribute new evidence that policymakers need to advance equitable, and eliminate discriminatory, policies with Part-D and resolve persistent disparities in medication adherence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The proposed renewal application seeks to build upon the past success of the currently NIMH R25 funded Psychiatry Residency Research Education Program (PRREP). The goal of PRREP is to enhance the recruitment and training of psychiatrists for a career in academic psychiatry in order to meet the increasing shortage of physicians who conduct research in mental health and mental disorders. Training will focus on basic neuroscience, clinical science, imagining, genetics, public health, and epidemiology but can be in any area that impacts mental health and illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 25 million American adults live with persistent pain, contributing to their worsened health, disability and use of health care services. New strategies are urgently needed to understand the basic mechanisms, and develop non-opioid interventions. This project will investigate RNA-protein interactions in sensory neurons as a mechanism for the generation of persistent pain and determine if targeting these interactions is a viable future strategy for the development of a new class of therapeutics. Experiments will expand our basic knowledge of how the biosynthetic machinery within pain sensing neurons responds to tissue injuries and inflammation, and how these processes become dysregulated in pre-clinical models of chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding intracellular protein degradation is a key goal of basic research, with applications in biotechnology and medicine. Enzymes of the AAA+ family clear the cell of toxic proteins and carry out many other ATP-dependent cellular processes needed to promote health and prevent disease. Our studies will illuminate molecular mechanisms employed by a specific AAA+ protease, ClpXP, and shed light on the entire enzyme superfamily.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Dysfunction and death of the insulin-producing β-cell underlies virtually all forms of diabetes, and the protection of β-cells represents an approach to the treatment of diabetes that has yet to be exploited. The 12-LOX pathway represents an attractive target for protection of β-cells, since inhibitors of this pathway have been developed. This proposal will provide a better understanding of how the 12-LOX pathway can be manipulated to protect β-cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The University of Maryland School of Public Health proposes to continue a Summer Training and Research (STAR) program for yrs 11-15 that provides underrepresented and disadvantaged undergraduate students with two consecutive 10-wk summers of research and career development training to enhance their potential to apply for and complete graduate degrees in biomedical and behavioral science relevant to preventing and treating cardiovascular disease. The aim of the STAR program is to increase diversity in the pool of individuals who ultimately choose careers in biomedical and behavioral research to reduce premature morbidity and mortality from cardiovascular, lung, and blood diseases. STAR Trainees primarily focus on laboratory research closely integrated with that of their faculty Mentor; in addition, Trainees meet weekly to discuss research issues, set weekly goals, meet with various academic professionals for dynamic exchanges about graduate school issues, discuss classic research articles on cardiovascular disease, and take part in either Ethics- Related (first year trainees) or Research-Related (second year trainees) Training.

PHR: RELEVANCE: Given the disproportionate burden of cardiovascular disease in rural areas, particularly in the southeastern portion of the United States, the proposed study will examine whether features of neighborhood physical and social environments are associated with CVD risk and subclinical disease burden in rural communities, and which groups are most vulnerable and resilient to the health impacts of these environments. Findings from this research may help to elucidate the key contextual drivers of cardiovascular risk and resilience in rural communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This training program recruits 6 undergraduate diversity students for research experiences and mentorship in environmental health sciences for one year and will include an intensive summer program focusing on laboratory experiences, mentoring, responsible conduct of research training and educational/inspirational experiences. Students will gain a better understanding of future career options and how to prepare for graduate or professional school with a long-range goal of increasing the number and quality of diversity students pursuing a career path in basic, translational or clinical environmental health sciences research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early identification of individuals at high risk for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) has been partially addressed by genetic risk scores and gene expression prediction models, though these tools are suboptimal in non-Europeans. We propose developing a multi-ancestry genetic and blood- and lung-based gene expression risk scores. We will use these risk scores to classify individuals and identify drugs for COPD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed research is relevant to public health because necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) affects 7% of infants hospitalized in neonatal intensive care units and is a leading cause of neonatal sepsis. Prevention and treatment strategies are currently lacking. This project is relevant to the NIH’s mission because it will define the mechanistic response of the intestinal epithelium during NEC, developing fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burden and mortality of this human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative  There is currently no ideal therapy for type II diabetes (TIID), the most prevalent type of diabetes, which doubles a patient’s risk for cardiovascular disease (CVD) and death due to CVD. In this proposal, we will examine the molecular mechanisms by which a high fat diet induces insulin resistance in the heart, as obesity is thought to be its main cause. This information will allow for the development of new and effective therapies to prevent CVD in patients with TIID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The experiments will test what changes occur in the prefrontal cortex after subjects are trained to perform a cognitive task that requires visual, short-term memory. Such training has shown promise in improving cognitive function after traumatic brain injury, stroke, and normal aging. Our results will uncover the changes in brain circuits following cognitive training and offer insights on the design of better treatment strategies for these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Experience-dependent neural network refinement is a fundamental process during postnatal brain development. This project is to investigate the molecular mechanisms that underlies silent synapse-based cortical excitatory network refinement. Specifically, we aim to dissect a signaling hub, coordinated by the signaling scaffold PSD- 95 that controls the pace of silent synapse maturation local visual cortex circuits and visual perception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Black and Hispanic women of childbearing age are at risk for alterations in sleep health that contribute to significant health outcomes, including adverse pregnancy outcomes, cardiometabolic and psychological health. We will conduct a comprehensive evaluation of multi-dimensional aspects of sleep health and determine the associations between potentially modifiable sleep-related cognitions and behaviors and sleep health and the extent to which cognitions and behaviors moderate the relationships between social and environmental determinants and sleep health. The results will be used to inform future intervention to promote sleep health, reduce sleep deficiency, and improve sleep-related outcomes among these women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: NARRATIVE The central hypothesis of this proposal is that the muscle stem cell niche is an everchanging environment in which proteases play an important role by cleaving and activating, or neutralizing, signaling molecules, their receptors, and the extracellular matrix. Our three specific aims are to define how the muscle stem cell niche is remodeled in the early hours and days after injury by the activity of neutrophil serine proteases. We will identify the cellular and molecular mechanisms regulated by neutrophil serine proteases in the context of muscle regeneration with a special focus on muscle stem cell activation, and further validate them in appropriate cell and animal model systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Work proposed here will combine genetically encoded biosensors in a multiplexed screening assay in live cells to identify small molecule probes capable of inhibiting glucose uptake and metabolism in kinetoplastid parasites in order to develop tools for exploring this important yet incompletely understood metabolic pathway. The proposed work is impactful, as it will pioneer a new self-validating screening methodology that will yield useful tools for understanding glucose metabolism at the cellular level in a group of important early-branching eukaryotes and could also be adopted for use in other organisms. Additionally, outcomes from the research have the potential to advance treatment of neglected tropical diseases that, in some cases, have currently inadequate therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition is a critical process in the dissemination of tumor cells from the primary tumor to distal organs. Tumor-initiating cells are formed in this transition, making possible the growth of new tumors at distal organs. Based on a novel mechanism by which the splicing of messenger RNA and the synthesis of new proteins encoded by that mRNA promotes this transition and tumor initiation, the proposed research will characterize new cellular mechanisms that may be targeted to suppress colorectal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intestinal helminth parasites that infect billions worldwide and cause significant morbidity are associated with a Type 2 inflammatory response. The factors that turn this response on and off, especially in affected tissues like the lung and intestine, are not completely understood, representing a major gap in our understanding. Studies in this application will explore how the lipid prostaglandin D2 and its receptor CRTH2 (chemoattractant receptor- homologous molecule expressed on Th2 cells) regulate innate immune and intestinal epithelial biology during Type 2 inflammation, informing efforts to target potent prostaglandin pathways to treat Type 2 inflammation- associated diseases including helminth infection and allergic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: A major challenge to patients with estrogen receptor (ER) positive breast cancer is the metastatic progression that significantly reduces their survival rate. This proposal aims to dissect the role and impact of androgen receptor (AR) on the metastatic progression of patients with gains of constitutively active ER mutations as a result of resistance to the aromatase inhibitor, a standard therapy that prevents the conversion of androgens to estrogens. The knowledge gained from this research will significantly advance our understanding of the critical signals and regulators that promote metastasis and facilitate the development of targeted therapies for ER mutant breast cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is characterized by massive β-cell loss due to autoimmune destruction. The generation of pancreatic β cells derived from stem cells (SC-β-cell) holds great promise for cell replacement therapy for T1D patients, and may serve as a disease model to facilitate the discovery of new therapies. This research will improve SC-β-cells produced in the dish by correcting how these cells utilize glucose in their mitochondria, a key process mediating insulin secretion.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Herpes simplex virus infects >70% of the US population colonizing the nervous system for life. Episodic emergence of virus in response to stress can cause nervous tissue damage and is considered a risk factor for the onset of neurodegenerative disease. Knowledge gained in these studies will identify potential targets for new antiviral therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Although neurodevelopmental disorders are most commonly studied in childhood and adolescence, the trajectory of aging for the nearly 6 million adults in the United States currently living with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) remains largely unknown. With this study, we will evaluate age-related brain changes in socioemotional circuitry and begin to identify ASD phenotypes most vulnerable to pathological aging and windows of opportunity for intervention to promote healthy aging in this rapidly growing population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Discoveries from basic systems neuroscience demonstrate that external senses (such as vision) interact with the internally generated, cognitive representations that underlie thoughts, perceptions, experience, expectations, and so on. Cognitive disorganization and memory loss are devastating consequences of numerous forms of neurological and psychiatric disorders, including Alzheimer's Disease, stroke, and schizophrenia. These experiments will provide crucial information about the neural mechanisms that allow information from the external senses to interact adaptively with internally generated, cognitive representations, providing insight into how these processes are disrupted in neurological and psychiatric disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: We have sought the basis of spinocerebellar ataxia type 7 (SCA7) neurodegeneration by focusing on polyglutamine-expanded ataxin-7 transcription and epigenetic dysregulation, and after implicating DNA damage, metabolic dysregulation, mitochondrial abnormalities, and calcium dyshomeostasis in SCA7 disease pathogenesis, we are now performing single-cell transcriptome and epigenome analysis to define the cellular and molecular processes underlying both the cone-rod dystrophy retinal degeneration and cerebellar degeneration. Employing a novel Purkinje cell-enriched single nucleus (sn)RNA-seq method, we discovered altered synaptic organization and dramatic dysregulation of normal aldolase-C / zebrin-II expression patterning, and based upon analysis of related SCA polyQ disease model mice, altered cerebellar neurodevelopment is emerging as a shared disease feature across various polyQ cerebellar ataxias. We now wish to continue this line of investigation, and propose a series of experiments intended to identify DEGs and DARs from different cell types to reveal genes and regulatory elements that underlie the molecular pathology in SCA7 retinal degeneration and cerebellar degeneration, and then to determine the biological and physiological relevance of delineated transcription factor alterations and epigenetic dysregulation by modulating the expression and function of implicated factors in SCA7 knock-in model mice and by pursuing in vivo epigenetic rescue strategy involving use of Cre-inducible dCas9-p300 (or -KRAB) mice to determine if such interventions can ameliorate SCA7 retinal and cerebellar pathology, including disrupted zebrin-II patterning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Memory loss is a devastating consequence of a number of neurological disorders, including Alzheimer's disease, stroke, and epilepsy. The hippocampus is a brain structure that is critical for the ability to form new memories and is highly susceptible to damage from these disorders, but the exact neural circuits and mechanisms underlying the role of the hippocampus in memory are not well understood. The results from this project will provide insight into how the normal brain encodes memories, which may provide powerful new clues to understand why deficits in memory arise from these neurological disorders and how these crippling deficits may be ameliorated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Nuclear pore complex (NPC)-associated cofactors are shown to cooperate with the regulators of N6- adenosine methylation (m6A) to control the nuclear export of mRNAs, which is essential for normal functions of certain physiological processes. However, no studies have ever investigated the role of this cooperation in cancer. Our preliminary data demonstrated that the m6A methyltransferase METTL3 directly binds to a component of NPCs called NUP93 in cancer cells, which ensures the efficient export of m6A-containing mRNAs. Interestingly, a subgroup of the mRNA cargos of the METTL3-NUP93 complex in prostate cancer (PCa) cells are functionally enriched in biosynthesis of androgen, the ligand for the main driver of PCa progression — androgen receptor (AR). Thus, in this study we aim to (1). Elucidate how the METTL3-NUP93 complex selects the target mRNAs and facilitates their nuclear export; (2). Investigate how the m6A-METTL3- NUP93 axis increases the intratumoral androgen levels and stimulates AR activity; and (3). Evaluate the therapeutic potential of targeting the m6A-METTL3-NUP93 axis for the treatment of castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC), the most aggressive form of the disease. As such, our research will furnish novel insights into the functions of m6A and NPCs in PCa progression and offer promising anticancer drug targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aberrant Protein Kinase A (PKA) signaling drives the growth and progression of a subset of lung, ovarian, liver, adrenal and gastrointestinal tumors. Pharmacologically targeting these aggressive cancers is challenging as directly inhibiting PKA has dire consequences such as heart failure, kidney dysfunction and diabetes. This multi- investigator project tests if PKAc-driven cancers can be treated by targeting its downstream effects on mRNA translation by inhibiting the helicase eIF4A rather than globally blocking the activity of the kinase.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narratives: Congenital kidney diseases are the most common congenital disabilities, and Wilms tumor is the most common type of kidney tumor in children, accounting for nearly 90% of cases. This grant aims to elucidate the underlying causes of these diseases and address critical questions about how transcription factors interact with chromatin remodelers and cis-regulatory DNA elements to mediate the development of a small group of progenitor cells into large numbers of nephrons (blood-filtering units) in a mature kidney. Understanding how nephron progenitors are specified and maintained may eventually provide insights for preventing or treating these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is an unmet need in modern medicine, and is associated with comorbidities like obesity, diabetes, and hypertension. HFpEF is characterized by pronounced coronary microvascular dysfunction (CMD), but the causal contribution of CMD is not clear. The current proposal is to study the impact of CMD on the cardiac function and remodeling in HFpEF and will test the hypothetical benefit of miR-21 deletion on maintaining the coronary microvascular function, myocardial blood flow and cardiac function in HFpEF using global and tissue-specific miR-21 knockout and lineage tracing mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Public Health Narrative Many skin diseases such as inflammatory diseases are due to the dysregulated immune homeostasis in the skin. Understanding how the immune system in the skin is regulated is fundamental to understand the basis of immune homeostasis and inflammation in the skin, the largest barrier tissue of a body under frequent assaults of various environmental factors. Findings from our proposed study on regulation of skin-specific migration and localization of various innate-like T lymphocytes will aid our understanding of molecular mechanisms regulating the skin immune response and development of therapeutic targets in treatment of the skin inflammation diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Research suggests that synaptic activity and signaling can regulate social behavior that is essential to survive for many species. However, the links between synaptic regulation and social behavior are not completely understood. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  We propose to develop rigorous and ﬂexible statistical tools for analyzing and decoding the rich glucose data from inpatient use of continuous glucose monitoring (CGM). The applications of the proposed statistical methods will generate useful insight for making evidence-based customized treatment decisions, leading to improved care for hospitalized patients with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurocognitive deficits represent a core component of several major neuropsychiatric disorders, most notably schizophrenia, affective disorders, autism spectrum disorders, and attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The proposed study is designed to exploit the Cognitive Genomics (COGENT) consortium dataset, in which we have performed large-scale genome-wide association studies of cognitive performance, as well as other publicly available genetic and neuroimaging datasets, to enhance our understanding of the causes of psychiatric illness and its treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the major challenges in vaccine development is access to adjuvants that promote long lived pathogen specific CD4+ and CD8+ T cell responses and provide protective cell mediated immunity. Our previous studies identified an adjuvant that induces protective long lived T cell populations in mice and primates but why this approach is so effective is unclear. Using next generation sequencing methods, we looked at what genes our vaccine-elicited cells were expressing. We found a unique gene expression program, guided by 2 factors that normally mediate opposing cellular functions to one another in a T cell responding to an infection. The overall goals of this project are to investigate what cellular function each factor is supporting, and how these normally competitive factors cooperate to keep the vaccine-elicited T cell alive and growing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Electrical stimulation of the brain, including deep brain stimulation, effectively reduces seizures in patients with epilepsy, but rarely leads to complete freedom from seizures. Progress in improving this important therapy is being hampered by poor understanding of the mechanisms by which electrical stimulation reduces seizures. In this project we will elucidate mechanisms of DBS in epilepsy in an animal model and expect that a better knowledge of how neurons in specific networks are affected by electrical stimulation could lead to further improvement of this therapy with the goal of achieving seizure freedom in more, if not all patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Depression is a leading cause of disability, and for many individuals, existing antidepressants are slow to relieve symptoms or do not provide lasting benefits. This project will investigate the molecular and circuit-level mechanisms by which antidepressants act to reverse the effects of chronic stress on reward-seeking behavior, and how these effects are sustained over time. Our studies will advance our understanding of how the brain integrates information about rewards in our environment and the effort required to obtain them, and will potentially open new avenues for identifying novel treatment targets for anhedonia in depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Smokers with mental illness (MI) have dangerously high rates of smoking, low rates of quitting, and greater risk of tobacco-related disease and early death than any other group in the US, justifying creation of new harm reduction strategies for smokers who have been unable and/or are not ready to quit. After demonstrating in a randomized study that almost 19% of smokers with MI who received electronic cigarettes (e-cigs) for 8 weeks replaced their cigarettes with e-cigs and had significantly lower levels of cancer-causing chemicals, we developed “SWITCH IT,” a behavioral support and harm reduction approach designed to help smokers replace as many cigarettes as possible with e-cigs. The proposed study will randomly assign 250 smokers with MI to receive e-cigs for 8 weeks, with or without SWITCH IT, to examine specific ways SWITCH IT might help smokers reduce harm from smoking (such as by increasing confidence for using e-cigs instead of smoking to reduce stress) and further advance the science of tobacco harm reduction by exploring outcomes using different definitions of “switching” and harm reduction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Persistent pain and hyperalgesia arising from tissue/nerve injury reflect an enhanced signaling mediated by DRG nociceptive neurons, macrophages, and spinal microglia. We now recognize that a common thread linking the enhanced responsivity associated with these three neuraxial components are cholesterol-rich lipid rafts that also express Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4-rafts). The present studies will define the principles of TLR4raft organization in DRG neurons and macrophages, the plasticity in this organization with nerve injury and tissue inflammation; and the impact of disrupting TLR4-rafts in alleviating neuropathic and inflammatory pain.

PHR: Project Narrative Research has shown that dysfunctional cognitive-emotion interactions undermine self-regulation in subtypes of high-risk individuals which contribute to risk for relapse to substance use and antisocial activity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Internalizing disorders, primarily anxiety and depression, are highly prevalent among adolescents receiving community-based treatment for SUD; moreover, unresolved internalizing issues significantly interfere with adolescent SUD treatment and recovery. Yet, routine services for youth SUD do not systematically target internalizing disorders. The proposed study will address this quality gap by developing a modular, family-based protocol to augment routine youth SUD care by directly targeting co-occurring internalizing problems as a primary treatment goal: Family Support Protocol for Adolescent Internalizing Disorders (Fam-AID).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic retinal microangiopathy is a key pathogenic event for the development and progression of diabetic retinopathy (DR), the leading cause of blindness in adults. We have designed studies to investigate the molecular mechanism(s) of diabetes-induced retinal endothelial cells stress-induced premature senescence (SISP) as this process, also known as inflammaging, is central to the development of the vascular pathology associated with the development of (DR). In particular, we will study the molecular and functional events associated with dysfunction of the HDAC6-SIRT-1 axis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Those at-risk for bipolar disorder and those diagnosed with the disorder demonstrate significant positive emotion dysregulation (PED), and PED is related to the severity of illness, functional outcomes, and comorbid conditions. This project will use multi-method experimental behavioral and neuroimaging paradigms to examine PED among three emerging adult groups: (1) early-onset bipolar disorder diagnosis, (2) at high-risk for bipolar disorder but not yet diagnosed, and (3) at low-risk for bipolar disorder. Of import, we will conduct novel work to examine how PED can prospectively predict the onset and progression of bipolar mood symptoms across a two-year longitudinal follow-up within the early-onset and high-risk groups to predict the early onset and progression of symptoms, so as to foster development of future interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  This project addresses a key translational gap in the treatment of chronic viral infections, which pose a major public health challenge with over 350 million individuals world-wide infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), and hepatitis B and C viruses (HBV and HCV). By providing a more complete understanding of how the self-renewing quiescent, yet functionally poised multipotent population of TCF-1Hi stem-like CD8 T cells develop in chronic viral infections, this project will unravel novel druggable targets and immunotherapy strategies for enhancing control of chronic viral infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project utilizes biochemical and computational methods to study the catalytic machinery of the bifunctional enzyme KatG in Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent for tuberculosis (TB) in humans. The proposed study is beneficial to human health for two reasons. This study will help 1) fight TB by disrupting the self-defense mechanism of KatG against an increased level of hydrogen peroxide in the infected host cell and 2) boost isoniazid activation in those specific isoniazid-resistance strains due to KatG mutations by enhancing their catalytic activity towards prodrug activation instead of other functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Recent clinical trials have added radiation therapy to immune checkpoint inhibitors based on the dogma that radiation releases antigens that’s activates dendritic cells and primes CD8+ T cell responses to result in an abscopal response. However, these abscopal responses are rarely seen, perhaps due to radiation-dependent lymphocyte apoptosis. The critical knowledge gap is how different forms of radiation-induced cell death induce both anti-tumor immunity and side effects from radiation; the proposed work will inform future development of immunotherapies and radiation therapy synergy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Lung cancer is the most commonly diagnosed cancer and the leading cause of cancer death. Recently, checkpoint blockade has demonstrated impressive results in resectable NSCLC, however the immunogenomic determinants of response or resistance in this setting remain largely unknown. In the present study, we will leverage biospecimens obtained from an existing clinical trial of neoadjuvant PD-1 blockade in resectable lung cancer to determine the functional impact of checkpoint blockade on T cell programs and to identify molecules/pathways that could guide development of future therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The main aim of the proposed research is to develop novel methods to improve glycopeptide enrichment, isomeric separation, identification, and quantification. This will be achieved by (1) the development of a novel mesoporous graphitized carbon liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry (MGC-LC-MS/MS) platform in combination with a hydrophobicity index of peptides (HIP) for better separation and identification of glycopeptide isomers; (2) the development of a 15N metabolic labeling + 18-plex tandem mass tag (TMT) method to achieve a 36-plex multiplexing and a PRM isomeric glycopeptide approach for better quantitation of glycopeptide isomers; (3) the development of novel glycopeptide derivatization methods to enhance the isomeric glycopeptides characterization and enrichment; and (4) the development of improved software and algorithms to improve automated characterization of glycopeptide isomers. Together, these proposed works will improve glycopeptide isomeric characterization. The outcomes of this proposal will provide reliable and efficient glycoproteomic platforms and algorithms for a better isomeric characterization of glycopeptides which can be employed to address biomedical issue, thus contributing to the glycoscience community.

PHR: NARRATIVE: Poor person-centered maternal care (PCMC) contributes to high maternal mortality and morbidity, directly and indirectly, through lack of, delayed, inadequate, unnecessary, or harmful care. The proposed R01 will test the effectiveness of an intervention that targets provider stress and bias to improve PCMC. The results will advance the evidence base for interventions to improve PCMC and contribute to equity in maternal and neonatal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need for reproducible technology solutions for efficient, cost-effective, and quality home modifications (HM) that support older adults to live independently and safely in their homes longer (Aging in Place) irrespective of their disease and/or disability status. HomesRenewed Ventures is developing an advanced interactive mobile application that will assist contractors and handy workers in completing HM tasks by generating site-specific design specifications, installation instructions, and documentation for quality assurance. Our long-term goal is to help Americans age in their home safely and healthfully, thereby reducing health care spending and supporting independence and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will utilize large and diverse registry-based samples of patients with early-onset colorectal cancer to estimate the risk of recurrence associated with clinical and sociodemographic data and characterize surveillance intensity and survivorship care needs across multiple domains using patient surveys. Using these population-based estimates of recurrence risk and patient care needs, we will then engage with clinician, patient, and caregiver stakeholders to develop and evaluate a stratified survivorship care framework and care pathways to improve care for this understudied and growing population of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Cutaneous T-cell lymphomas are incurable forms of skin cancer with highly variable clinical behavior without robust genomic tests that can be used for early diagnosis or predict who will have aggressive disease. Our laboratory recently identified genetic alterations in CTCL that will offer us with a strategy for developing better diagnostic and prognostic tools. The studies in this proposal will lead to development of simple blood-based genetic assays that will improve early detection and predict their clinical behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE Delivery of high-quality care for the 5.8 million individuals living with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) is a national priority that is hindered by our lack of understanding of the ways in which comorbidities such as serious mental illness (SMI) contribute to unique care needs, symptoms, and disease burden. The proposed project will use both national data and formal caregiver perspectives to characterize the impact of having both SMI and ADRD on symptoms, disease burden, and care. The findings will be used to identify possible targets for future development and testing of person-centered interventions that address these unique needs and improve outcomes for persons with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Disease caused by viruses such as dengue, chikungunya, and dengue, which are transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito, affect millions of people living in and traveling to the tropics; however, traditional approaches to mosquito control have not proven effective. We will conduct a randomized clinical trial in Merida, Mexico, to test whether application of insecticides with months of residual activity to specific mosquito resting sites in homes (targeted indoor residual spraying) reduces laboratory-confirmed cases of mosquito-borne virus infection. This work will have broad implications for how health programs around the world combat mosquito-borne viruses and set a precedent for the study and implementation of novel mosquito control interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The more than 700 microbial species identified as resident in the human oral cavity live in highly organized structures, and the relationships among the species determine the community's net functions and effects on the host. These biofilms can be visualized using new imaging techniques, but statistical methods to analyze the structures and relationships are lacking. We propose to create and share such tools, which will be used to extract information that will improve disease control and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in breast cancer prevention and therapies, Black women exhibit increasing incidence and continue to have the highest breast cancer mortality rate compared to any other racial population. Mammographic density is one of the strongest breast cancer risk factors, yet, while Black women are more likely to exhibit higher mammographic density, unique predictors of mammographic density are severely understudied in this vulnerable population. Using the Black Women’s Health Study, the largest cohort of Black women in the United States, the overall goal of this proposal is to identify life course developmental and maturation risk factors for increased mammographic density.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By 2060, the burden of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias in the U.S. is expected to double with women being overrepresented among cases, but many powerful and highly prevalent aspects of women’s lives–including exposure to gender-based violence–have received almost no attention in ADRD research. Thus, we propose to investigate the relationship between experiences of intimate partner violence and cognitive decline among cis-gender women. This work may suggest new strategies for ADRD prevention, reveal how lifecourse social experiences of women influence ADRD risk, and elucidate potential mechanisms of ADRD development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative There is an urgent need to develop novel therapeutic options for uveal melanoma, the most common primary cancer of the eye in adults that affects more than 2,500 patients each year in the US alone, nearly 50% of which will die from metastatic disease. The recent discovery of the GNAQ uveal melanoma oncogene, which encodes GTPase deficient and constitutively active Gαq proteins has provided an opportunity to investigate its cancer promoting mechanisms. Ultimately, our planned team efforts aimed at elucidating the GNAQ-oncogenic signaling circuitry will reveal novel targeted (precision) therapies for advanced UM and metastatic UM patients and many other human diseases involving aberrant GNAQ expression and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cancer research in Zambia, particularly population-based research, is limited, primarily due to a lack of well- trained investigators, supportive research infrastructure, and adequate funding. Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VUMC) and the University of Zambia (UNZA) are expanding their longstanding research training partnership to establish a new training program, the Vanderbilt-Zambia Cancer Research Training Program (VZCARE). The goal of VZCARE is to develop a cadre of researchers and educators equipped with modern knowledge and expertise to lead cancer epidemiology research and training in Zambia, to encourage US- based researchers to engage in cancer research in low- and middle-income countries, and to ensure long-term program impacts and sustainability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The strong link between the heart and the nervous system is critical for daily living, but becomes abnormal during chronic heart disease, and is associated with risk of death. In this proposal, we will investigate whether Satellite Glial Cells, an often ignored cell type within the nervous system, plays an important role in the process by which the links between the heart and nervous system become abnormal. If involved, our study's findings will lay the groundwork for future studies that guide therapies targeting satellite glial cells.
