IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE Deregulation of cullin–RING ubiquitin ligase (CRL) complexes contributes broadly to human disease, including cancer, infectious diseases, sleep disorders, metabolic diseases, degenerative neurologic disorders, etc. Notably, thalidomide and other imids, which repurpose specific cellular CRL complexes to degrade neo-substrates, have shown clinical success. The major goal of our research is to determine how CRL complexes control essential biological processes at the cellular and organismal levels, revealing yet unknown mechanisms and new therapeutic strategies for a wide range of human diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dengue is the most significant mosquito-transmitted virus that infects humans. We propose to use computational tools to design dengue envelope protein subunit vaccines and evaluate their safety and efficacy in mouse models of vaccination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is the most common monogenic kidney disease and the fourth cause of renal failure among adults, with close to $3.5 billion spent annually on the treatment of patients in the US alone. Yet there remain tremendous challenges in several facets of the disease, including the need for additional therapies to delay disease progression and identification of early disease specific biomarkers to assess disease severity, monitor disease progression and a treatment effect, from early stages of the disease. The findings resulting from this study will: 1) advance the understanding in the pathophysiology of ADPKD, 2) may identify novel biomarkers, and 3) point out additional mechanisms that could be target for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a chronic, progressive and fatal disease that affects ~180,000 Americans. To date there are very limited treatment options for IPF with many patients requiring lung transplantation as the last resort. Our lab has identified a activation of Sineoculis homeobox homolog 1 (SIX1) and its co-factor eyes absent homolog (EYA) in IPF; however how the SIX1/EYA1 axis modulates lung fibrosis is not known and will be studied in this proposal.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Our study focuses on improving measurement as well as prevention of complications that patients experience related to routinely placed tubes called urinary catheters to empty the bladder during and after surgery; urinary catheters are among the most commonly used medical devices in the world with an estimated 100 million indwelling catheters sold annually worldwide and one-quarter million sold in the United States, but urinary catheters’ risks have not been well studied. Although infections related to urinary catheters are getting more attention recently due to Medicare-required public reporting and hospital penalties, there is less recognition that non- infectious complications related to the trauma of catheter placement and removal are as common as urinary tract infections – and often have long-lasting consequences for patients with abnormal bladder emptying and discomfort. This study is being performed to develop better tools to measure and reduce perioperative urinary catheter use, as well as related post- operative urinary retention and urinary catheter complications.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Improving the Safety of Surgical Patients by Addressing Urinary Catheter Use, Urinary Retention, and Catheter Injury
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: L. PROJECT NARRATIVE We have established chemically defined culture methods for deriving embryonic joint progenitor-like cells that preferentially form cartilage, showing signs of permanent, articular-like cartilage, from human pluripotent stem cells. The proposed study will elucidate the underlying mechanisms of this process, by defining genes essential for the genesis of joint progenitors and progression from them to articular cartilage, using cellular molecular genetics, genomics, tissue engineering, and transplantation technologies, and then the generated information will be applied to studies of clinically relevant human adult stem cells, in order to verify that we are also able to regenerate articular cartilage efficiently from adult cells. The proposed research will thus provide the foundation for basic research towards understanding the mechanisms of articular cartilage formation, leading to a novel therapeutic method for joint cartilage repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Hepatic stellate cells are the main fibrogenic cell types of the liver, promoting the deposition of extracellular matrix and the progression to fibrosis and cirrhosis in many different types of liver disease. Our proposal will investigate protective and fibrosis-independent functions of hepatic stellate cells, focusing on their role in the regulation of liver injury and regeneration. For this we will combine mice with selective depletion or knockout of hepatic stellate cells in conjunction with in vitro models and novel single cell-sequencing based bioinformatic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brown adipose tissue (BAT) is an essential regulator of energy balance and glucose homeostasis. Human genetic variants in ankyrin-B, a scaffolding protein expressed in several metabolic tissues, including brown adipose tissue, lead to increased risk of metabolic diseases such as obesity and type 2 diabetes (T2D). This project will investigate the role of ankyrin-B in glucose uptake and fatty acid synthesis in BAT, as a likely mechanism underlying dysregulation of lipid metabolism, energy balance, and systemic metabolic homeostasis caused by ankyrin-B deficiency in BAT and will further our knowledge of BAT physiology and the contribution of deficits in BAT function to the development of obesity and T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite clear evidence of the benefit of integrated care for HIV and opioid use disorder on both HIV and opioid use disorder related outcomes, there is a gap between the evidence and “real- world” practices. The objectives of this proposal are to understand the barriers to integrated care from the patient, provider, clinic, and governmental level in New Jersey and to evaluate the effectiveness of an implementation strategy, that uses coaching and a collaborative learning environment, to help clinics adopt an integrated care model for HIV and opioid use disorder treatment. It is expected that the findings from this project will contribute valuable information about the impact and mechanisms by which implementation science strategies improve the quality of health care delivery to people with HIV and opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Ion channels are the targets of drugs used to treat pain, epilepsy, mood disorders, hypertension, and arrhythmia. Our work aims to understand the fundamental mechanisms that control the function of a family of ion channels, known as K2Ps, that are involved in thermal, mechanical, and chemical sensing and to develop and understand the mechanisms of action of novel reagents that affect channel function. Such knowledge and reagents have direct relevance for development of more efficacious treatments of nervous system and cardiovascular disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Development of the proposed statistical method will advance scientific understanding of the associations between highly variable temporal changes in psychological states and allow for assessment of the impact of a given intervention on vulnerability to smoking lapses. By increasing understanding of the factors that trigger smoking lapses, knowledge generated by this method will also enhance development of effective interventions. This novel methodology can be used to analyze data generated from mobile health studies in a variety of different settings beyond smoking cessation, and thus has the potential to contribute to fundamental understanding of dynamic risk factors relating to drug use and other chronic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Hippocampal dysfunctions, which arise in the course of aging, mental illnesses (major depression, schizophrenia), neurological disorders (epilepsy) or neurodegenerative diseases (Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s), can lead to impairment of navigation and spatial attention. Little is known about the link between spatial attention and hippocampal spatial codes, primarily because it is difficult to track moment-to-moment changes in attention in traditional research animals. The proposed experiments will bridge this gap by using novel technologies and new experimental paradigms in echolocating bats, which enable measurement of attentional shifts on a rapid timescale, to elucidate how spatial attention modulates hippocampal spatial codes—a key open question in the neurobiology of navigation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Our research focuses on molecular interactions, and we develop methods for protein-protein docking and the characterization of ligand binding properties of proteins. Predictive tools for these applications will be substantially improved by integrating classical biophysical approaches with sequence, structure, and interaction information on biological macromolecules, and by utilizing the unprecedented availability of computer power. The methods will be implemented as web-based servers for use by the biomedical research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PRPOJECT NARRATIVE The NRAS gene is frequently mutated in leukemia and other human cancers. These mutations lead to the production of over-active N-Ras proteins that are very difficult targets for drug development. The overall goal of this project is to test a novel strategy for inhibiting the mutant N-Ras proteins found in cancer cells by blocking enzymes that regulate where N-Ras is located in cells and its biochemical output.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Sickle cell anemia and β-thalassemia are among the most common inherited disorders, whose clinical symptoms can be ameliorated by increasing the levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF). We have identified Pumilo-1 (PUM1), an RNA binding protein with no previously reported functions in erythropoiesis, as a post-transcriptional regulator of hemoglobin switching. The proposed studies will determine if modulating PUM1 can be employed as a potential therapeutic strategy for fetal hemoglobin induction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The striatum is a brain structure that plays an essential role in action control, reward and decision making, and its dysfunction is associated with neuropsychiatric disorders. We aim to employ modern optical measurement technologies to visualize and investigate the precise neuromodulator releases and subcellular signaling events involved in locomotion in behaving mice. We expect that our study will lead to a deeper understanding of neuromodulatory mechanisms underlying striatal function and locomotion control, which will in turn lead to an increased understanding of neuropsychiatric diseases associated with striatal dysfunction.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: We hypothesize that PDACs with an immunogenic profile could be a target subgroup that is responsive to immunotherapy either by MSLN-VLP vaccination or combination therapy of VLPs and an immune checkpoint inhibitor. We will test our hypothesis in pre-clinical animal models that best recapitulate human PDAC patient’s response to immunotherapy, including PDX and humanized mouse models. We propose two specific aims. In Aim 1, we will determine whether the immunogenic subtype of PDAC is responsive to MSLN-VLP vaccine in PDX-hu- NSG model. Here, we will use EDec method to stratify VA PDACs by subtype and then determine MSLN-VLP vaccine efficacy in specific PDAC subgroups in humanized PDX mouse model. In Aim 2, we will determine whether combination therapy with anti-PD-1 Ab enhances MSLN VLP vaccine responses and efficacy in onco-humice model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative:  Obesity, which is defined as an excessive accumulation of fat mass, is currently one of the leading public health challenges. Obesity is a legitimate public health concern for two reasons: 1) several other diseases are associated with obesity, including diabetes, cardiovascular disease and cancer, and 2) the rates of obesity have increased rapidly over the last forty years with almost one third of the adult population in the U.S. being classified as obese today. The goalof this proposal is to identify signals within fat that regulate fat mass and function,which may lead to the development of novel therapies for the treatment ofobesity and obesity-related pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: Project Narrative Synthetic efficiency is critical to future advances in biology and medicine. Thus, the objective of this research program is to develop new technologies that provide effective solutions for the synthesis of difficult to access or inefficiently prepared biologically relevant compounds. The expected outcome of our program of research are the introduction of new methods based on multifaceted organoboron reagents that leverage their unique chemical attributes to enable novel, stereoselective approaches to such compounds from readily available starting materials.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE / PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses uneven implementation of evidence based cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention guidelines that would prevent more than 50% of annual deaths in middle-aged US adults. Urgent expansion of telehealth due to the COVID-19 pandemic brings rapid changes in primary care visit patterns, posing new barriers to already uneven implementation and making intensive expert-led tailoring of strategies to local barriers even less feasible in practice. This proposal proposes an alternative design adapted from engineering to develop and pilot a configurable toolkit that can potentially increase guideline adherence through selection of implementation strategies matched to local barriers.

PROJECT_TITLE: Adapting Guideline Implementation to Local Environments (AGILE) in Primary Care After Telehealth Expansion

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies are focused on how Factor IIIA produced by mast cells can protect against Group B Streptococcus (GBS) infections and the role of GBS proteins in Factor IIIA mediated entrapment. Our studies will also evaluate how sexual dimorphism in mast cells may favor an immune system that functions to enhance innate immune defense against GBS. These results will be relevant for prevention of bacterial infections and host defense.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this training program is to increase the number of Tanzania physician scientists with rigorous training in patient-oriented HIV clinical investigation. Mwanza Intervention Trials Unit (MITU) and Weill Bugando will establish courses in clinical investigation, advanced biostatistics, and epidemiology to be offered in Mwanza and 15 long-term trainees will conduct mentored research in one of the following HIV research priority areas: HIV prevention and vaccine research, implementation of HIV testing and treatment, women’s health, and management of HIV related opportunistic infections and cardiovascular disease. The goal is to establish MITU/Weill Bugando as a training hub for HIV clinical investigation in East Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative There is a need for a highly sensitive and specific assay that can readily detect active infection by TB, particularly for yourg children in HIV-1 endemic area, who are difficult to diagnose by standard methods. Our previous work has advanced our understanding of the antigenic properties of lipoarabinomannan (LAM), a useful TB biomarker that is secreted in low concentrations into the urine of the great majority of actively infected TB patients. The current proposal will seek to further improve the sensitivity of these reagents, with the goal of developing a highly sensitive and accurate point-of-care for TB infection that is effective in young children, both with and without HIV-1 co-infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The unwanted expression of fear in safe environments is often experienced by individuals suffering from anxiety-related disorders such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). The proposed project will provide first insight into the deep brain neurophysiological signatures of fear regulation in humans with and without anxiety disorders. Findings will characterize oscillatory and single unit activity that mediate physiological response during fear-states and help lay the foundation for future treatments for illnesses marked by debilitating unwanted fear expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  While acute kidney injury (AKI) is common, costly, and associated with adverse outcomes, little is known about risk factors that can be identified when people are healthy where preventive strategies can potentially minimize AKI risk. We will evaluate biomarkers characterizing the functions of kidney tubules and hypothesize that kidney tubule dysfunction predicts AKI events in patients suffering from sepsis, heart failure, or undergoing coronary bypass surgery. This award will thereby provide new insights to potential mechanisms driving AKI events, and provide tools that will allow clinicians to differentiate which patients are at particularly high risk for future AKI events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD) suffer from widespread tissue injuries, including skeletal muscle wasting, and they develop markedly increased blood levels of phosphate. We have found that phosphate can damage skeletal muscle cells in a dish, and that healthy mice receiving a high phosphate diet develop high blood phosphate and a mild form of skeletal muscle injury in the absence of CKD. In this research proposal, we will determine if high blood phosphate is a cause of skeletal muscle injury, by studying how exactly phosphate acts on skeletal muscle cells, whether high phosphate diet - when given over a long period of time - can cause severe skeletal muscle injury, and whether CKD mice receiving a low phosphate diet are protected from skeletal muscle wasting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: With 24.3 million people affected worldwide in 2005 and an estimated rise to nearly 45 million in 2020, Alzheimer's disease is a leading unmet medical need. The goal herein is to optimize oral bioavailability and kinase selectivity of an efficacious proof-of-concept DYRK1A inhibitor and evaluate an optimal candidate in 3xTg-AD and JNPL3 mouse models of AD. Such a molecule may have potential as a disease-modifying therapy through unique dual targeting of tau and amyloid pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Disturbances in gut microbial communities and leaky gut may contribute to inflammation and blood-brain barrier (BBB) dysfunction in HIV. Cannabis may help to normalize dysbiosis and leaky gut, thus reducing inflammation and BBB dysfunction. This project will evaluate differences in dysbiosis, leaky gut, neuroinflammation and BBB dysfunction in PWH and evaluate the therapeutic potential of cannabidiol and tetrahydrocannabinol in a clinical trial of controlled cannabis formulations.

These activities will support improved quality of biospecimens, and expanded access for translational scientists, thus leading to better quality research and identifying appropriate patients for personalized approaches to improved cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) affects >30% of the US population and is projected to become the leading cause of liver-related death in the US within the next 20 years; however, predicting which patients with NAFLD ultimately develop advanced liver disease is challenging and this knowledge gap impairs allocation of resources to the highest-risk patients. Genetics and electronic medical record-derived data may provide additional information that assists with risk stratification, and the research proposed here will incorporate genetics with the electronic medical record to generate predictive models for incident cirrhosis among patients with NAFLD. Ultimately, this project will allow medical providers to better identify which patients with NAFLD are at highest risk of progression and accordingly prioritize them for intensive therapy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ABCD Study consortium uses multimodal brain imaging, cognitive and clinical assessments, bioassays, mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and social functioning in 11,878 9-10 year-olds to be followed over 10 years, to determine the effects of substance use on adolescent brain and cognitive development. This ABCD Research Project Site will follow and assess participants enrolled in the study. These data will be shared with the scientific community to address a comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Biofilm, a protective extracellular-polymeric substance that surrounds bacterial colonies, is associated with more than 80% of microbial infections. This proposed study aims to improve biofilm removal from an infected wound using self-locomotive antimicrobial micro-robots (SLAM) and, in turn, to promote skin regeneration in the wound. If successful, this proposed study would greatly contribute to saving wound patients from death and disability resulting from microbial infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intrahepatic macrophages (Macs), liver sinusoidal endothelial cells (LSECs), and stellate cells (HSCs) can greatly influence the composition of the hepatic microenvironment and development of fibrosis. Therapies targeting these initiators of fibrosis are being investigated in phase II-III clinical trials; however, the underlying hepatic microenvironment and patient variability in these cells and expression of these targets is not being considered prior to treatment. In this retrospective longitudinal study, we will determine which platform (Spectral imaging-Aim1 vs. NanoString-Aim 2) is the most performant for determining potential targets of fibrosis progression and most cost efficient for clinical implementation in the future.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Multiple factors contribute to poor outcomes among minority patients with asthma, including poverty and other social determinants of health (SDoH), environmental exposures, and suboptimal self-management skills. Mobile interventions that facilitate shared decision-making and address modifiable factors in asthma management, such as medication adherence and optimal screening and referrals for SDoH concerns, may play a key role in improving disease outcomes. This proposed project will: 1) adapt, test, and iteratively refine the ASTHMAXcel Voice mobile platform to collect vocal biomarkers and address SDoH; 2) conduct a randomized clinical trial at outpatient sites to compare the adapted and refined ASTHMAXcel Voice intervention to usual care; and 3) evaluate the process of ASTHMAXcel Voice implementation within the outpatient setting.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: A novel patient-facing mobile platform to collect and implement patient-reported outcomes and voice biomarkers in underserved adult patients with asthma

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: For more than a century, radiation has been used as an effective therapeutic modality for many different cancers and other diseases, and is clinically indicated for more than half of all cancer patients. However, it has long been known that ionizing radiation can also promote cancer in otherwise normal tissue. While it is rare for an individual to develop a radiation- induced cancer, actual estimates of this rate vary widely according to different studies. Moreover, we have a poor understanding of individualized risk and, in particular, the role that personal genetics may play in determining relative risk of developing a radiation-induced cancer. My research aims to 1) identify a high-confidence cohort of Veterans receiving radiation therapy, 2) characterize second and secondary malignancy rates within the VA, and 3) quantify genetic risk factors of radiation-induced secondary malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE The molecular mechanisms that drive myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) progression and responses to hypomethylating agent (HMA) therapy are poorly understood. Our single-cell RNA-sequencing studies of MDS patients with progressive cytopenias have demonstrated that MDS hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) exhibit unique gene expression profiles and splicing patterns from normal controls, with responders and non-responders to HMA therapy exhibiting differences in gene expression and splicing. We will leverage novel single cell sequencing technologies to simultaneously evaluate the transcriptional and genetic states of MDS HSCs and committed progenitors to elucidate the molecular basis of disease progression and therapeutic responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Circadian rhythms control a wide variety of processes in all eukaryotes, including linkages to the cell cycle, human metabolism and cancer. The fundamental organization of the clock as consisting of two or more, linked autoregulatory feedback loops is shared among all model systems, but the individual molecular players often vary among the kingdoms. Here inter- and intracellular mechanisms of circadian clock control in Arabidopsis are investigated, with potential relevance to other eukaryotic oscillatory systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis is one of the commonest causes of death from infections worldwide, but no new vaccines for TB have been introduced in nearly 100 years. Despite this gap, little is known about how the lung environment shapes the immune response to M. tuberculosis, the organism that causes tuberculosis. By the end of this proposal, we will understand how respiratory mucins, the first proteins that M. tuberculosis encounters in the lung, influences susceptibility and severity to tuberculosis, and may identify novel treatment and vaccine strategies

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This application is for the position of Research Career Scientist for Dr. L. Ashley Cowart, Ph.D. Dr. Cowart is an internationally recognized expert in lipid metabolism and its contribution to health and disease. Her research focuses on obesity and related illnesses including type 2 diabetes, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, and heart failure. Studies show that over 75% of veterans of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars are overweight or obese. Furthermore, obesity is highly linked to post traumatic stress disorder. Dr. Cowart has recently begun new work to identify novel lipid that could predict the risk of post-traumatic stress disorder in veterans who experienced traumatic brain injuries while deployed. Dr. Cowart has been VA funded since 2005 and is currently funded through December 2025. In addition to VA funding, she has served as PI on 2 NIH R01 grants, with funding through June 2025. This award will provide stability and continuity as Dr. Cowart furthers her overall research program which extends well beyond the proposed work in the current Merit award.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NEW JERSEY HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Preclinical experimental model systems, which accurately depict human cancer, is critical in translating laboratory findings to the clinic. We discovered aberrant GRM1 expression in a large number of late-stage melanoma patients. However, current melanoma animal models do not mimic this common genetic alteration. We, therefore, propose to use our unique experimental mouse models reflecting this cancer-driving modification and focus in melanoma brain metastasis that remains a clinically challenge aspect of this disease. A better understanding of the characteristics of brain metastases is essential to develop more effective therapeutic strategies to treat or prevent brain metastases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The goal of the Chen lab’s VA-funded research is to curtail the grave consequences of traumatic brain injury (TBI) and ischemic stroke on our veterans’ health and wellbeing. To meet this goal, our research team seeks to understand the regulatory role of immune cells in the progression of brain injury and functional recovery after TBI or stroke. We seek to identify the mechanisms underlying the double-edged sword of microglial activation and brain infiltration of circulating immune cells. We have successfully developed numerous strategies to harness the tissue-restorative power of immune cells while also tempering inflammation-induced secondary injuries. We will comprehensively test these strategies using state-of-the art assessments of long-term neurological functions in both male and female subjects. This molecular, cellular, and systems-level evidence will be valuable for future development of new therapies to minimize veteran disabilities, promote veteran rehabilitation, and improve quality of life after TBI or stroke.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Dr. Zaika's research focuses on the molecular analyses of esophageal and gastric adenocarcinomas. The incidence of gastroesophageal reflux disease, the main risk factor for esophageal adenocarcinoma, is significantly higher in our veterans' population compared to general population. Furthermore, recent studies of U.S soldiers deployed abroad have shown that the incidence of H. pylori infection is approximately three-fold higher than that of U.S. military recruits serving at home, which represents a major increase in gastric cancer risk. Taken together, the molecular and translational research activities of Dr. Zaika's laboratory are highly relevant to our Veterans' health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Age-related neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) are the most common cause of morbidity in the Veteran population. With no prevention or treatment, individuals with neurodegenerative conditions could reach 11-16 million by 2050. The Head laboratory investigates how caveolin (Cav), a cholesterol binding and scaffolding protein within membrane/lipid rafts (MLRs), regulates synaptic signaling, mitochondrial function, and neuroplasticity in human neurons derived from iPSCs and in animal models of neurodegeneration such as AD and ALS. Recent work from the Head group showed that his patented Cav gene therapy preserves cognitive function in AD mice and improves motor function and extends survival in ALS mice. The findings from this research exhibit strong therapeutic implications for Veterans afflicted with neurodegenerative conditions. Dr. Head’s long-term goal is to translate this gene therapy to the clinical setting to treat Veterans suffering from neurodegenerative conditions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a common and debilitating condition among Veterans. While evidence-based treatments have been developed for PTSD, not all patients respond to treatment. Understanding the factors that underlie PTSD symptoms will inform the development of more targeted treatments. Sleep problems are nearly universal in PTSD, as insomnia and nightmares are some of the most commonly reported symptoms following trauma exposure. Preliminary evidence suggests disrupted sleep, especially fragmented Rapid Eye Movement (REM) sleep, impair emotion regulation processes, which may in turn make daytime trauma-related symptoms more severe. However, the potential link between sleep and emotion regulation has not been well explored in clinical groups. This study will investigate the link between disrupted sleep and emotion regulation in Veterans with trauma histories, which will lead to a better mechanistic understanding of PTSD and thus inform the development of better interventions for Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The lung has a great capacity for healing after illness due to stem cells that repair the distal lung. Some individuals are more vulnerable to lung injury and poor healing, and repair weakens with age. In our work to understand lung repair, we have found that cell metabolism is important to lung healing, and we are working to understand pathways that control cell metabolism after injury as opportunities for enhancing lung repair.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES A. HALEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Dr. Subhra Mohapatra is a recognized leader in research on the molecular and cellular mechanism of Inflammation, which is the central feature of most chronic human diseases, that afflict millions of Veterans. Her major research emphasis has been on using nano- and - biotechnology-based diagnostic and therapeutic approaches to advance the treatment of diverse human diseases, which have already led to clinical studies and/or products in the marketplace. Thus, her Lab at the James A. Haley VA Hospital, Tampa has discovered a few drug targets and packaged them in nanoformulations that are expected to advance the treatment for COVID-19 virus infection-induced lung disease, traumatic brain injury and other neurocognitive diseases, and a variety of cancers including lung, breast, and colorectal cancers, some of which are under clinical evaluation for efficacy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Alcohol use disorder (AUD) and stress-related disorders such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) constitute a significant health concern for our Veterans. Given that the prevalence of AUD and PTSD comorbidity is especially high in Veterans, the need to better understand how stress interacts with alcohol is critical for developing more effective treatments for this significant health problem. The Becker research program utilizes novel models involving stress and alcohol exposure, along with cutting-edge experimental tools to probe neural mechanisms and brain circuits underlying enhanced alcohol drinking, relapse vulnerability, and cognitive impairments associated with stress and chronic alcohol exposure. The ultimate goal is to provide new insights for developing novel therapeutic interventions that will aid in treatment for individuals suffering from stress and alcohol related disorders - an especially important and clinically relevant problem for our Veteran patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Dr. Richards' research examines genetic factors that influence not only population risk, but individual risk, for the unhealthy use of alcohol, methamphetamine and other drugs, including opioids. In 2012, the US National Drug Control Strategy identified active military personnel, Veterans, and their families as populations requiring special support to deal with their drug use problems. In 2022, the same publication reported that the VA is the first organization to implement an evidence-based contingency management “incentives” intervention on a wide-scale that has shown some efficacy. Considerable evidence suggests that mental health disorders are best served by combining psychological and pharmacological interventions. Dr. Richards' research program focuses on genetic and genomic factors that impact initial and continued substance use, as well as the consequences of use. A major goal is to identify individual risk and response mechanisms that could lead to personalized medical advances for addiction and greatly benefit Veteran's health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Jie Fan, M.D., has been working at the VA Pittsburgh Healthcare System (VAPHS) since 2003 and is a VA Research Career Scientist, a Director of the Surgical Research Program, a Vice-Chair of the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee, a Mentor of VA Career Development Awardees, and a tenured Full Professor of Surgery and Immunology in the Departments of Surgery and Immunology at the University of Pittsburgh. Dr. Fan is a Principal Investigator who has been continuously funded by VA merit review grants since 2007 and NIH research grants (R01, P50, and R56) since 2005. Dr. Fan's research seeks to answer how trauma and sepsis patients develop severe systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) and acute lung injury (ALI), the common causes of death in veterans. Dr. Fan's research is geared toward providing a new understanding of the mechanisms underlying SIRS and ALI and developing novel treatments for SIRS and ALI.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: SOUTH TEXAS VETERANS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Parkinson's disease (PD) is the second most prevalent age-related neurodegenerative disorder, after Alzheimer's disease, affecting up to 5% of the population aged 65 – 85 years. Veterans are at increased risk for PD because the veteran population is older than the United States population as a whole and because veterans are more likely to have been exposed to toxic environmental agents during deployment. Current therapies only treat the symptoms of the disease and do prevent or delay its progression. A growing body of evidence from our lab and others has implicated impaired removal of toxic biogenic aldehydes in affected brain areas. Our studies will help to identify drugs that can remove or prevent the accumulation of biogenic aldehydes and alleviate the burden of Parkinson disease in veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES A. HALEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Trauma is a major cause of mortality and morbidity in American soldiers and veterans. As a typical type of trauma, thermal injury results from flame/chemical burns in combat or anti-terrorist actions. Despite the improved critical care and wound management, posttraumatic complications remain a life-threatening problem that causes extended hospital stay and charges. The gut plays an important role in the development of multiple organ complications following a severe burn. Gut barrier failure contributes to systemic inflammatory syndrome and sepsis by serving as the major site of blood leakage and bacteria translocation. The mechanisms of leaky guts are poorly understood. This study provides a comprehensive evaluation of the molecular pathways leading to gut hyperpermeability during burn. This research work has the potential to impact the development of surgical or medical interventions against gut barrier injury in VA patients with trauma or inflammatory bowel disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: SOUTHERN ARIZONA VA HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a neurodegenerative disease and currently there is no cure. Veterans are at a higher risk of being affected with the disorder, thus ALS has been listed as a disease entitled to presumptive service connection. The PI’s Merit project is to use well-defined genetic models to determine the mechanisms by which mutations in the RNA binding protein FUS disrupt protein biosynthesis and RNA metabolism and induce downstream toxicity and neuronal death. The results from his project will not only provide critical insights into the pathophysiology of ALS but will also identify novel targets for therapeutic developments. Since the relocation to Tucson, the PI has taken new responsibilities as the site PI of the nationwide VA Biorepository Brain Bank (BBB). As the only ALS biorepository for veterans across the U.S., VA BBB is a critical resource for the entire ALS research community. The support from the Research Career Scientist program will enable the PI to make continuous contributions to the healthcare of veterans, particularly those afflicted with ALS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In the era of genomic medicine, we can accelerate the development of diagnostics and therapeutics through data science tools that equip scientists with the means to make sense of genomic datasets. Given the critical role of data visualization in making discovery more eﬃcient and communication more eﬀective, we are proposing to develop an innovative grammar-driven framework for interactive visualization of both bulk and single-cell genomics data. The design of the framework and the tools built on it will be guided by user-driven development approaches to ensure that they cater to experimentalists, data analysts, and software developers.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: NARRATIVE Dr. Ngan F. Huang's translational research program focuses on cardiovascular disease and traumatic muscle injury, both of which are highly relevant in Veteran populations. The goal of her research program is to develop novel therapeutic strategies to improve tissue regeneration and functional restoration to cardiovascular and skeletal muscle diseases/injuries experienced by Veterans. Active research awards from the Department of Veteran Affairs and National Institutes of Health seek to develop engineered tissues with spatially patterned biomaterials that direct cell fate and tissue function, the engineering of vascularized tissues for improved skeletal muscle tissue survival and function, and the development of synthetic hydrogels with controllable mechanical properties that modulate the survival of transplanted tissues for treatment of peripheral arterial disease. If successful, these studies will impact Veteran care by reducing mortality and improving the quality of life.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Schizophrenia and related psychotic disorders are a major cause of disability worldwide. Current treatments can improve schizophrenia symptoms such as hallucinations and delusions, but do not affect the symptoms most closely correlated with real-world functioning (cognitive and negative symptoms). An improved understanding of how neuroinflammation contributes to the pathophysiology of schizophrenia could lead to a) novel treatments for cognitive and negative symptoms, b) identification of biomarkers that could help guide future treatment, and c) foundation for a personalized medicine approach to the treatment of schizophrenia, including utilization of anti-inflammatory and antioxidant treatment. These developments may, in turn, improve the vocational, housing, and social situation of Veterans and others with schizophrenia. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative The locus coeruleus is the brain’s major source of the neuromodulator norepinephrine and is one of the first regions to be affected by the accumulation of abnormal tau, a neuropathological hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease. We propose individuals combat insults to locus coeruleus by increasing rates of norepinephrine synthesis. We will investigate the relationship between norepinephrine synthesis capacity and underlying locus coeruleus structure, and the possible role of elevated norepinephrine synthesis in cognitive resilience and resistance to the spread of tau pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative For this work, we will employ a variety of biochemical and biophysical tools to elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which two different protein families transport ions across biological membranes. Specifically, KdpFABC actively pumps potassium into bacterial cells in order to maintain turgor pressure, whereas YiiP exports zinc and belongs to a large class of proteins that control the distribution of transition metal ions. Our goal is to combine structural studies with functional analyses to develop a comprehensive understanding of the reaction cycle governing the transport process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Overall: Project Narrative The UCLA-CDU CFAR is located in metropolitan Los Angeles, which is a major epicenter for the AIDS epidemic, and is the most populous county in the nation, ranking second in the number of documented cases of advanced HIV disease. The UCLA-CDU CFAR seeks to catalyze and expand HIV research by providing the infrastructure to connect, support and enhance the capacity of investigators affiliated with UCLA and CDU. The UCLA-CDU CFAR will strengthen and amplify the impact of existing research activities and launch new partnerships across Los Angeles and globally through our focus on three themes: we will STOP HIV by preventing new HIV infections (Prevention), reducing morbidity among people living with HIV (Treatment) and developing strategies for eradication (ART-free Remission).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The goal of this project is to characterize the molecular, cellular and pathophysiological mechanisms of a class of renal cancers driven by the Folliculin-TFEB signaling pathway. We will test the hypothesis that dysregulated mTORC1 is a key driver of renal cancers triggered by Folliculin deletion and TFEB translocation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: This project will systematically identify substrates and functions of calcineurin, which regulates many processes in humans by mediating Ca2+-dependent changes in protein phosphorylation. Misregulation of calcineurin underlies immune disorders, diabetes, cancer, heart disease and epilepsy. This research studies calcineurin function at a biochemical and structural level and will provide new insights into its actions in healthy and diseased cells, thus uncovering new therapeutic approaches to control its activities selectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Mechanical signaling is critical in development and immune function, and its dysfunction has been implicated in numerous malignancies, including cancer and cardiomyopathies. This project aims to reveal how forces alter the structure of actin filaments, the major load-bearing element of the cell. Our studies will establish basic principles of how forces alter protein structure to transmit mechanical signals, which in the long-term will guide the development of therapeutics targeting these processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent studies indicate that use of methamphetamine among those using opioids (coined the “twin epidemics) is on the rise. This study seeks to understand the impact of methamphetamine use on drug-related harms (injection, overdose, HIV/HCV/STI) and SUD treatment enrollment in rural areas that are enmeshed in the opioid epidemic. To this end, we will collect prospective data from two extant, NIDA-funded cohorts of rural people who use drugs and this proposed renewal will address gaps in our knowledge of the twin epidemics of methamphetamine and opioid use and provide data that are integral to addressing drug-related harms in the rural U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will advance the understanding of the physiological mechanisms of weakness in older adults. Weakness is a major risk factor for the development of physical disability in old age. As such, this application is highly relevant to NIH’s mission of extending healthy living and reducing the burdens of physical disability in old age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The progressive myoclonus epilepsies (EPM) are a class of genetically-determined neurological disorders defined by onset in previously healthy individuals of tremor, seizures, and ataxia, advancing relentlessly to loss of ambulation, chronic epilepsy and myoclonus, and early death. EPM is without cure or disease-altering treatment, yet advances in neurogenetics may inform novel therapeutic approaches. Here, we have generated a new experimental animal model of an EPM and propose to define cellular and circuit mechanisms of disease and treat the disorder using targeted pharmacotherapy that may be translatable to the clinical arena.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The major goal of the current application is to understand functions of posttranslational lysine modifications in the regulation of chromatin, polyubiquitination functions, and cyclic GMP-AMP synthase. The project is relevant to public health and the NIH’s mission in promoting health and combating diseases because it will reveal the molecular basis of chromatin and cyclic GMP-AMP synthase regulation by posttranslational lysine modifications and assist in the identification of therapeutics that target chromatin and cyclic GMP-AMP synthase modifications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proper wiring of the cerebral cortex in humans is essential for the performance of a variety of complex behaviors. Disrupted cortical wiring leads to a number of neurodevelopmental disorders including autism spectrum disorders and intellectual disability. Understanding genetic programs that dictate how neurons and astrocytes coordinate their activities during circuit formation will provide important insight for the development of therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this proposal is to determine, at the circuit and systems level, the role of visual familiarity- evoked oscillations in predictive behavior in wild type and Fmr1 KO mice, a model of Fragile X Syndrome. We will perform extracellular recordings with Neuropixels probes in V1 and ACC of awake mice, use optogenetics in combination with behavior to determine the relationship between oscillations and visual learning. We will map the underlying neural circuit responsible for these oscillations and impaired in Fmr1 KO mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Our proposed work continues to be fundamentally basic research on the cholesterol-dependent cytolysins but which often leads to translational applications (i.e., vaccines) and supports the efforts in the field of pathogenesis where these toxins contribute to disease. These studies have led us to the discovery of a large class of ancient CDC relatives that have spread throughout the Bacteria kingdom and are present in many major species of the human microbiome. Finally, these studies will reveal the molecular mechanism of a unique class of anti-bacterial toxins, which could potentially be used in therapies for infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE K+ channels are membrane proteins that allow rapid and exquisite selective flow of K+ ions across the cell membrane that is crucial to generate chemical and electrical activities in living cells, and their dysfunction lead to many human diseases. To completely understand the behavior of ion channels, dynamic views of the structures are essential to fill the gap between crystal/CryoEM structures and single ion channel current analyses. The structural dynamics of potassium channel proteins presents an exciting and emerging field of study which will provide new understanding of the fundamental basis of channel function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One in 151 women in the United States carry the FMR1 premutation, a genetic abnormality that is associated with substantially increased risk for disease that appears to worsen at older ages. This longitudinal investigation of mother carriers of the FMR1 premutation aims to define age-related stability of symptoms in midlife and early old age, associated functional limitations, and the role of biological and environmental factors. Delineating the trajectory and predictors of age-related decline will inform critical age periods for prevention, risk factors, and the eventual development of strategies to improve age-related outcomes for both carrier mothers and their children with fragile X syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative When cells in a developing animal grow to form tissues and organs, they often do so in response to concentration gradients of chemical signals. The mechanisms by which these molecular messages move and are received has been in question, but research proposed in this application explores the structure and function of cytonemes - thin, finger-like protrusions from cells that play a key role in this process. Our findings will have important implications for cell-cell signalling in normal development and in many disease contexts, including viral infections and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Myocardial infarction (MI) often results in heart failure due to gradual loss of healthy cardiomyocytes and increased fibrosis. This proposal aims to determine how Pitx2 signaling protect cardiomyocytes after myocardial infarction and regulate the fibrotic signaling during myocardial remodeling. Improved understanding of Pitx2 signaling will provide alternative therapeutic strategies for treating MI.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: NARRATIVE Good glycemic control is important for optimal health and prevention of acute and chronic complications among people living with diabetes, but food insecurity is a serious barrier to achieving good glycemic control, particularly among underrepresented racial/ethnic groups. This is the first longitudinal study that will characterize how food insecurity affects glycemic control measured by continuous glucose monitoring and the impact it has on health care utilization on a day-to-day basis in youth and young adults with type 1 and type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The overall mission of this proposal is to improve sepsis patient care by identifying and harnessing new mechanisms in the body’s own resolution phase of inflammation that can be used to control the excessive inflammatory responses that occur in sepsis. These include experiments focused on the specialized pro- resolving mediators (SPMs), their new autocoid pathways producing potent cys-SPM, and SPM mechanisms we’ve discovered to permit their use in human resolution physiology and pharmacology. The potential for resolution mechanisms as a new means to stratify sepsis and other maladies could diminish the consequences of prolonged uncontrolled infectious inflammation, organ damage and shorten recovery time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: A cornerstone of several common therapies for human diseases is the use of a vein as a conduit to increase blood flow such as the arteriovenous fistula, the preferred access for hemodialysis. However, fistulae have extremely high rates of both early and late failure, and these poor clinical results lead to patient suffering and extensive expenditure of precious healthcare dollars and other resources for additional re-do procedures and surgery. The work to be accomplished within this proposal addresses the knowledge gap in the biology of venous remodeling that has created a serious unmet need for novel approaches to enhance venous adaptation to the fistula environment and enable successful long-term use of venous conduits in both women and men.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The integration of evidence-based screening and suicide prevention delivered by community health workers into pediatric primary care has the potential to address mental health service gaps experienced by Latinx youth and their families, reduce suicidal ideation and behavior, and prevent youth suicide. Systems-level approaches to the identification and management of suicidal ideation and behavior developed in this study may be broadly generalizable to populations of underserved youth from families with limited English proficiency and in settings with limited mental health service workforce capacity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE In this proposal, we seek to improve the outcome of patients with relapsed/refractory NHL who have failed CAR19 T-cell therapy. We identified CD70 as a novel therapeutic target after CAR19 T-cell failure. Here, we propose a Phase I/II clinical trial to test the safety and efficacy of CD70 targeting CAR-NK cells in this patient population. In addition, we propose to conduct IND enabling studies to develop the next-generation CD70 targeting CAR-NK cells by silencing the immune checkpoint CIS to enhance their potency and metabolic fitness. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Young people transitioning from the foster care system are at elevated risk for a range of mental health diagnoses, but they are often less prepared to manage mental health challenges and more likely to have negative perspectives on help- seeking, increasing the risk of unmet needs as service use rapidly declines following the exit from foster care. We are pilot testing an indicated prevention intervention to improve coping self-efficacy and help-seeking attitudes in ways that lead to adaptive functioning, including social support-seeking and mental health treatment engagement. Our remotely- delivered group-based intervention approach is a broadly scalable enhancement to existing foster youth transition services, and is likely transferable to similar service-involved youth populations during the transition to adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: A commonality in childhood speech disorders, like autism spectrum disorders, primary apraxia, or stutter, is the inability to properly coordinate the movement of the ~100 muscles to speak. Here, our goal is to identify and characterize if a small collection of neurons is specialized to harmonize verbalizations with breathing. This work will provide a platform for future studies to understand the brain-wide systems that create vocalizations and how they are changed in various speech pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Primary Progressive Aphasia (PPA) is a dementia that undermines word finding and the ability to communicate through the asymmetric degeneration of the language-dominant (usually left) hemisphere of the brain. It can be caused by multiple entities, including Alzheimer's disease (AD) and several forms of frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD). This project, based on a unique group of longitudinally evaluated PPA participants, will explore disease-specific anatomic, cellular and molecular aspects of PPA so that each patient can be approached through principles of personalized medicine that address not only symptoms but also underlying disease types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Ischemic acute kidney injury (AKI) is a common and often a life-threatening consequence of reduced kidney blood flow during cardiac surgery caused by NPM, a key protein that promotes regulated cell death and tissue injury in the human kidney. We will use an integrated approach to characterize the structure-function relationship (SAR) of human NPM and Bax to identify novel targets for drug interventions with non-toxic, injectable peptides. Our goal is to prevent and treat regulated cell death that causes AKI during cardiac surgery, an insult that resembles experimental ischemia-reperfusion injury in which NPM and Bax are lethal co- toxins.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to enhance the value to the research community of the structural birth defect data on the Kids First cohort with chromosome 18 deletions. We propose to review and abstract the existing repository of scanned medical records and survey data and recontact the participating families to acquire any additional or more recent information. These data will then be mapped to Human Phenotype Ontology to ensure harmonization with the larger database. The added precision, detail and interoperability of these data will help advance the discovery of the genetic causes of these structural birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Signaling molecules, such as serotonin (5-HT), which do not cross cell membranes, must activate receptors on cell surfaces to which receptors are transported from their intracellular site of biosynthesis. Evidence suggests that insertion of the 5-HT4 receptor subtype into cell surface membranes in the brain is critically dependent on an interaction with another molecule, p11, which functions as an adaptor. We plan to test three hypotheses strongly supported by our preliminary data, (i) that the p11-5-HT4 interaction is necessary for insertion of 5-HT4 receptors into cell surface membranes of intestinal nerve and epithelial cells, is thus (ii) essential for 5- HT4-stimulation of enteric neuronal development and function, and, (iii) when defective, underlies the frequent co-existence of 5-HT4-mediated brain and gut disorders, including constipation and depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Research Narrative  As access to cannabis has increased dramatically, it is imperative to understand how to approach cannabis use among individuals with alcohol use disorder (AUD) who also use cannabis. The proposed research will compare the effects of a harm reduction intervention (instruction to switch from a high THC product to a low THC/high CBD) product versus a no intervention control condition (continue to use THC like you normally do) in a sample of cannabis users who wish to reduce or quit drinking. If the hypotheses of the proposed research are supported, the dissemination of the research would have an immediate public health impact by educating individuals and health care providers about the relative benefits of switching from high potency THC products to a product with lower THC and higher CBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE) Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE, lupus) commonly have injury to their kidneys, called lupus nephritis. We and others have found that lymphocytes enter the kidney in lupus nephritis, and promote the injury that occurs therein. We now propose to determine the factors that contribute to the damage caused by kidney lymphocytes in mice and humans with lupus, and how we can modify them genetically and therapeutically to potentially prevent lupus nephritis, studies that could lead to new treatments for SLE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excess adrenal steroid production is increasingly recognized as a common cause of hypertension and cardiovascular disease, with medical therapies that remain suboptimal and biological mechanisms that remain incompletely defined. We have developed novel methods for deeply interrogating the proteome and bioenergetics of adrenal mitochondria and have obtained preliminary data for several redox pathways that are uniquely enriched in adrenal mitochondria. The proposed research will test the concept that dysfunction of adrenal mitochondrial redox pathways can be a pathogenic driver of dysregulated aldosterone and cortisol production relevant for common hypertension and cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although most G-protein coupled receptors are activated by contact with their neurotransmitters at the cell surface, new data suggest that some receptors, such as the metabotropic glutamate mGlu5 receptor, are primarily expressed on intracellular membranes where they trigger distinct and longer lasting signaling responses. Recently, we created genetic models to test membrane-restricted mGlu5 signaling in motivated learning and memory assays in vivo. Because mGlu5 has been linked to disorders of intellectual disability, anxiety, and depression, these studies have enormous potential for the discovery of novel therapies that improve outcomes for people with these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Each year nearly 2 million individuals become infected with HIV-1 and with no universal cure, development of an effective vaccine to prevent HIV-1 infection remains a major goal. A significant hurdle for the development of a successful vaccination strategies has been the lack of tractable and affordable preclinical model system. This application will leverage the combined expertise of three PIs (Drs. Goettel, Almodovar, and Georgiev) to employ a newly developed advanced immune humanized murine system to evaluate the antibody response to HIV-1 (R5) virus infection as well as vaccination protocols using established and novel HIV-1 immunization approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the global water crisis is among the most urgent issues of our time, little attention has been given to the myriad ways in which problems with water access, use, and stability (i.e., water insecurity) can influence health beyond waterborne diseases; this R03 therefore examines the underexplored relationships between water insecurity and nutritional, physiological, and mental health. Household water insecurity experiences were measured in a nationally representative health and nutrition survey for the first time in 2021 (Mexico's renowned Encuesta Nacional de Salud y Nutrición); these data will permit the quantification of the role of water insecurity and food insecurity in key health outcomes, including dietary intake, adiposity, hypertension, diabetes, and depression. The proposed work will demonstrate the utility of the measurement of water insecurity in other large surveys (including in the US) and identify previously unrecognized but modifiable drivers of health inequities, thereby helping public health efforts to address root causes of poor mental and physical health that hinder resilience, economic growth, and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE     Despite  recent  advances  in  immunotherapy  that  lead  to  substantial  increase  of  cancer  patient  survival,  still  a  great portion of patients are not responsive to the treatment, underscoring the need for a deeper understanding  of how tumor cells and immune system interact with each other. In this project, the proposed doctoral research  aims to elucidate the molecular mechanisms via which cellular senescence triggers immune surveillance against  liver cancer in vivo, with the ultimate goal of identifying new strategies to pharmacologically mimic or enhance  these effects. The proposed postdoctoral research will investigate NK cell- based mechanisms of immune escape  during  extrahepatic  metastasis  of  liver  tumors  to  lung,  which  could  offer  novel  insights  into  re- activating  this  innate immunity to target this end- stage cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many biological processes are controlled or modulated by the membrane potential via structures called voltage sensors, which are critical in the generation and propagation of nerve and muscle impulses, playing a fundamental role in excitability. This proposal aims at the understanding of the physical bases at the molecular detail of sensing voltage and how these sensors couple their action to open the ionic channels, using a combination of state-of-the-art techniques, that correlate structure and function of voltage-sensitive sodium and potassium channels. These studies have relevance in the knowledge of the basic mechanisms of the nervous system function, in skeletal muscle and heart contraction in health and, also, in a variety of diseases such as heart arrhythmias, myotonic muscle and epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health as it addresses a direct link between defects in human ribosome assembly and the resulting human blood disorders. Ribosomes are the molecular machines responsible for protein synthesis in all human cells. As genetic diseases associated with ribosomal protein coding genes are linked to abnormalities in the synthesis of ribosomes, this research program will be essential to understand the molecular underpinnings of these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to vestibular science and the general public because age-related vestibular hypofunction is a major contributor to poor balance, falls, and other adverse health outcomes. In this investigation we propose to: 1) assess the preliminary efficacy of a novel intervention system for improving vestibular function and dizziness in community-dwelling older adults, 2) assess the safety and feasibility of the this system, and 3) assess the acceptability and implementation potential of this system, prior to a large-scale, R01-level investigation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell growth triggers human cell division at the G1/S transition before DNA is replicated, but our molecular understanding of this process is poor and largely based on cell culture studies. Here, we propose to determine how cell growth, through the DNA-to-cytoplasm ratio, triggers the G1/S transition in mouse hepatocytes in vivo. Determining how cell growth triggers cell division will impact our understanding of developmental biology and cancer, where this it is misregulated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC), the most common form of kidney cancer, is characterized predominantly by alterations to the VHL gene which often results in the activation of a cellular protein called HIF (hypoxia inducible factor). The altered VHL protein exists in one of three different forms, and it was recently discovered that one of these forms is a potent inducer of ccRCC metastases. Following up on exciting preliminary observations, we will investigate how this tumor-promoting VHL isoform communicates with other cells in the tumor microenvironment, enabling the onset and spread of ccRCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults need transportation options that maximize their physical activity and social participation, regardless of disability status. This research will inform future planning and policy by highlighting components of accessible public transit systems which are associated with physical activity and social participation among older adults with disabilities. The knowledge gained will inform whether accessible and inclusive public transit options are a potential avenue to maximize health equity among older adults with disabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed Leadership Award will synergize Dr. Rabinovici’s programmatic contributions in ADRD biomarkers with Dr. Possin’s contributions to clinical diagnosis and care models. The research program will validate cutting- edge tablet-based cognitive assessments and biomarkers to reimagine Alzheimer’s diagnosis that is precise, inclusive, and scalable, and that will identify appropriate candidates for disease modifying therapies. Supported by a multi-disciplinary team of co-investigators and consultants, and by leveraging the resources of the UCSF Alzheimer’s Disease Research Center and New IDEAS, the PIs will foster significant growth and depth of their mentoring program of diverse mentees to tackle the major challenges in the ADRD field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: A method that could improve the accuracy of MRI for brain tumors would be of great clinical benefit. Towards this end, we have developed a new class of pulse sequences, called T1 Relaxation-Enhanced Steady-State (T1RESS), that greatly improves the visibility of tumors in contrast-enhanced MRI by differentially suppressing the signal intensity of non-enhancing background tissues while maintaining the signal intensity of contrast- enhancing lesions. The primary hypothesis of this five-year grant proposal is that T1RESS will significantly improve the sensitivity for small brain metastases compared with existing MRI pulse sequences, while a secondary hypothesis is that the twofold improvement in tumor-to-brain contrast obtained with uT1RESS can be used to enable a substantial reduction in gadolinium-based contrast agent dosage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative APOE4 is the major genetic risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease (AD), however we do not fully understand how APOE4-driven endolysosomal trafficking defects influence disease risk in human AD brain cells. The goal of this project is to understand the molecular mechanisms of APOE4 lipid-endolysosomal trafficking defect in human astrocytes and identify targets that can reverse the phenotype. Human iPSC-based model application and the knowledge gained from this proposal will be essential to the development of novel AD therapeutic modalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies in animal models and humans support the notion that disease-causing mutations for frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and Alzheimer's disease (AD) may play critical roles in neurodevelopment. By studying children carrying mutations causing FTD or AD, this proposal will characterize and identify how early disease- specific neural circuit differences arise. These findings will reveal important insights into the underlying biology of these diseases and will determine how early biomarker trajectories in genetic FTD and AD diverge from trajectories in noncarriers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Fms-like tyrosine kinase 3 (FLT3) mutations are some of the most common mutations in acute myeloid leukemia. Phenylalanine 691 to leucine (F691L) mutations in AML occur following targeted FLT3 inhibitor therapy, making these types of AML especially difficult to treat. The proposed research will explore the mechanisms underlying this F691L mutation, aiming to target this exquisitely resistant form of cancer genetically and pharmacologically, with a goal of identifying novel targeted therapies against this high-risk group of leukemias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Pediatric dysarthria is a disorder of speech movement that causes reduced speech intelligibility and negatively impacts quality of life for over half of children with cerebral palsy (CP), yet there is little evidence to guide its assessment and treatment. This research will compare the efficacy of a local, emphatic stress based speech modification strategy to two previously-studied global strategies (i.e., “loud” speech and slow rate) for 25 children with dysarthria secondary to cerebral palsy, and will identify mechanisms underlying intelligibility gains from these strategies. Results of this research will provide essential information about the “key ingredients” to successful use of speech modification strategies that can be leveraged to improve effectiveness of speech intervention for children with dysarthria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Malaria kills more than 400 million people in Africa each year, with the majority of fatalities occurring in children under the age of 5 in areas south of the Sahara. Control efforts have been scaled up in many parts of sub-Saharan Africa. However, these efforts are being hampered by resistance to commonly used insecticide for vector control. Results of these studies will help manage insecticide resistance and malaria control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Large-scale volumetric voltage imaging is a powerful method in understanding brain function, yet posts profound technical challenges. We propose a mesoscopic oblique plane microscopy (Meso-OPM) to address the challenges and achieve >1.8 mm2 field-of-view, >0.1 mm depth penetration, and 1 KHz volume rate in imaging Voltron voltage indicators. We will test our technique in Zebra fish larvae, for the first time, offering recording across the whole nervous system to dissecting neural circuitry responsible for motor behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Affecting up to 10% of the population, melanoma continues to be a deadly form of cancer for many patients despite recent advances in immunotherapies. A group of melanomas that harbor NF1 or SPRED1 mutations have particularly poor outcomes and developing new therapies will require a more thorough understanding of the affected signaling pathways. At the end of this research we expect to better understand the range of additional oncogenic mutations that cooperate with NF1 or SPRED1 loss and how these melanomas will respond to drugs that act on the RTK–RAS-MAPK pathway.
