IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The current system of liver transplant allocation assigns candidates a score based on laboratory testing (known as the Model for End Stage Liver Disease, or MELD) that is meant to estimate the risk of dying while awaiting transplant, and patients who are thought to have a higher risk of mortality than reflected in their calculated MELD score are assigned a higher exception or allocation MELD score that is meant to better reflect risk. A critical flaw in this policy is that it does not account for regional variation in social determinants of health and access to care which likely have significant effects on waitlist mortality; rather, the risk associated with a given MELD score is assumed to be the same everywhere in the nation. Understanding and accounting for the role of geographic location in the risk of waitlist mortality has the potential to ameliorate this flaw and inform a more equitable liver transplant allocation system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We now know that effective tuberculosis vaccines can be developed with defined antigens, properly adjuvanted, and three decades of antigen discovery has made it possible to focus on a short list of vaccine candidates. We have developed a third generation RNA vaccine platform capable of inducing potent T cells in small animals and non-human primates, as well as new formulation/delivery technologies that enable a new generation of RNA adjuvants. We will test the RNA vaccine platform as well as RNA-based adjuvants, alone and in combination, to optimize protective immunity against tuberculosis, with an emphasis on mucosal immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many cell types have hundreds of important structures (organelles) that are arranged into complex patterns (for example the respiratory epithelial cells carry fields of motile cilia and the cells in the inner ear have rows of sensory stereocilia). These patterns are physiologically important but the mechanisms of their formation are largely unknown. Here we will be using the protist model that assembles unusually complex patterns, Tetrahymena, and genetic tools, to uncover and study novel genes whose products regulate the intracellular pattern formation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the United States, adolescents experience alarmingly high rates of major depression, and gold-standard treatments are only effective for approximately half of patients. Rumination may be a promising treatment target, as it is well-characterized at the neural level and contributes to depression onset, maintenance, and recurrence as well as predicts treatment non-response. Accordingly, the proposed research will investigate whether an innovative mindfulness-based real-time fMRI neurofeedback intervention successfully elicits change in the brain circuit underlying rumination to improve clinical outcomes among depressed adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are the largest family of cell surface receptors in the human genome, and they are also the proteins most widely targeted by clinically used drugs. GPCRs are implicated in many different biomedical areas, including neuropsychiatric disorders, cardiovascular disease, cancer, allergy, asthma, or pain management. The goal of this application is to develop new state-of-the-art assay technology to improve and accelerate the study and pharmacological targeting of GPCR signaling.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Methods to inactivate specific genes in zebrafish are essential for uncovering basic insights into life, which translates into a better understanding of human development and disease. Existing methods for inactivating genes in zebrafish have limitations, including slow inactivation kinetics and the lack of combined spatial and temporal control. To overcome these problems, we propose to develop a set of protein depletion tools for zebrafish that will allow rapid protein inactivation with combined spatial and temporal control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Ras signaling network mediates diverse cellular functions and is often overactivated in diseases, such as developmental disorders and cancer. By studying its spatiotemporal dynamics, we will provide insights into the regulation of this signaling network in various cellular processes. The knowledge will facilitate the development of strategies to effectively reduce Ras signaling activity for disease treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This K24 Mid-Career Development Award proposes to expand our current program of research by investigating the associations between financial fraud and Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) in the Health and Retirement Study (HRS) and the Rush Alzheimer’s Disease Center (RADC) cohorts. A mentoring team consisting of USC and RADC faculty will provide the PI and trainees guidance in mentorship, professional development, and current research approaches with large datasets. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prescription medications are vital for the treatment of opioid use disorder (OUD) and comorbid medical and mental health conditions, which differentially affect people living with OUD. State prescription cap policies imposed on our most vulnerable populations, such as low-income Medicaid beneficiaries with OUD may force these populations to go without treatments or decide between treatments – a decision that may be particularly challenging for people with OUD who taking multiple medications, including medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD). In this mixed-methods study, we will analyze national Medicaid data to evaluate the impact of prescription cap policies on initiation and continuity of MOUD use among individuals diagnosed with OUD; determine the impact of prescription cap policies on health services utilization, overdoses, and all-cause mortality among individuals diagnosed with OUD; and contextualize our quantitative findings via interviews with patients with OUD and providers who practice in states impacted by cap policies to elucidate their experiences with caps and identify best practices for navigating these policies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Innovative treatment strategies are central to addressing the critical and growing problem of antibiotic resistance. One such strategy is to repurpose drugs (such as β-lactamase inhibitors) that can sensitize multidrug-resistant bacteria to killing by antimicrobial peptides of the innate immune system. The goal of this study is to investigate the mechanistic underpinnings for such synergy with the vision of harnessing these underappreciated therapeutic interactions to improve treatment outcomes for patients with multidrug-resistant infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are anthropogenic chemicals and prominent soil and water contaminants with inherent resistance to environmental degradation, which warrants increased human exposure in decades to come. There exists mounting evidence pertaining to PFAS neurotoxicity, particularly dopaminergic cell loss, a central feature of Parkinson’s disease. The elucidation of underlying mechanism of neurotoxicity, alongside the development of an independent career, is expected to have a significant public health benefit.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Peru is a global center of training in public health and research in tropical medicine and the study of emerging diseases, but training and leadership is exclusively concentrated in the capital city of Lima and access to the training has largely bypassed academic institutions and professionals in Loreto, the largest department in the Peruvian Amazon. This D43 grant renewal seeks to continue to build research capacity to correct this disparity in opportunity by offering a collaborative research training program in partnership with the Universidad Nacional de La Amazonia Peruana (UNAP) complemented by skills training and research mentorship provided by the University of Virginia, Tulane University, and Universidad Peruana Cayetano Heredia. The goal of this training program is to train health researchers capable of leading research to diminish the burden of endemic and emerging infectious diseases in one of the highest burden areas for tropical and neglected diseases in the Americas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Project Narrative  KIR2DL2 is an inhibitory receptor whose role in T cell biology has been poorly characterized. The proposed research aims to validate KIR2DL2 as a new T cell immune checkpoint and to elucidate the signaling mechanism underlying its modulatory functions. The knowledge acquired through this project will be used to design novel and more efficient immunotherapies, including TIL, TCR-transgenic, and CAR-T cells, through manipulation of KIR2DL2 expression or function.

PHR: Project narrative Computational modeling is a crucial tool to better understand how the brain produces cognition and behavior, and how individuals differ, both in healthy and psychiatric populations. This project will develop widely applicable tools that will broadly extend the theories neuroscience researchers can explore quantitatively.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: The genetic analysis of rare diseases across multiple studies has the potential to reveal novel causes of disease that might be missed in isolated study-speciﬁc analyses. Although the Gabriella Miller Kids First (KF) cohort has genetic and clinical data on almost 20,000 people who have, or who are related to someone who has, a birth defect or pediatric cancer, the cohort has not been analyzed jointly. We will develop and deploy a set of computationally efﬁcient and statistically powerful methods for discovering novel causes of rare diseases in KF and validate our results in other rare disease cohorts to which we have access.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Liver transplantation is the only effective treatment for patients with end-stage liver diseases; however, the shortage of donor livers makes this therapy very limited. Comprehensive and detailed understanding of innate liver regeneration in diseased livers will provide significant insights into developing therapeutic strategies to promote liver regeneration in the patients. Our studies will delineate the molecular mechanisms underlying hepatocyte-to-cholangiocyte reprogramming-mediated biliary regeneration and suggest HDAC1/2 inhibitors as promising therapeutic drugs to promote the reprogramming-mediated regeneration in patients with cholestatic liver diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although Multiple Myeloma (MM) causes devastating bone destruction and protracted suppression of bone formation, which increase mortality and contribute to MM cell drug resistance, there are no safe effective bone anabolic agents currently approved for MM. We identified p62 ( sequestosome1) as an important contributor to MM, and developed XRK, a small molecule that targets the p62-ZZ domain, which caused dramatic new bone formation in MM-bearing mice, induced MM cell death and enhanced the anti-MM effects of proteasome inhibitors (PIs) used for MM treatment in vitro. This proposal will investigate the mechanisms responsible for XRK’s effects in MM as a means to build bone, decrease tumor growth and develop new mechanism-based therapeutic agents for MM.

PHR: Project Narrative We propose to develop a systematic and high-throughput method for the engineering of specific and sensitive biosensors based on fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET). IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The role of donor Clonal Hematopoiesis (CH) on hematopoietic cell transplant recipient outcomes and risk of future malignancies is poorly understood, as are the in vivo evolutionary dynamics that dictate the progression of CH to leukemia. Additionally, the patterns of CH clone distribution in stem and mature populations are unclear, limiting our insights into how to perform effective screening and risk assessment. Using a combination of cell phenotypic and genetic analysis, we will assay a unique longitudinal post-transplant and matched donor sample resource, focusing on cases with donor CH to examine the changes in clonal architecture over time, allowing us to gain insights into the risks in donor CH and leukemogenesis in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cigarette smoking causes variable degree of inflammation in the lung that only some smokers will develop chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Genetic factors that increases the risk to develop COPD have been identified, but how genetic factors increase COPD risk and whether genetic factors contribute to inflammation is not well understood. We propose to investigate genetic mouse models and lung tissue samples and genetic data from COPD patients to understand how genetic factors influence inflammation in COPD. This study will help to identify novel therapeutic targets and provide insight into the pathology of COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Currently, quantitative PCR (qPCR) is one of the most abundant DNA quantification tools available and is widely used in molecular diagnostics, such as COVID-19 test. The drawback to qPCR is that the data is not digitized and requires more test controls in order to interpret the results. Enumerix aims to circumvent this limitation by developing the next generation DNA quantification tool called direct count PCR (dcPCR) where the DNA data is digitized and rivals the sensitivity and dynamic range of qPCR in a cost effective manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Cardiometabolic diseases are on the increase worldwide, contributing to high levels of morbidity and mortality, with limited resources among lower-resource populations in North America and Africa to prevent disease, make diagnosis and clinically manage patients. In this study we bring together ~50,000 African-ancestry participants (African American, Jamaicans and continental African) to form the CARDINAL study to assess and develop polygenic risk scores for cardiometabolic diseases and traits, and to develop analytic approaches for multi-ethnic cohorts leveraging the increased genetic diversity and lower linkage disequilibrium in African genomes. This research will lead to a better understanding of the transferability of polygenic risk scores from discovery to target populations of different ethnicities, informing prevention and diagnostic strategies that could contribute to the development of effective public health policies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Projection neurons (PNs) in the spinal superficial dorsal horn are essential for nociceptive transmission to the brain and the generation of chronic pain after injury, and the long-term potentiation (LTP) of sensory synapses onto these neurons has been strongly linked to increased pain sensation. The expected outcomes of the proposed research will have a positive impact on public health by providing valuable insight into novel interventional strategies to disrupt spinal LTP as a means to alleviate chronic pain. In addition, by showing that neonatal surgical injury persistently facilitates LTP in adult PNs via changes in spinal dopamine signaling, these studies will provide much needed information regarding the potential mechanisms by which tissue damage in infants and children can alter pain sensitivity throughout life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Triple-Negative breast cancer (TNBC) represents the subtype of breast cancer with worst prognosis and there is a lack of valuable therapeutic targets in this lethal disease. Here we provide evidence from unbiased screens that BBOX1 is a new therapeutic target in TNBC and genetic knockdown or pharmacological inhibition of BBOX1 leads to decreased TNBC cell fitness. The studies, if successful, will provide a new therapeutic avenue for TNBC and also provide a foundation for developing effective BBOX1 inhibitors for this lethal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this project we will determine the roles of specialized white blood cells, called tumor-specific interleukin 9- producing T cells, in promoting an immune response against solid tumors in mice and determine their potential for use in cancer adoptive cell immunotherapy. We hypothesize that transfer of these tumor-specific T cells will eradicate large established tumors and prevent recurrence in vivo in both mouse and human tumor models, due to their ability to 1) directly kill the tumor cells; 2) penetration into stroma-rich solid tumors, and 3) restrain relapse caused by acquired resistance due to high heterogeneity in tumor antigen expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL Despite strong links between maternal infection and neurodevelopmental disorders, little is known about why some pregnancies are susceptible, and others resilient, to this risk factor and why the susceptible pregnancies lead to a wide range of distinct disorders in humans. Using a newly discovered approach that predicts outcomes, we will measure changes in maternal immunity and cortico-striatal circuits in five highly interactive projects using mouse and NHP models of MIA and individuals with schizophrenia, to determine factors in the mother and offspring that contribute to susceptibility and resilience to different phenotypic outcomes. If successful, our results will identify causal molecular pathways in specific neural circuits critical for developing interventions optimized for the developmental age and sex of at-risk offspring following MIA, as well as biomarkers to predict pregnancies most at risk and approaches to prevent behavioral aberrations in offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic inflammation is a central feature in the development of obesity-induced insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes. Although physical activity protects against adiposity and chronic inflammation, the cellular mechanisms remain undefined. We will assess how exercise and diet contribute to the development of adipose tissue inflammation and diet-induced insulin resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The role of cardiac vagal motor neurons in the regulation of cardiovascular function has long been established, but the contribution of this system to cardiovascular dysregulation during the consumption of foods high in fat is an understudied topic. These experiments will address the hypothesis that consumption of foods high in fat significantly elevate inhibition of brainstem vagal motor neurons responsible for the generation of vagal motor drive to the heart. This proposal develops a novel neuromechanistic model by which a microcircuit within the brainstem underpins increased vagal inhibition after the consumption of a diet high in fat.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Child maltreatment and adolescent substance use are highly-prevalent and tightly-connected public health concerns in the United States. The current study aims to identify the pathways from child maltreatment to adolescent substance use by focusing on risky and protective attributes within youth activity spaces as critical underlying mechanisms. Findings from the proposed research will inform the development of more effective interventions to prevent substance use among high-risk youth by elucidating key contextual mechanisms and protective factors for adolescent substance use following child maltreatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  During neural development, neuronal stem cells produce neurons that ultimately wire-up to form circuits that process somatosensory information (e.g., touch, temperature, pain). The current proposal will identify molecules that instruct neurons from a single neuronal stem cell to populate different somatosensory circuits. This knowledge is critically required to produce therapies for injuries and diseases affecting somatosensation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative We use Electronic Health Records (EHR) data of over 527,000 patients with incident diabetes who were diagnosed and treated in the Southern California Kaiser Permanente (KPSC) health care system from 1993- 2020 to update the United Kingdom’s Prospective Diabetes Study (UKPDS) risk equations. KPSC’s diverse and vast membership further allows us to estimate UKPDS risk equations separately for major racial/ethnic groups. We will also explore the impact of health behaviors on diabetes trajectories including exercise and referrals to diabetes and weight management education classes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: There is an urgent need for the development and commercialization of highly effective treatments for COVID-19. Currently there are only limited FDA-approved therapeutics to combat the SARS- CoV-2 (CoV-2) virus that has caused the COVID-19 global pandemic, killing more than 6.4 million people worldwide to date. OyaGen has discovered that sangivamycin is a highly potent antiviral for CoV-2. Sangivamycin was proven safe when evaluated in human cancer clinical trials performed in the 1960’s. It however was ineffective against cancer and abandoned. In this Phase I SBIR application, preclinical studies are proposed in response to FDA guidance that will be IND- enabling and a prerequisite to Phase I clinical trial safety and pharmacokinetics evaluation in healthy volunteers. The development of sangivamycin as a therapeutic for infected patients is a medical countermeasure for immunocompromised people who may not benefit from vaccine immunization as well as a stop gap therapeutic for new strains of CoV for which current vaccines may be less effective. Importantly, our data support that sangivamycin has the potential to enhance the efficacy of other therapeutics as a combination therapy option in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Three plasma phosphorylated tau epitopes (p-tau231, p-tau181, p-tau217) have recently emerged as important tools to study Alzheimer’s disease (AD) pathophysiology. However, the difference in performance between these epitopes to identify the AD continuum is poorly understood, making it difficult for the field to choose the plasma p-tau epitope or combination of epitopes that will advance for widespread use in clinical trials and practice. We will measure the p-tau231, p-tau181, p-tau217 assays in longitudinally collected plasma samples, with associated positron emission tomography tau and amyloid-beta, from individuals across the AD spectrum to elucidate the performance of each p-tau epitope to use in research and clinical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Intracellular membrane trafficking that mediates the delivery of secretory and endocytic cargo proteins and lipids is critical for a range of cellular functions, including protein secretion, post-translational modifications, signaling, cell polarization, and cell maintenance. Defects in membrane trafficking can underlie or exacerbate many human diseases, including cancer, diabetes, Alzheimer’s disease, cystic fibrosis, Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome, and congenital disorders of glycosylation. In this project, we will uncover the molecular basis for protein-protein interactions and regulations of key components of the Golgi trafficking machinery and create a novel cellular model to study congenital disorders of glycosylation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Up to 68% of child welfare cases involve a caregiver with an alcohol and/or other substance use disorder (AOSUD), which is significant given that in 2020 there were 3.9 million child welfare referrals involving 7.1 million children! Child welfare professionals lack knowledge of AOSUDs and their evidence-based treatments and many caregivers’ AOSUDs go unidentified and untreated, which puts children at greater risk for maltreatment and out-of-home placements. The proposed training program seeks funding to enhance Virginia Commonwealth University’s (VCU) federally-supported Title IV-E child welfare professional training program with specialized training on AOSUDs integrated with ongoing clinical/peer supervision and tele-education, creating an innovative training model that can be adopted across the country’s network of almost 150 Title IV-E programs to improve child welfare outcomes nationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Treatment with immune checkpoint inhibitors is promising for many types of cancer. Self-management of symptoms with timely reports to the healthcare providers is necessary to prevent immune-related adverse events. A highly scalable intervention sequence consisting of an automated telephone intervention with need- based addition of a counseling intervention for survivors with persisting psychological distress will be tested in this project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ovarian cancer is the deadliest gynecologic malignancy, accounting for ~25,000 cases and ~15,000 deaths annually in the United States. This project investigates RHNO1, a newly discovered oncoprotein and potential therapeutic target in this disease. Our studies will investigate the role of RHNO1 in ovarian cancer and identify the first small molecule inhibitors that inhibit the function of this protein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE: Speech and language learning impairments have been linked to deficits in processing the complex spectral and temporal structure of sound. This project investigates cellular mechanisms of auditory perception in zebra finches, focusing on how early experience shapes the intrinsic physiological properties of neurons that may enable them to process rapid temporal modulations in vocalizations. Understanding these mechanisms will give insight into analogous processes in human speech development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to investigate the role of transcriptionally generated G-quadruplex (G4), R-loop and DNA supercoiling in transcription and translation. Potential G4 forming sequences are prevalent in regulatory regions of human and e. coli genome and the G4 formation can up or downregulate gene expression including many oncogenes. Defining the molecular mechanism will contribute to the development of rational cancer drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The proposed Undergraduate-Research Initiative for Student Enhancement (U-RISE) at Claflin University (CU) consists of interdisciplinary research projects that 18 U-RISE Trainees will conduct under the supervision of a total of 15 researchers at CU and in collaboration with institutions that have research-intensive environments focusing on National Institutes of Health Training Programs over a five-year period. At CU, the project will be conducted in various laboratories (Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics-Computer Science and Engineering) in the School of Natural Sciences and Mathematics, with selected projects integrated with community-based participatory public health research to help address pertinent health disparities with collaborating external mentors. This project will enhance students’ enthusiasm in research and promote career development with an increased number of underrepresented students entering and completing Ph.D. or MD/Ph.D. programs in biomedical-focused sciences.

PHR: Tuberculosis remains a leading cause of death around the world, and new treatments are needed to curb the epidemic. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Older adults are at risk for ICU-acquired cognitive decline discernible from clinical, biological, and imaging- related changes in the brain following delirium and critical illness. Our Driving Rehabilitation and Innovation for Evaluating Risk in Post Intensive Care Unit Survivors (DRIVE-PICS) application seeks to implement in-vehicle kinematic driving data with neurocognitive assessments for essential formative work to develop data-based insights into driving behaviors. DRIVE-PICS is designed to contribute to a critical gap in health promotion to develop an evidence-based, in-vehicle driving assessment system to provide actionable driving safety data and rehabilitation strategies tailored to older ICU survivors, their care partners, and clinicians.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Statement There has developed a great need in contemporary society for veterinarians trained in the methodology of basic research but, unfortunately, veterinary students are often not aware of the career possibilities in these areas of need. The expansion of biotechnology frontiers require contributions by veterinary scientists capable of evaluating whole animal health issues while being expert, or at least conversant, with the rapidly evolving technologies. We believe our proposed training grant (third renewal) “Georgia Veterinary Scholars Summer Research Program” will make veterinary students more aware of and likely to pursue careers in research. Such veterinary research scientists will then be particularly well equipped to identify unique features of various animal models of human disease, to advance studies in translational medicine and animal health, to navigate the interface of animal and ecological health, and to be leaders in public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Cilia are tiny hair-like projections on the surface of the cell that can serve as antennae to sense the cell’s environment or beat to move fluid. Defects in cilia cause disorders known as ciliopathies that affect numerous organs, including the brain, kidneys, eyes, and lungs, which require cilia for their formation or function. The aim of this project is to understand how a newly discovered family of widely conserved, yet poorly understood, ciliary proteins contributes to cilia assembly and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: A reason for the scarcity of safe and efficacious therapies these pain and comorbid depression is our limited knowledge of viable targets. In this project, we will use integrated positron emission tomography / magnetic resonance imaging to test the hypothesis that cannabidiol (CBD), compared to placebo, 1) reduces pain- and depression-related neuroinflammation, and 2) normalizes striatal function, in chronic low back pain patients. By studying the neural and neuroimmune responses to CBD, this study will advance our knowledge about the mechanisms of action of this drug, and help us understand which conditions might benefit the most from its use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Axons (the long cellular connections among nerve cells) typically fail to regrow when severed, leading to paralysis after spinal cord injury. We have discovered a series of compounds that promote the growth of axons in the brain and spinal cord. The goal of this proposal is to improve the properties of these compounds to generate candidate drugs that can be tested in clinical trials of injured patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Members of the Environmental Mutagenesis and Genomics Society (EMGS) have expertise in multiple disciplines covering all aspects of basic and applied research on mechanisms and consequences of responses to genotoxic agents. Integration of these disciplines remains the central focus of the Society, and the annual meetings are key to the dissemination of information and fostering of interactions between researchers and individuals who must make informed regulatory decisions with respect to environmental health hazards. Funding is being sought for these meetings to help provide a forum in which students, postdoctoral fellows, and early- stage investigators can develop and enhance their careers by sharing information with established scientists through formal scientific sessions and informal interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many researchers use DNA sequencing to study disease and biology, and analyzing this data requires sophisticated software capable of piecing together puzzles made of billions of fragments of DNA. Our main strategy for assembling these puzzles, aligning sequencing reads to a reference genome, suffers from the “reference bias” problem, where a lack of inclusiveness in the reference genome used causes it to give incorrect answers. We propose a new index data structure that tackles this problem while allowing for the extremely fast queries needed to keep up with fast DNA sequencers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project charts the process of human biological niche construction: the formation of lived individual ecosystems at the intersection of genes, environment, & experience. We will measure genetic and environmental influence on social looking and brain growth in order to identify specific gene-by-environment- by-age transactions, transactions that typically canalize normative social development and that also offer the potential to identify optimal intervention targets to prevent or preempt the development of social disability.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cesarean delivery, the most common major surgical procedure in the US, is the strongest risk factor for maternal infection (a top 3 cause of death during childbirth). Adjunctive azithromycin compared to standard antibiotic prophylaxis alone is proven (through our large C/SOAP trial and other studies) to be highly effective in preventing infection after cesarean - with authorities now recommending consideration of its use while calling for more information on long-term health outcomes after exposure at birth. We propose a US multi-center long-term follow- up study of children from the parent C/SOAP trial at age 7 (6-9) years to evaluate childhood obesity/growth and neurodevelopment after perinatal exposure to adjunctive azithromycin (complementing our NICHD grant evaluating pulmonary and gastrointestinal health scored at the 6th percentile); findings from this study will be used to inform and strengthen national and global health care policy regarding the safety of adjunctive azithromycin to reduce maternal infection after cesarean delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this project we search to validate the use of a new type of MRI technique, called Deuterium Metabolic Imaging (DMI) as a tool to detect abnormal glucose metabolism in brain tumors. We test the new technology by comparing with existing methods for validation, and also to reveal any improved performance. In addition, the use of DMI is evaluated as technique to detect early treatment effects in brain tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) is overexpressed in over 20% breast cancers, and to a lesser degree in gastric cancers, colorectal cancer, ovarian cancers and bladder cancers. Here, we will develop a novel HER2-targeting transformable cancer targeting nanoplatform (TCTN) that not only can directly suppress HER2 dimerization and signaling leading to tumor cell death, but can also greatly augment systemic anti-tumor immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Most adjunctive treatments developed to date against cerebral malaria have not reduced fatal outcomes mainly because treatments have focused on clearance of circulating parasites but neglected the involvement of damaging parasite and host factors appearing early in infection or remaining after treatment. The proposed study uses 3D in vitro models, animal, and human studies to clarify our understanding of the role of NRG1/ErbB4 and PD1/PD-L1 signaling in HCM severity in order to target NRG1 in clinical trials with the ultimate goal of improving survival rates in children with cerebral malaria. The proposed study will clarify the role of NRG-1 in attenuation of ECM and human cerebral malaria (HCM) and mechanisms mediating its function.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Scaling Up Research Ethics and Research Integrity (SURER) Project Project narrative  With increasing number and scope of research projects, the University of Maryland School of Medicine, Center for Bioethics and Research and University of Ibadan, Nigeria identified need to build capacity for mentored Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR), research/scientific integrity (RSI), Conflict of Interest (CoI), Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI), Safe Working Environment and Sexual Harassment training to strengthen research environment in Nigeria. We engage our successful training resources, technologies, and models to create new institutional resources and infrastructure, conduct advocacy, build public and professional awareness, implement training and innovative e-mentoring for RCR, RSI, CoI, DEI, Safe Working Environment and Sexual Harassment in sixteen Nigerian universities. We use the experiences and expectations of our trainees and use these to create a Learning Educational Program (LEP) with regular adjustments and updates to our curriculum contents and training examples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The third most common disease category in the U.S. after cancer and heart disease is autoimmune disease. Yet, treatments mainly rely on immunosuppressive drugs with significant side effects that are not curative and do not induce long term remissions. Our studies propose to reprogram neutrophils, abundant in blood and traditionally viewed as short-lived cells evolved to kill pathogens, into cells that re-educate autoreactive T cells to be tolerant to self-antigens, which in turn could reverse autoimmunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Sexual and Gender Minorities (SGM) living in rural areas and small cities in the United States are disproportionately affected by depression and suicide, yet little research has explored how pervasive and persistent experiences of SGM-related stigma, discrimination and trauma (i.e., distal minority stressors) may be associated with depression, suicide ideation, and suicide attempts among diverse rural SGM sub- populations. We will use online approaches to enroll 2000 rural SGM (500 each: cisgender sexual minority female, cisgender sexual minority male, transfeminine, and transmasculine persons) participants from across the US and administer repeat measures over 12 months to determine whether: classes of stigma, discrimination, and traumatic experiences vary across SGM subgroups; these exposures are associated with increased prevalent/incident depression, suicidal ideation, and suicide attempts; and if identity, psychological, and proximal minority stress related factors mediate and/or moderate these associations. Building on these findings, we will compare the relative acceptability of various technology-delivered intervention components for depression and suicide prevention that can be targeted to diverse rural SGM communities and their heterogenous experiences of distal minority stressors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is in urgent need of therapeutic strategies that offer an improvement in clinical outcome and the targeting of cancer metabolism represents a promising approach in developing anti- cancer therapies. We have discovered that pH homeostasis is achieved in PDAC cells by employing the trans- Golgi network (TGN) as a “proton sink”, and we have developed a TGN pH biosensor assay for high-throughput (HT) screening of small molecules. The novel compounds that we identify will result in a loss of pH homeostasis and cancer-selective cell death, and may serve as chemical starting points to be further developed into safe and effective therapeutic agents for PDAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Dental enamel is unique in biology, as it is the only epithelial derived mineralized tissue and has a remarkable architecture based on extremely thin fibers of 50 nm in diameter that are woven into a fracture resistant and hard tissue for optimal mastication. This renewal application expands on a new paradigm that will decipher how the organic protein matrix of the developing enamel controls and guides enamel structure and will also initiates study towards the engineering of an enamel-like material in vitro.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ARIZONA VETERANS RESEARCH AND EDUCATION FOUNDATION
PHR: Project Narrative Neurological disease (e.g., Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias), injury (e.g., traumatic brain injury), and aging trigger inflammation that goes on to activate microglial immune cells in the brain. In this proposal, we develop molecular tools for the rod microglia variant, which follow the onset, progression, and resolution of neurological conditions. The tools will identify, isolate, and interrogate cell surface markers, genes, and proteins unique to this microglia variant, which can be used for diagnosis, prognosis, and potential treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Renal cell carcinoma (RCC), the 8th most common form of adult cancer in the US, is in need of novel therapeutic strategies to overcome resistance to existing therapies. My preliminary studies have revealed that deregulation of the Hippo-YAP/TAZ pathway represents a major molecular hallmark in RCC, and is a key mechanism used by RCC cells to maintain their transcriptional homeostasis. Employing patient-derived RCC tumor models and clinically viable inhibitors, my study will establish the therapeutic potential and mechanisms of actions for YAP/TAZ-based therapies in RCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application requests support to study predictors and immune signals of recurrent glomerular diseases after kidney transplantation. This research has the potential to refine the pathogenetic model of recurrent glomerular diseases, improve donor-recipient matching, and discover more effective therapies. Our goal is to reduce recurrent glomerular diseases and ultimately improve transplant survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Using brain lesions and deep brain stimulation to identify an epilepsy circuit Focal epilepsy affects over 30 million patients worldwide and identifying the brain circuits involved in epilepsy can lead to better, more targeted treatments. Here, we use maps of human brain connectivity and a technique recently developed by our lab to identify the brain circuits connected to lesions causing epilepsy and brain stimulation sites treating epilepsy. Identification of these circuits will help identify lesion patients at highest risk for epilepsy, guide DBS programming, and provide a more precise therapeutic target for future brain stimulation trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) is a relatively common disorder that causes debilitating cognitive and psychiatric decline. No cure or effective therapies exist for these symptoms because the biological processes driving them are poorly understood. This project will analyze thousands of proteins in the brains and spinal fluid of individuals with DLB to better define its underlying biology and identify key proteins that can help us better monitor and treat this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE: There is an urgent need for finding more effective drug delivery methods and treatments for respiratory tract infections, such as COVID-19. Nitric oxide (NO) gas is an inhalable, extremely potent and FDA approved medicine used to increase oxygen levels of blood and has a very strong antimicrobial effect, but its therapeutic application is very limited due to its very high costs. Herein, we propose to develop a novel, safe and very inexpensive electrochemical method for generating gas phase NO from nitrite solution that can be attached to a noninvasive high flow nasal cannula (HFNC) delivery system for very precise and controlled administration of NO to patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Resistance to endocrine therapy is the major challenge in the management of ER+ BC. Endocrine therapy is designed to target ER in luminal tumors. However, if luminal tumors lose ER expression, a process called “de- differentiation”, tumors lose responsiveness to endocrine therapy, and become resistant. This project aims to understand the underlying molecular mechanism controlling transition from ER+ breast cancers to stem-like cells (SLCs) and target SLCs using epigenetic drugs (i.e., EZH2 inhibitors).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disrupted enhancer activity is associated with a wide variety of pathologies, from congenital disorders to cancer, however, the mechanisms which regulate enhancer activity are still poorly understood. In this proposal, I seek to characterize a newly identified regulatory element that has been shown to be necessary and sufficient for long-range enhancer activity. My findings should provide insight into a new mechanism of gene regulation during development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Humans move their eyes several times a second, and each of these eye movements is accompanied by changes in our visual perception, including distortions of location and duration. The proposed series of electrophysiological, psychophysical, and statistical modeling experiments will identify neuronal changes and brain areas involved in changes in perception around the time of saccades, with direct implications both for understanding normal vision and for disorders involving impaired integration of information across eye movements, such as schizophrenia, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, dyslexia, and autism spectrum disorders.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed Microbiome and Metagenomics Center is relevant to human health because we anticipate results can be used by the Nutrition for Precision Health Consortium to understand the relationship between the microbiome, nutrition, and human health. Data and technologies developed will be widely available to the community to promote further scientific advances. The Center is relevant to NIH and NIDDK’s mission because it seeks to produce high quality metagenomic and metatranscriptomic data that will help determine how nutrition and the microbiome can be used to improve people’s health and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite CDK4/6 inhibitors significantly improve overall survival of advanced ER+ breast cancer, not all patients respond to these drugs and most patients whose tumors initially respond to CDK4/6 inhibitors eventually develop acquired resistance. In this application, we will determine a novel mechanism regulating resistance to CDK4/6 inhibitors and evaluate effects of potential new drug combination treatments to overcome resistance in ER+ breast cancer. This study can lead to development of an innovative therapeutic strategy for treatment of CDK4/6 inhibitor resistant breast cancer patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neural tube defects are among the most common structural birth defects and can lead to long-term disability and death. These malformations result from a failure of the flat neural plate to roll into a neural tube during embryogenesis, a complex process involving morphogenesis of not only the neural plate but the underlying cranial mesenchyme. This project aims to elucidate the molecular mechanisms that drive cranial mesenchyme morphogenesis contributing to neural fold elevation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Neglect, abandonment, abuse, and other forms of early life adversity significantly increase risk for psychiatric disorders, such as depression, by shifting developmental brain trajectories and sensitizing individuals to subsequent stress. This proposal tests the hypothesis that paternal deprivation alters the lateral septum to respond to social stress experienced later in life via neural, epigenetic, and transcriptomic mechanisms that act on the function of the oxytocin and vasopressin systems. This work will contribute to a novel understanding of stress susceptibility and can provide insight to better inform new therapeutic strategies to understand the developmental differences in how sociality is altered by early life adversity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Of the 13 million US older adults admitted to the hospital each year, nearly half will require a surrogate decision maker due to Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and other conditions that cause cognitive impairment. The process of decision making and the experiences of the surrogates are therefore central to the care of older adults. Findings from this research will improve the quality of medical decisions for older adults with AD and other causes of cognitive impairment and will improve the well-being of family surrogates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of non-narcotic (non-opioid) therapeutics is urgently needed in light of the current opioid epidemic. Pain that results from surgeries or from arthritis is linked to prolonged inflammation and is typically treated with opiates, which places million of patients with these conditions at higher risks for opioid abuse problems. The proposed studies will validate a specific target to promote a faster resolution of inflammation as a new non-narcotic therapeutic strategy that has the potential to prevent or treat surgical or inflammatory pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure to cues associated with drugs of abuse can provoke craving and precipitate relapse long after the last drug experience. This reflects an increased ability of these cues to energize behavior, which is a hallmark of dopaminergic activity. Using a rodent model of vulnerability to cocaine relapse after protracted abstinence, I will measure dopamine and test for its functional significance in this behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance Understanding the molecular mechanisms that drive cancer formation and responses to therapeutic interventions will improve our ability to diagnose and treat cancer, which is one of the leading causes of death in the U.S. We have proposed an integrative set of studies that will provide new information about the role of transcription factor ADP-ribosylation by nuclear PARPs in breast cancers, as well as their role in determining the unique biology and therapeutic responses of different breast cancer subtypes to PARP inhibitors. We anticipate that these studies will suggest new avenues for the therapeutic potential of PARP inhibitors in cancers beyond DNA repair pathways.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The presence and function of vasculature is critical to the success of islet cell replacement therapies for type I diabetes that utilize hydrogel-based scaffolds. The proposed work will use novel techniques to control hydrogel structure with the goal of driving the controlled formation of vasculature around stem cell-derived pancreatic islets. Results from the proposed studies will improve the survival and function of engineered pancreatic islet grafts and help bring these emerging technologies closer to a translational endpoint.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammation of the brain accompanies many chronic neurologic disorders including epilepsy. A major inflammatory pathway, that mediated by activation of the EP2 receptor for prostaglandin E2, appears to exert a dual role during the development of epilepsy, both promoting and opposing neuropathology. We will identify the cell types underlying these opposing roles with the aim of developing more targeted anti-inflammatory therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are a group of blood cancers which reduce the ability of the bone marrow to produce normal blood cells while increasing the risk of patients developing a related aggressive form of blood cancers. While a lot has been learned about how mutations alter hematopoietic stem cells to drive MDS development, our ability to analyze the cells responsible for initiation of MDS has been hampered by the fact that these cells are rare in number, which presents a technical challenge for their study. In this proposal we will focus on identifying the abnormalities in DNA, RNA, and protein level within individual cells from the bone marrow of MDS patients, to provide our first ever look into how mutations in MDS perturb each individual cell to drive disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fatigue is a persistent problem affecting up to 90% of cancer patients, yet treatment options are limited. Advances in metabolomics and genomics offer an unprecedent opportunity to unravel the underlying biological mechanisms and to identify novel biomarkers of fatigue, which may be targets for therapeutic intervention. We will use the 3-P (Predisposing, Precipitating, Prepetuating) model to combine genomics, metabolomics, inflammatory markers and behaviors to comprehensively examine contributors of cancer- related fatigue in ColoCare, a large cohort of colorectal cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our overall long-term goal is to accurately identify who is at risk of decline in driving, to forecast when decline will occur, and to intervene before decline, thereby reducing the numbers of crashes, injuries, and death in older adults. By 2050, 1 in 4 drivers will be 65 or more years of age, and currently, motor vehicle crashes are a leading cause of injury and death in older adults, with depression and symptomatic Alzheimer disease (AD) independently increasing the risk of a crash. Driving data continuously collected from the natural environment are needed to more accurately evaluate daily behavior and can allow us to determine how preclinical AD, depression, and antidepressant use affect driving decline and crash risk over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent progress in complex trait genetics, coupled with the technical ability to generate accurate genome-wide genotypes from single-cell input, has made it possible to genetically screen embryos for common polygenic traits and disease risk. However, little empirical work has been done to quantify the utility of polygenic embryo screening (PES), examine its ethical implications, and assess stakeholder perspectives. The proposed study is designed to provide the necessary empirical basis for informed ethical discussion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Statement Nationally and globally the aging population continues to grow. In the US and elsewhere, the predominant face of aging will be female as aged women will outnumber men by two to one. Understanding how estrogen, the predominant feminizing hormone, acts to promote and sustain the energy producing system of the brain is critical to revealing changes that occur in the aging female brain that can increase the risk of age-associated neurodegenerative diseases in postmenopausal women such as Alzheimer's, depression and multiple sclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This study will utilize a set of artificial intelligence methods to evaluate large quantities of data derived from individuals with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1), a complex genetic disease with the potential to affect every organ system, in order to develop clinical decision support tools that can predict disease risk at the individual patient level. The knowledge gained from such studies will enable physicians and patients (or their family members) to better manage the treatment of NF1 over a lifespan, thus increasing the timeliness and safety of care, as well as the quality of life of those individuals and their care providers. Further, given the similarity of NF1 to many other diseases that involve a complex interaction of genes, clinical features, and other measurable characteristics, the methods we develop should be applicable to a broad variety of conditions beyond NF1 and improve our ability to deliver precision medicine, with ensuing benefits in terms of the costs, quality, and outcomes of healthcare.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE__________________________________________ The proposed research will investigate the hypothesis that silent cerebral infarctions in young children with sickle cell disease can be predicted by a combination of neuroimaging measures and neurocognitive test scores. The knowledge gained from this research could lead to development of a predictive risk score to identify young children with sickle cell disease at highest risk for silent cerebral infarctions and other neurological complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diagnostic DNA testing is often inconclusive, as we cannot always determine whether a given DNA change in will cause disease. We will use cells to develop a method to determine whether specific DNA changes cause a genetic condition called Hunter syndrome or are benign DNA changes. The results can help better predict whether someone will have Hunter syndrome from DNA testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The incidence of HPV-related oropharyngeal cancer has been rapidly increasing in the US. In this project, we propose to develop and validate quantitative imaging biomarkers to predict risks of locoregional relapse and distant metastasis in oropharyngeal cancer. This has the potential to optimize selection of patients who are eligible for treatment de-escalation in HPV-positive disease, paving the way for precision medicine in oropharyngeal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Fungal infections are responsible for more than 1.5 million deaths worldwide each year, and within the United States, invasive fungal infections (IFIs) are a significant threat to immunocompromised patients. Only a few classes of antifungal drugs are available, and the emergence of resistance within all classes is an alarming threat to global public health. Curatix is developing a new class of antifungals that act via a novel target to provide a more effective treatment strategy for IFIs in addition to enhancing the activity of current anti-fungals to overcome resistant infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Overall Goal of the MIEHR Research Center is to elucidate the contributions of exposures in the biological, physical, social and built environments of the environmental riskscape to environmental health disparities in pregnant women and their infants. The MIEHR Center has two synergistic Research Projects that build on a unique ongoing, perinatal database and biospecimen repository: the BCM PeriBank, a Community Engagement and Dissemination Core (CEDC) and an Investigator Development Core (IDC). The MIEHR Center will accomplish its goals in research, career development and community engagement with multidisciplinary and diverse teams of community and academic experts, interdisciplinary collaborations between synergistic research projects, activities that develop a diverse workforce and community engagement that fosters equitable community stakeholder interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Astrocytes are critical mediators of innate immunity in the brain. Activation of innate immunity in the brain causes astrocytes to undergo astrogliosis, which contributes to the pathogenesis of neuroinflammatory and neurodegenerative diseases. The mechanisms that regulate astrogliosis are incompletely understood. Preliminary studies from our lab support a role for PARP7, an enzyme that catalyzes the post-translational modification known as mono-ADP-ribosylation (MARylation), in astrogliosis. Using unique chemical tools, we are investigating the mechanism by which PARP7-mediated MARylation regulates astrogliosis. The knowledge gained from these studies could lead to novel treatments for neuroinflammatory (e.g. multiple sclerosis) and neurodegenerative diseases (e.g. Alzheimer's disease), which are major health burdens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Convergent research finds a single overarching general factor, the “P factor”, contributes to a broad array of psychiatric symptoms, but we know very little about what factors influence the neurodevelopment of the P factor during youth. This project addresses this gap in knowledge by leveraging data from the seminal Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) study. Using advanced multivariate neuroimaging methods, we systematically map how social/environmental, psychological, and genetic factors shape brain structure and function during adolescence which in turn leads to the emergence of the P factor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Current treatment regimens are not adequate for patients with relapsed T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T- ALL). We propose a novel approach to target T-ALL by using innate-like cytotoxic gamma delta (γδ) T cells and will test two strategies, one utilizing cellular stress modulation as a means to sensitize T-ALL to γδ T cell- mediated killing, and the other through the use of a CD5-directed chimeric antigen receptor (CAR). Research outlined in this proposal will provide invaluable preclinical data necessary to develop γδ T cell-based strategies to treat T-ALL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Adolescent alcohol exposure leads to long term detrimental effects on behavior, with recent evidence indicating exposure causes increased responsiveness to pain or hyperalgesia in adulthood, however the neural and biochemical alterations leading to this phenotype are not known. Here, we propose a fellowship training plan where a physician-scientist in training will investigate adolescent alcohol effects on amygdalar neuropeptide and glutamate systems, and will test the role of those systems in mediating adolescent alcohol induced hyperalgesia in adulthood. The findings from the proposed work will (1) characterize how the amygdala changes during and after adolescent alcohol exposure, (2) test and inform the development of translationally relevant therapies, and (3) foster the development of a promising M.D./Ph.D. student with training in alcohol and pain related neuroscience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  The manner in which the brain responds to cumulative traumatic brain injuries (TBIs) and leads to neurological dysfunction is unknown. Our approach permits inter-injury in vivo microscopy to observe injury- induced change in blood flow and blood-brain barrier permeability, while recording post-traumatic sleep, as predictors of subacute neurological function. New insights to cumulative pathophysiology after TBI can inform clinical management and studies to reduce damage and accelerate recovery.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The gene Expression Analysis Resource (gEAR portal, umgear.org) is a cloud-based tool for analysis, visualization and sharing of multi-species multi-omic inner-ear related data. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The goal of this research is to better understand the impact of aging on the DNA of individual cells in people with and without Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Our lab has recently discovered that human brain cells continually accumulate mutations throughout life, a phenomenon called genosenium, and that the rate that mutations accumulate is much higher in individuals with AD. We will further explore this event in different regions of the brain and in different cell types in order to elucidate the underlying mechanisms at work, and explore how they are related to AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neuronal remodeling is a conserved process whereby the developing nervous system eliminates extraneous cells and connections. This refinement allows for proper rewiring of the nervous system for optimal function in adulthood. My goal is to understand the fundamental mechanisms by which unneeded neurons and connections are recognized and appropriately eliminated from the developing nervous system, which holds promise for furthering our understanding of neurodevelopmental disorders such as Autism Spectrum Disorders and Schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Narrative: This proposal seeks to address long-standing racial and ethnic disparities in use of permanent contraception (historically called “surgical sterilization”) by disseminating PCOR on the comparative safety and effectiveness of long-acting contraceptives. Although permanent contraception aligns well with some patients’ reproductive life plans, reports that 10% of women regret having undergone these procedures are troubling. By increasing equitable access to alternatives to permanent contraception, this project strives to increase the proportion of US women who are using a method of contraception that aligns with their personal preferences and reduce the proportion of individuals who regret having undergone a permanent contraceptive procedure.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Disseminating PCOR findings to Reduce Racial Disparities in Surgical Sterilization

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Chromatin structure and organization profoundly influence gene expression which ultimately controls normal cell proliferation and cellular differentiation in humans. Mutations in genes functioning in chromatin assembly and remodeling are found associated with numerous human tumors. This grant is focused on understanding a unique type of chromatin structure and how this structure is used by the cell to influence genomic activities, such as gene expression. The outcome of this research could potentially lead to new targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Recent discoveries in cancer research have revealed that many aggressive cancers consume glutamine to fend off toxic reactive oxygen species in addition to using glutamine to produce energy and building blocks for making more cells. We will develop positron emission tomography (PET) imaging methods to report the glutamine metabolism level and glutamate transport activity in triple-negative breast cancers to guide targeted therapy. Once they are validated in animal models of this proposal, these imaging tools can be readily translated to the clinic for personalized treatment based on specific cancer metabolic features for each patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm infants are at risk of bleeding in the brain which can cause permanent damage and long-term disabilities for which no treatment exists. We discovered that fibrinogen, a blood clotting protein, leaks into the injured brain and blocks stem cells from forming the new neurons and myelin needed for normal brain development. The goal of this project is to determine if we can overcome fibrinogen’s inhibitory effects in the brain as a new treatment strategy for preterm infant brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Respiratory infections including COVID19 ignite the host response in the lungs. Endothelial cells in the pulmonary vasculature mediate recruitment of neutrophils to fight the invaders. Neutrophils inflict the collateral damage to endothelium. Emerging clinical reports implicate this complication in poor outcomes of COVID19 in the high-risk patients. We have devised nanocarriers for targeted delivery of protective agents to endothelium using ligand molecules with specific affinity to these cells. In the pilot studies we have also found that some nanocarriers lacking affinity ligands fortuitously accumulate on the neutrophils residing in the pulmonary vasculature. Using these two types of nanocarriers may permit cell-specific delivery of distinct drugs to endothelium vs neutrophils. Dual drug delivery of distinct pharmacological interventions in these adjacent cells may enable alleviation of the endothelial collateral damage concomitantly with desirable modulation of neutrophil activity. In this project, we will devise these dual drug delivery system(s), characterize their mechanism of action and appraise their benefit/risk ratio in pre-clinical translational studies in animal models of respiratory infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH CTR AT TYLER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infectious respiratory diseases such as those caused by nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) are acquired through environmental exposures that remain largely under-described. Every day, millions of people inhale hazardous aerosol emissions from erupting volcanoes globally; our evidence supports NTM are hitchhikers on volcanic ash that together overcome innate immune control by lung cells to establish infection. In this proposal, microbiological, molecular, and immunological assays and human lung cells from healthy donors will be studied to reveal the immunological mechanisms of front-line lung cells to NTM and volcanic ash, providing critical new information to improve respiratory health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The health risks related to heart failure (HF) – the fastest growing cardiovascular disorder – are particularly grave for America's expanding population of older adults, for whom HF is the primary reason for hospitalization, and who experience the highest burden of serious adverse outcomes related to HF hospitalization (re-admission and death). HF hospitalization also poses serious health risks for family caregivers, particularly spouses/partners, who are critical to patients' successful post-discharge transition to home, but not without substantial cost to their own health and well-being (increased strain, mortality risk). This proposal employs innovative methods to advance our understanding of how older hospitalized HF patients and spouse/partner caregivers monitor and respond to HF symptoms together during the post-discharge period, and how dyadic symptom monitoring and clinical biomarkers of HF progression can enhance our knowledge of mechanisms of risk, and uncover potential targets for precision interventions to support patient, caregiver, and dyad health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The consequences of overnutrition on human health are perilous, even though the prevalence of metabolic disease in adults is so high that it may constitute a new normal. The goal of this project is to develop a clearer understanding of the metabolic features that influence glucose production and da mage in the kidney and liver during obesity so that they may be better targeted to reduce the burden of disease. This proposal incorporates a significant training and development plan aimed at shifting my career toward research independence.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The majority of people in the US are overweight or obese and the lack of effective, long-term treatment options lends a particular urgency towards understanding the underlying physiologic mechanisms driving obesity. The proposed studies in this R01 proposal will lay the foundation for future studies targeting brain glucose transport and metabolism alterations to treat and prevent the central nervous system complications of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latinos/as face Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) disparities and are projected to see the largest increase in United States dementia cases by 2060. To address this impending public health crisis, the proposed project will examine longitudinal changes in cognition based on cardiovascular disease risk, acculturation, small vessel disease, and ADRD biomarkers among diverse Latinos/as 50+ years old. Using a biopsychosocial approach, this project will provide nuanced characterization of risk factors for ADRD in this population which may lead to better informed clinical care, novel interventions, and may ultimately reduce ADRD disparities in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is aimed at examining the role of a specific structure, the mediodorsal thalamus, in cognitive control and flexibility. Our work will provide fundamental insights into thalamic circuits and how they may control cortical processing. Additionally, it will set the stage for future translational studies involving thalamic vulnerability in disease and the use of the thalamus as a target for intervention in a variety of cognitive disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will analyze existing and publicly available data to identify genetic variants that either directly influence risk of orofacial clefts (OFCs) and subtypes or moderate the effects of maternal smoking, alcohol, and multivitamin/folate exposures during pregnancy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: COPD is a multifactorial pathology and PLWH demonstrate and higher incidence of COPD even when adjusted for the smoking status. HIV tat and TGF-β signaling (upregulated by Tat, cigarette smoek and in COPD), dysregulate the airway microRNAome and this can have downstream effects on the transcriptome and signaling pathways leading to pathological hallmarks of COPD. Understanding the mechanism of miRNA dysregulation and its downstream effects can identify targets for intervention, and silencing HIV transcription by CRISPR based inactivation of cellular cofactor CyclinT1 only in HIV-infected cells can decrease the Tat burden in the airways and improve outcomes in HIV associated COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Disorders such as Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) and schizophrenia are caused or worsened by stress exposure, and have devastating effects on patients and their families. The proposed research will examine the receptor subtypes through which stress impairs higher brain functioning in order to design more effective therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Sleep and feeding are two essential and mutually exclusive behaviors that are homeostatically regulated, and deviations from the relative stability that is maintained by both feeding and sleep homeostasis can have negative consequences for an individual health. In this proposal, we will uncover the logic by which individual sleep-promoting neurons can integrate sensory stimuli and internal state variables to modulate behavioral flexibility between sleep and feeding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative How disseminated tumor cells (DTCs) initiate the metastatic colonization process in the bone remains poorly understood. We discovered that DTCs may establish direct cell-cell contact with mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) in the perivascular niche, and co-migrate toward the site of osteogenesis upon activation of bone turnover. We propose to investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying DTC-MSC interaction and assess the impact of bone turnover on early-stage bone colonization of breast cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE GABA is an important metabolite regulating neuron function as well as cell growth, differentiation and migration. We have discovered a transporter protein, SLC45A4, which controls the GABA levels in cancer cells. Our goal is to figure out how SLC45A4 works in the context of GABA production and how to regulate GABA level through SLC45A4.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Established smoking cessation medications effectively treat withdrawal symptoms but do little to address the powerful influence that cues and contexts have on smoking behavior. Across both basic and clinical research, β-adrenergic medications have demonstrated potential to reduce these influences by disrupting the key cognitive processes that unfold when smoking cues and contexts are encountered. This project will use neuroimaging to determine the effects of these medications on brain responses to smoking cues and contexts in human cigarette smokers, providing vital information on the mechanisms responsible for their effect and informing further treatment development efforts.
