IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because hearing loss in the U.S. affects two- thirds of adults age 70 and older, many of whom would have an improved quality of life given the partial restoration of hearing from a technological intervention called a bionic cochlear implant. This research aims to understand and improve speech understanding for older (>65 yrs) cochlear- implant users. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission to develop new knowledge and improve technologies to help treat disability, NIA’s mission to understand the biological effects of aging, and NIDCD’s mission to provide technological interventions for hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart attack (myocardial infarction) is a major killer in western society, so there is a drastic need for therapies to avoid myocardial injury. The heart is a very metabolically demanding organ, but there are still large gaps in our knowledge of cardiac metabolism. We have identified several key metabolic events that take place during and after heart attack, and this project will investigate how manipulating these events can impact the outcome of heart attack. Specifically, under conditions of chronic hyperglycemia such as seen in diabetes, there is an elevation of the metabolite methylglyoxal (MGO), and this is generally thought to be detrimental to the heart. However, we have identified novel mechanisms in which acute MGO may elicit beneficial signaling effects to protect against heart attack.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accumulating evidence indicates that astrocytes, classically considered to serve passive support roles, play important functions in learning, memory, and information processing by actively modulating neuronal activity and synaptic function. The present proposal aims to define the functional role of astrocytes in amygdala-related behavioral tasks using in vivo and in ex vivo preparations. Defining the impact of astrocyte-neuron signaling on amygdala function may reveal novel mechanisms involved in brain disorders, such as Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) and excessive anxiety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE If this work demonstrates that CBD interacts specifically with signaling pathways relevant to targeted cancer therapies, this result would strongly imply that use of CBD by individuals with cancer, either prior to diagnosis, or during or after treatment with targeted therapies, could significantly affect disease prognosis, response to treatment, or likelihood of disease recurrence. Such interactions could add a previously unappreciated variable to the performance of clinical trials for new cancer therapeutics. In addition, should CBD be found to synergize with clinically useful drugs currently used or under investigation for cancer therapy, the proposed work may provide the basis for preclinical and clinical studies to advance innovative new combination treatments involving CBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  Kidneys, as a major organ for waste removal, are being exploited to accelerate the body clearance of “off-target” engineered nanoparticles to meet FDA regulation for the clinical translation of nanomedicines, which demands thorough understanding of nanoparticle transport and interactions at the fundamental level. However, renal proximal tubule is often overlooked in comparison with extensive studies on glomerular filtration of engineered nanoparticles even though proximal tubule is the most active site involved in concentration, retention and reabsorption of the filtered proteins through glomeruli. In this application, we aim to fundamentally understand the size, charge and surface-chemistry dependencies in the transport and interactions of ultrasmall engineered nanoparticles in both normal and injured proximal tubules, laying down a foundation for developing kidney-safe nanomedicines that can be used in clinics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement The neural crest is a multipotent stem-cell population that forms an amazingly diverse set of derivatives, including neurons and glia of the craniofacial skeleton, peripheral nervous system, skin melanocytes, and portions of the heart. Because they are involved in many birth defects, including cleft lip and palate, and cancers (e.g. melanoma, neuroblastoma), our results on their normal development will yield important clues regarding mistakes causing abnormal development and tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The anesthetic ketamine is efficacious as a fast-acting antidepressant in patients with treatment refractory major depression, but its potential for long-term antidepressant use is limited by its abuse potential and capacity to produce dissociative effects. Ketamine is rapidly metabolized to a number of biologically active metabolites that are pharmacologically distinct from ketamine, including (2R,6R)-hydroxynorketamine, which in preclinical models, shares ketamine’s therapeutic effects without its side effects. We propose to utilize preclinical models including electrophysiological characterization of brain synapse function to further determine the relevant antidepressant- and side-effect profiles of ketamine’s hydroxynorketamine metabolites, which will lead to important mechanistic insights relevant to the development of next generation fast-acting antidepressants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative: Surgery is the most important treatment method for oral cancer, and intraoperative histopathology via frozen section is the gold standard to diagnose positive margins and to guide surgical resections. However, frozen section histopathology requires specialized equipment and expert personnel that are not available in many settings including rural US, and surgeons struggle with the need to ensure complete tumor removal while sparing normal tissue. The DeepDOF platform developed here will provide an affordable tool to rapidly examine tumor margins of large areas of fresh tissue resections, allowing precisely guided surgical resections at the point of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The repair of damage to neurons in both the central and peripheral nervous systems depend on precise regulation of microtubule dynamics and tubulin post-translational modifications. An understanding of how tubulin PTMs contributes to neuronal injury repair will inspire the development of new therapeutic agents to assist in neuronal injury repair, but we first require an understanding when and where tubulin PTMs appear during the repair process. Probes to detect tubulin PTMs in living cells do not currently exist, but we have developed a pipeline to convert pre-existing monoclonal antibodies to fluorescent, single chain variable fragment (scFv) constructs that allow us to record the formation of PTMs in real-time, and will use this platform to generate a complete panel of probes so investigate the role of tubulin PTMs in neuronal development, regeneration and repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The development of versatile and practical methods for organic synthesis is critical to the discovery and manufacture of molecular structures relevant to understanding biological mechanisms and treating human disease. In this proposal, we will pursue the design of new reactions and elucidation of fundamental reactivity principles in the areas of Ni-catalyzed cross coupling and phosphoranyl radical catalysis. In so doing, this research will provide new tools for the selective and efficient preparation of biologically relevant small molecules from simple and abundant starting materials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Genomic organization in the 3-dimensional nuclear space emerges as a new epigenetic regulator of transcriptional specificity that affects various developmental processes. The olfactory system provides an ideal system for deciphering in vivo the structural principles and regulatory significance of nuclear architecture, since it utilizes this regulation of the nuclear architecture for the monogenic and monoallelic expression of olfactory receptor genes. Thus, our experiments are likely to reveal generally applicable principles for the role of mRNA in the formation of activating genomic compartments during neuronal differentiation and to uncover perturbations in genomic compartmentalization that are linked to neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Dysfunction to insulin secreting cells causes diabetes. Insulin-secreting cells show extensive electrical communication to regulate insulin secretion, and this communication is disrupted during diabetes. Understanding how this electrical communication is disrupted in diabetes will identify targets for retaining normal electrical communication and insulin secretion, thus providing potential drug targets for diabetes prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early life exposures such as a diverse microbiome are inversely related to the risk of developing allergic diseases and asthma. We will use multi-omics techniques to test whether traditional agrarian microbial exposures and colonization promote immune development and airway epithelial cell functions in young children to reduce the risks of respiratory illnesses, allergies and asthma. The results of these studies of traditional agrarian exposures and health benefits will provide critical information that can be used to improve the health of all children.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative Our proposed project will test the implementation of the NHLBI-funded NEW Soul program and how the program can lead to significant improvements in dietary and weight outcomes. The goal of this study is to develop a ready to adopt intervention in African American owned vegan restaurants. This study will test an entirely remotely delivered behavioral intervention that has the ability to be scaled up so that reach of this treatment approach is broad.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In humans and in monkeys neurological findings, functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), and electrophysiology have all converged to show that the object recognition part of the visual pathway is divided up into domains specialized for processing specific object categories, such as faces, text, places, and body parts; these domains underlie complex social behavior, and astonishing skills like fluent reading. The project goal is to explore how early experience interacts with innate programs to generate the remarkable selectivity of neurons in these domains. Early life experiences clearly can have long lasting consequences, and treating these consequences requires an understanding of how some kinds of experience, or the deprivation thereof, can permanently change how the brain processes visual information.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE  While monoclonal antibodies inhibiting immune checkpoints (ICI) are able to restore anti-tumor immunity and have dramatically changed the therapeutic options for many cancer patients, up 60% of patients will experience immune-related adverse events (irAE) depending on the tumor type and ICI. The importance of predicting and managing ICI-related adverse events has already been identified as a critical gap in knowledge and clinical practice. Targeting a common molecular node of integration for the innate immune system in irAE, we have discovered a novel positron emission tomography (PET) radiopharmaceutical that we propose to drive into a first-in-human safety/dosimetry Phase 0/1 trial for whole-body imaging and quantitative surveillance of ICI- mediated irAE by PET.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The MYC oncogene is the most common cancer gene involved in human cancer and is overexpressed in over half of all cancers. However, there has been a paucity of small molecule MYC inhibitors amenable to in vivo efficacy studies. We have developed new small molecule inhibitors of MYC with in vivo efficacy and tolerability that we will use to probe MYC function in vitro and vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ABCD Study consortium uses multimodal brain imaging, cognitive and clinical assessments, bioassays, mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and social functioning in 11,878 9-10 year-olds to be followed over 10 years, to determine the effects of substance use on adolescent brain and cognitive development. This ABCD Research Project Site will follow and assess participants enrolled in the study. These data will be shared with the scientific community to address a comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Drosophila is a model system used to map neural circuits and study cell firing during innate behaviors, such as feeding; to understand how neuromodulation regulates behavior or encodes memories, we need tools to examine multiple neuromodulators throughout a circuit. Here, we will develop new multiplexed tools to study neuromodulator interactions in Drosophila during sugar feeding. These tools are critical to understanding how genetics, behavior, or disease alter neuromodulator release, and will facilitate using Drosophila as a model organism for studying neuromodulation in neurological diseases, such as schizophrenia, compulsive eating, and addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The increasing prevalence of HIV drug resistance is a threat to HIV treatment and prevention. An HIV drug resistance database that curates, annotates, and synthesizes the primary data from many studies will be an invaluable research resource to the many researchers performing drug resistance surveillance, managing persons with HIV, and discovering new antiviral drugs. The proposed project will advance research to combat the threat that HIV drug resistance poses to containing the HIV pandemic.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Only 4% of the human proteome (20,171 human proteins) has been liganded by chemical probes. The majority of the proteome is undruggable by small molecules. Cyclic peptides are considered as promising molecules to address the undruggable targets, but its larger molecular mass and more complex secondary structures result in unpredictable and almost always low cell permeation, significantly limiting their utility as drug candidates. This proposal will develop analytical assays and tools for the detection and screening of cell-penetrating cyclic peptides as tool compounds for platform development. Screening results will be used to build machine learning models of permeation and inform its applications in next-generation diagnostics and therapeutics.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this work is to better understand the impaired phospholipid metabolism in the glaucomatous trabecular meshwork (TM) tissue. Proposal will evaluate the enzymatic activities in the phospholipid metabolism pathways. Successful completion of this research will yield new insight into the phospholipid metabolic impairment in the TM and their possible potential modulation in the treatment of glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Disease-modifying treatments are urgently needed to slow the progression of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), the most common neurodegenerative disorder that leads to dementia and dependency world-wide. Microglia and blood monocytes that enter the brain, can both positively and negatively impact AD progression and our exciting preliminary data suggests that Kv1.3 channels expressed by brain immune cells represent therapeutic targets to mitigate detrimental neuroinflammation in AD. In this proposal, we will perform in-vivo mechanistic and therapeutic studies in pre-clinical models of AD with the overall goal of laying the pre-clinical foundation for translation of Kv1.3 blockers to humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute Lung Injury is a devastating and prevalent condition with poorly understood links to the gut microbiome. I propose to study how host control of a key gut bacterium changes pulmonary metabolite exposure from the gut microbiome and downstream inflammation during Acute Lung Injury. This project will lay the foundation for future studies defining how gut bacteria change lung function in alignment with NHLBI strategic vision 1.CQ.07.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Aging with HIV may be associated with a greater impairment in physical function and worse fatigue, contributing to an impaired healthspan; few therapies are effective in slowing physical function decline or improving fatigue in people with or without HIV. Here we propose to test two exercise regimens of varying interval and intensity (high-intensity interval training vs continuous moderate-intensity exercise) on changes in physical function, fatigue, and mitochondrial bioenergetics. Furthermore, we will explore the impact of a biobehavioral coaching intervention vs control on adherence to physical activity following the supervised exercise intervention.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Oxytocin is a maternal hormone important for childbirth, parent-child bonding, and social cognition. However, it is unclear how, when, or where oxytocin acts in the brain to enable successful maternal care, or if oxytocin is involved in social transmission of parental behaviors from experienced care-takers to new care-takers. The experiments to be performed in this proposal provide essential data on the action of oxytocin in the brain, required for improvement of therapeutic strategies for treatment of maternal neglect or other conditions relating to incorrect processing and behavioral responses to social stimuli.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: MAKERERE UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Uganda is currently scaling up proven malaria control interventions, but these efforts are not sufficient to adequately reduce the high malaria burden in the country, and resurgence after discontinuation of control measures has been experienced. These observations highlight an urgent need for continued research that informs optimal malaria interventions, and thus a necessity for the training of Ugandans to lead this research. Improved in-country expertise in epidemiology, translational research, and implementation science will be critical to assist the Ministry of Health in establishing effective policies for the better control and eventual elimination of malaria in Uganda.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Nucleophosmin mutations (NPM1c) are among the most common aberrations in acute myeloid leukemia, however, the mechanism of action is poorly understood and there is a desperate need for targeted treatment options. We recently uncovered a novel link between NPM1c and the MLL histone methyltransferase complex through the use of Menin-MLL interaction inhibitors, which are able to reverse leukemic self-renewal programs. In this study we seek to define the chromatin changes induced by mutant NPM1c and how it employs the MLL complex to regulate leukemic self-renewal.

PHR: The National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK) is providing funds to establish the coordinating unit (CU) for the Innovative Science Accelerator (ISAC) Program. The CU will coordinate the interactions of the ISAC awardees, provide financial management for opportunity pool programs, interact with the NIDDK Program Officers and External Expert Panel, support the annual ISAC scientific meetings as well as provide a national web portal for ISAC in order to disseminate information and provide an organizational infrastructure for the program. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: A major goal in HIV infection and for the NIH is to improve diagnosis of ongoing cognitive impairment as well as monitor brain health with the advent of new therapies and cure tactics. This proposal demonstrates that extracellular vesicles shed from neurons into the peripheral blood have newly discovered proteins that correlate with cognitive impairment and differ in men versus women. We will correlate these biomarkers with neuroimaging and develop a panel of proteins for prognosis and diagnosis of neurocognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most common form of dementia globally, but current therapies only treat its symptoms but cannot stop disease progression. Using genetic tools combined with high-resolution synaptic imaging to manipulate and monitor the central hallmark of AD—degenerative synapse loss, we will investigate its molecule and cellular mechanisms in the AD brain. The proposed studies will examine a new paradigm essential to axonal and synaptic degeneration and potentially identify novel strategies that may ultimately transform current therapies to protect synaptic connection and cognitive function in AD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Type 2 Diabetes (T2D) and several life-threating complications of T2D share, as a major cause, insulin resistance for which the etiology is not fully understood, thus limiting the ability to develop highly effective and safe insulin- sensitizing medications. Palmitic Acid Hydroxy Stearic Acids (PAHSAs), endogenous lipids with potent insulin- sensitizing effects in obese T2D mice, are highly associated with insulin-sensitivity in humans and markedly down-regulated in the adipose tissue and serum of insulin resistant individuals. Combining cutting-edge, unbiased and synergetic approaches, we will determine the mechanisms responsible for the down-regulation of PAHSAs in insulin-resistant individuals and identify the enzymatic program responsible for the synthesis and degradation of PAHSAs in mammalian cells, providing novel therapeutic avenues to prevent or treat insulin resistance and T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using EEG to better understand the neural mechanisms of language acquisition in the context of neurodevelopmental disorders such as Fragile X Syndrome (FXS) and autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is crucial to the development of targeted drug and behavioral-based interventions to improve developmental outcomes in these children. EEG-markers identified during this study could be used as an objective measure of language prognosis, treatment monitoring during clinical trials, and ultimately development of effective therapeutics. In addition, improved understanding of the similarities and differences between FXS and ASD can help generalize these findings to the broader ASD community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are a large number of motor dysfunctions in neonates that could arise by anomalous development of spinal cord microcircuits. A major deficit is our little knowledge about the organization of spinal cord microcircuits controlling motoneuron activity and how they develop and mature in newborns. We propose to study one subclass of genetically defined interneurons that we hypothesize plays major roles in coordinating muscles activities during motor behaviors. We will investigate their development and their role in maturing coordinated motor function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human immunodeficiency virus (HIV-1) envelope glycoproteins (Env) change shape to allow the virus to enter host cells and to evade host antibodies. Before HIV-1 encounters its receptors on the host cell, Env is in a pretriggered shape that is a key target for effective virus entry inhibitors and virus-neutralizing antibodies. Understanding this pretriggered Env shape, and how it is maintained despite HIV-1's variability, will assist efforts to design treatments and vaccines.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: There are no approved treatments for congenital cognitive impairments in individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). However, our preliminary results indicate that limited postnatal treatment with the hypothalamic peptide oxytocin can effect a life-long rescue of memory functions in the mouse model of Fragile- X Syndrome, the leading inherited cause of ASD. The proposed studies will test if postnatal oxytocin treatment rescues a range of social and episodic memory functions, and normalizes neurobiological processes underlying memory encoding in the Fragile X model mutants, and if these functional changes reflect direct oxytocin action on trophic signaling in the developing hippocampus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to understand how microbial metabolites can influence the behavior of animal hosts, using the simple animal host Caenorhabditis elegans. We will conduct molecular genetic analysis of how the detection of microbial molecules alters neuroendocrine signaling and behavioral responses of C. elegans, with the anticipation that our studies will reveal mechanisms by which host-microbe interactions can influence diverse aspects of host physiology and behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our research focuses on elucidating how adult neurons control mitochondrial localization under aging and nerve injury conditions. Accurate regulation of mitochondrial localization is essential for maintaining neuronal function in response to age and injury. An improved understanding of the signaling mechanisms underlying the regulation of mitochondrial localization will suggest therapeutic strategies to improve axon regeneration of injured neurons and treat neurological diseases associated with mitochondrial abnormalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The frequency-following response (FFR), a scalp-recorded neurophonic potential, is a widely-used metric of speech encoding integrity in healthy and clinical human populations. The translational potential of the FFR as a biomarker is constrained by poor understanding of its neural generators. This proposal leverages a cross-species and cross-level approach to provide mechanistic insight into the properties of the cortical source of the FFR, and elucidate the role of cortical feedback via cortico-collicular projections on modulation of the FFR as a function of stimulus context, arousal state, and category relevance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Longitudinal studies of structural racism and resulting inequalities in risk factors for Alzheimer’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease Related Dementias (AD/ADRD) are rare, especially in young adulthood. Additionally, effective population-level policies and interventions targeting structural racism to reduce racial inequalities in biological risk factors for AD/ADRD are sparse. The proposed study will create a database of multilevel, repeated, and prospective measures of structural racism; investigate the extent to which structural racism in education, residential, and criminal justice contexts shape Black-White inequalities in AD/ADRD risk; and use causal modeling techniques to evaluate the impact of structural interventions on documented racial inequalities in biological risk factors for AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Pulvinar Neuro LLC, TOWNSEND Transcranial current stimulation (TCS) is a non-invasive form of brain stimulation that is being studied as a treatment for several psychiatric disorders, including depression and schizophrenia. This proposal develops XCSITE 300, a cloud-enabled TCS device that delivers individualized closed-loop stimulation and can be used in large double-blind placebo-controlled studies either in a clinic or research laboratory (XCSITE 300 Clinic) or at-home (XCSITE 300 Home). This work is of impact in human health because it is a key step towards novel brain stimulation treatments for mental illness, including depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project examines a form of gene regulation by a molecular machine called condensin, which functions both in mitotic chromosome condensation and in interphase genome organization. Condensin is conserved from yeast to humans and mutations in condensin subunits have been linked to diseases such as microcephaly and cancer. An understanding of condensin’s role in gene regulation and development may lead to better treatments for these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The proposed research has public health implications because it will provide a multidimensional description of the lexical-semantic deficits seen in Latino Spanish-learning toddlers with early language delays and the supportive role of caregiver language input and interactions. This project is of particular relevance to NIH and NIDCD in that it aims to examine health disparities in dual-language learners with language impairments. The integration of a multidimensional approach and rich behavioral assessment in an understudied population will lead to better identification of, and intervention with, children with persistent language delays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to understand the communication and coordination of the moving parts within a molecular “recycling center” called the proteasome. The proteasome is an emerging drug target for numerous human diseases, including some cancers, several neurodegenerative disorders, and a number of infectious diseases. Understanding this communication will help us to design new treatments for these diseases that work by controlling protein recycling inside cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging causes arterial stiffness, which is a hallmark of cardiovascular diseases and related to vascular dementias. This project probes the role of neutrophil elastase, a neutrophil-specific protease, in age-related vascular damage and stiffness in mice. This study may shed new light on a novel therapeutic strategy to alleviate the development of aging-related cardiovascular diseases and vascular dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative. There is an urgent need to expand the number of underrepresented minorities in STEM. Hampton University proposes the implementation of the U-RISE program which endeavors to: 1) increase the number of students interested in research careers; 2) improve STEM retention rates; 3) improve academic performance and achievement in training eligible departments; 4) increase the number of students from Hampton pursuing and matriculating in PhD or MD/PhD programs in biomedical sciences; and 5) implement effective mentoring and enhanced opportunities for pre-U-RISE and U-RISE Scholars through formal mentor training and engagement of U-RISE faculty in program activities. Overall, the proposed curriculum and activities will continue to enhance students’ skills and prepare scholars for entry into top-ranked biomedical PhD or MD/PhD programs. This program will also improve the mentoring capacity of faculty at Hampton University.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Relevance This project will evaluate the accuracy of noninvasive methods for estimating brain connectivity in humans and monkeys, compare areal organization across species, and characterize individual variability of cortical organization using a multimodal parcellation derived from the Human Connectome Project. Results will be shared via a state-of-the-art database that stores extensively analyzed data. These efforts will increase our understanding of normal human brain circuitry and organization and may ultimately contribute to better diagnosis and treatment of brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Acute kidney injury (AKI) significantly increases the risk of developing chronic kidney disease (CKD). T cells and polymorphonuclear neutrophils (PMNs) play important roles during AKI-to-CKD transition. This proposal will seek to (1) identify the signals that home T cells and PMNs during AKI-to-CKD transition and (2) develop innovative translational nanoparticles that can selectively deliver siRNAs to knockdown these homing signals to slow or even prevent CKD progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The skin of the vast majority of patients with Atopic Dermatitis (AD) is colonized by Staphylococcus aureus bacteria that secrete toxins called superantigens, predominantly staphylococcal enterotoxin B. We propose to use a mouse model of AD to examine the mechanisms by which skin colonization by S. aureus and the SEB they secrete result in more severe food allergy in patients with AD. It is anticipated that the results obtained will lead to novel therapies for food allergy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PRC2 is a context-dependent tumor suppressor whose core components (e.g., EZH2, EED, or SUZ12) are inactivated in various cancer types, and PRC2-loss in cancer leads to enhanced cellular plasticity, aberrant activation of multiple signaling pathways, an immune-desert tumor microenvironment and resistance to immune checkpoint blockade. In selected cancer types, we uncovered that PRC2-loss enhances cytotoxic responses to DNMT1 inhibition and anti-tumor responses to immunogenic viruses through activation of double-stranded RNA (dsRNA)-sensing and signaling responses. We propose innovative and integrative approaches to dissect the molecular mechanisms and evaluate novel therapeutic strategies (e.g., DNMT1 inhibitors, synthetic dsRNA, second generation of engineered immunogenic viruses) in relevant PRC2-loss cancer models to facilitate future design of biomarker driven clinical trials in PRC2-loss cancers with the goal to improve outcomes in individuals with MPNST and other PRC2-loss cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Both insomnia and Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) are independent risk factors for cardiometabolic diseases; the leading causes of morbidity and mortality in the US for which the growing geriatric population is at elevated risk. PTSD and insomnia disorder frequently co-occur yet require unique treatments, thus the proposed project will evaluate the added benefits of treating residual insomnia symptoms with Cognitive- Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) following Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) for PTSD among understudied older adults with PTSD. Findings from this pilot study will expand our understanding of the relationships between evidence-based insomnia and PTSD treatments and key outcomes of sleep, PTSD symptoms, cardiometabolic health and quality of life in older adults with PTSD and insomnia while informing future research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Tsetse flies transmit sleeping sickness and Nagana diseases that are fatal to humans to their livestock in sub- Sahara, with no effective vaccines. Tsetse control using odor baited traps and targets is considered an effective strategy for control of these diseases. Studies proposed here will investigate chemical ecology and behavioral responses of tsetse flies to odors, formulate novel tsetse attractants and repellents and optimize them for routine control of tsetse and trypanosomiasis in Kenya.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The percentage of underrepresented minorities (URMs) graduating from bachelor programs far exceeds the URMs attaining PhDs in biomedical science. This disparity highlights the need to increase the diversity of URMs and other underrepresented groups in doctoral programs. This proposal seeks to implement an integrative curriculum that includes a specialized series of courses and workshops aimed at promoting critical thinking, while simultaneously immersing students in independent laboratory research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiac allograft vasculopathy is a pan-arterial disease that impacts 50% of patients within ten years of heart transplantation and is the cause of death for up to 1/3rd of patients. Currently our understanding of the mechanism of CAV and the standard modalities to diagnose CAV are insufficient. Achieving our aims will set the stage for a change in the diagnostic paradigm for cardiac allograft vasculopathy and advance our understanding of the pathophysiologic mechanism for the disease that impacts the majority of heart transplant recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The absence of Fragile X Mental Retardation Protein (FMRP) results in the most common single gene cause of hereditary autism spectrum disorder, which is also associated with hypersensitivity to sounds. Results may reveal therapeutic targets to treat hypersensitivity to or abnormal processing of sounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Opioid addiction extorts a tremendous toll on society, but a mechanistic understanding of how repeated exposure to opioids such as heroin ultimately results in compulsive drug-taking and -seeking behavior in some individuals, but not others, is still not known. We will generate comprehensive datasets aimed at understanding how single- cell gene expression, circuit connectivity, and activity are impacted by previous heroin seeking behavior. These data will provide a much-needed cellular atlas and resource for the addiction neuroscience community, and will likely lead to the identification of many novel cell type specific genes that can be leveraged for future study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Experiments proposed in this application will study the potential of a naturally occurring nucleotide, that activates the contractile protein myosin (dATP), to increase the performance of the heart. We have produced heart muscle cells derived from human stem cells that have elevated dATP (donor cells) and will determine how these donor cells affect ventricular function when transplanted into rodent hearts after a myocardial infarction. We will also determine how dATP affects the muscle contractile protein myosin that uses it to increase contraction.

PHR: Project Narrative Transplantation of hematopoietic (blood-forming) stem cells is a life-saving therapy used to cure blood and immune disorders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  It has been hypothesized that dysfunction of brain hubs underlies brain network changes and neuro- pathophysiology of numerous brain disorders, but directly testing this hypothesis in humans is challenging. The proposed research will elucidate the causal impact of short-term and long-term suppression of a hub on brain network organization, function and behavior using an awake rodent model. Such knowledge will help reveal the neural substrates causing large-scale brain network changes, and provide insight into understanding the neuro- pathophysiology of brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The current application proposes studies to elucidate the mechanisms, role and importance of senescent A1 astrocytes and microglia in chronic neuroinflammation after traumatic brain injury (TBI). Preclinical studies are also proposed to determine the therapeutic efficacy of targeting senescent A1 astrocytes and microglia to inhibit chronic neuroinflammation and improve long-term outcome after TBI. If successful, the studies could provide hope of a therapy that could be used months or even years after TBI, where there are now no treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Although antiretroviral therapy (ART) results in successful suppression of HIV and a decrease of AIDS progression, a substantial proportion of people living with HIV have elevated risk for chronic kidney disease, which leads to increased mortality. To thoroughly investigate the molecular system influencing kidney function and disease, we will conduct a longitudinal study using multi-omics approaches (i.e., epigenomics, genomics and transcriptomics) and methods of causal inference. This study aims to identify and replicate epigenomic markers and their related molecular functions to understand inter-individual variability of kidney function and chronic kidney disease, and to identify novel targets for improved treatment and prevention among people living with HIV of African ancestry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The successful completion of the MONA-LISA project will provide detailed knowledge of the immunological, genomic, and metabolic characteristics of people who are at risk for the development of systemic lupus erythematosus and subsequently go on to develop the disease. This will enable clinical researchers to develop better clinical trials to test novel therapies that prevent the development of autoimmune diseases such as lupus. These data will also allow health care providers to better diagnose patients with early lupus features before they develop permanent organ damage and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Parkinson's disease is the second most common neurodegenerative disease, affecting 1% of Americans older than 65. Parkinson's disease is a complex disease affecting a wide range of organ systems and impacting patients in a variety of ways. The motor features of Parkinson's disease including tremor, gait and balance dysfunction are well known, but non-motor features of Parkinson's disease such as those affecting cognition, sleep, and gut absorption are wide ranging and less well known but have a significant impact on patient quality of life. The management of Parkinson's disease is complex and subspecialty care by a movement disorders neurologist is important for extending quality of life for as long as possible. This project seeks to develop improved technology for use in rural environments to aid in the diagnosis and management of Parkinson's disease patients.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: OVERALL - NARRATIVE The Washington LHS E-STAR Center will build a consortium of research organizations that are leaders in LHS training and research, and diverse primary care organizations (PCOs) across the state, where early career scientists receive training and mentorship for the purpose of transforming primary care. The Center will (1) build new infrastructure for bidirectional research-health care partnerships, (2) train 7 early-career researchers in embedded LHS research in partnership with PCO leaders, and (3) lead embedded LHS research in participating PCOs. These activities will enable the Center to achieve its goals of producing a diverse set of independent scientists with a solid foundation in LHS research who can change the paradigm of primary care research through research that rapidly develops and implements evidence; and simultaneously building LHS capacity in safety net primary care settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Chronic itch is a debilitating disease that can have serious clinical consequences. Our studies suggest that the sensory neuron expressed MrgprA1 and its human homolog MRGPRX4 are novel itch receptors and contribute to multiple chronic itch conditions including medication caused itch side effect, allergic contact dermatitis, and uremic itch. Therefore, functional analysis of MrgprA1/X4 will not only provide a mechanistic understanding of itch but also open new avenues for the development of novel itch therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative Ourproposed research is highly relevant to public health because it willprovide fundamental knowledge about molecular mechanisms regulating astrocytic scar progression and promising new targets for treating chronic SCI. We will investigate functions of long noncoding RNAs and their target genes and pathways in astrogliosis after SCI usingcutting-edge technology and innovative research strategies.These studies are important for developing novel therapeutic interventions to improve the injury environment and facilitate axonal regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Up to 25% of diabetic patients develop chronic non-healing ulcers in their lifetime, which present significant infection risks given the poor vascularity and immunodeficiency related to diabetes. More generally, chronic non-healing wounds affect an estimated 6.5 Million Americans with annual cost of $50 billion dollars. This project seeks to develop an effective, novel peptide-based treatment to promote wound healing and to improve the quality of life for patients suffering from chronic wounds, especially in the diabetic populations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Half of patients with heart failure (HF) have preserved pumping function of the heart (HFpEF). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The Indiana University (IU) Comprehensive Training Program in Clinical Pharmacology, currently in its 29th year, has a track record of excellence in training successful clinician scientists able to implement the science of clinical pharmacology and therapeutics in academic, pharmaceutical industry/biotechnology and drug regulatory agencies. We propose to continue this successful training program in a setting of a well-established Division of Clinical Pharmacology, multiple well-funded and experienced investigators to mentor trainees, a pipeline of highly qualified applicants, and outstanding institutional training environment and support. Our goal is to continue generating clinical scientists that can augment translation of new therapies into clinical practice and ensure safe and beneficial effects of medications.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This innovative study seeks to understand how the use of specific food parenting practices varies across time and context, and how various food parenting approaches impact children’s dietary intake over the long term. A longitudinal study with 240 parent-child pairs will be conducted with data collection via state-of-the-art measures, including EMA and interview-led 24-hour diet recalls, every 6 months for two years. The proposed study represents a significant and necessary next step to inform the development of clinic-based recommendations and public health interventions that account for- and are responsive to- daily challenges found to influence parent’s use of specific food parenting practices.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Animal embryos undergo precisely timed cellular/nuclear divisions that rely on histone protein availability. While the embryo initially relies on histones donated from its mother, at some point, the embryo must begin manufacturing its own histones. I propose to examine the role of pioneering transcription factors in embryonic histone gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the fundamental role that risk plays in evaluating choice options as well as the role sensitivity to risk plays in psychiatric illness, including anxiety disorders at one extreme and health risk behaviors like substance use at another other, an understanding of the neurobiology of risk remains elusive. Here, we take advantage of a new technology to directly measure serotonin, norepinephrine and dopamine on a sub-second basis to investigate the neurocomputational role of these neurotransmitters in risky choice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) is a chronic disease in which allergic inflammation and tissue damage eventually lead to scarring and fibrosis of the esophagus. This proposal seeks to elucidate the role of epithelial- derived transforming growth factor- (TGF) and lysyl oxidase (LOX) in tissue remodeling and fibrosis. Results from this study will lead to a more precise understanding of role of the esophageal epithelium in pathologic remodeling in the esophagus and will provide the basis for future work targeting the prevention and reversal of fibrosis in EoE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research described in this proposal aims to challenge traditional views of brain aging by using the rejuvenating effects of exercise-induced blood factors to obtain a mechanistic understanding of the molecular and cellular events required to counteract the effects of aging in the old brain. These studies will have significant translational potential, identifying molecular pathways that could be targeted for novel therapies to restore age-related cognitive dysfunction and potentially treat dementia-related neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Rotavirus (RV) infections kill an estimated 130,000-215,000 young children globally in spite of the recent introduction of vaccines, highlighting the importance for continued study of this pathogen. Our proposed studies are designed to understand how RVs take advantage of key host cellular pathways involved in the accumulation of fat (lipid) and cellular membranes to form specialized sites in the infected cell critical for virus replication. We expect the knowledge gained from our studies will help (1) understand how RVs and many other viruses cause disease, (2) explain why RV infections in children become life-threatening, and (3) lead to new treatment and antiviral therapies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The American Cancer Society estimates that in 2019 around 74,000 people will be diagnosed with non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL). The majority of these tumors arise from B cells (B-NHL) at the germinal center stage of differentiation. Using mouse models of B-NHL that recapitulate the human disease, we will determine the function and potential targeting of Coactivator-Associated Arginine Methyltransferase 1 (CARM1) in NHBCL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to develop a comprehensive learning-based causal inference framework to generate high-throughput drug repurposing hypotheses for Alzheimer’s' disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD) from real-world data and biomedical knowledge bases. The generated drug repurposing hypotheses will be validated with diverse data sources and approaches including (1) using multi-omics data based on the network medicine approach, and (2) using the trial emulation approach and with i) high-quality cohorts’ data from the National Alzheimer's Coordinating Center (NACC), and ii) a prospective RWD-based cohort. The developed algorithms and software tools will be made publicly available and widely disseminated in the AD/ADRD research communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic pain is a common, morbid sequela following burn injury. Currently, there are no therapies to prevent chronic pain development after burn injury; therefore, the goal of this research is to provide evidence on the effectiveness and corresponding immune mechanisms of vitamin D to prevent chronic pain following major thermal burn injury. This work has the potential to improve pain outcomes, understand important mechanisms through which vitamin D reduces pain, and provide new mechanistic insights into the transition from acute to chronic pain following burn injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NYU LONG ISLAND SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease is one of the risk factors for nonalcoholic fatty liver diseases (NAFLD), an emerging metabolic disease in the US population. The proposed research will lead to many discoveries that will significantly improve the health of US citizens and others suffering from nonalcoholic fatty liver disease by revealing new concepts and ideas that can be used to develop therapies for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH's mission that pertains to developing new approaches and fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial endophthalmitis remains a significant cause of visual loss in patients undergoing eye surgeries. As the aging population grow worldwide, the demand for cataract and other ocular surgeries increases as well, and so too will the incidence of endophthalmitis. In this study, we aim to investigate the role of NAD+ in protecting the eye during infection and provide the rationale to consider NAD+ boosting supplements as an adjunct therapy to treat bacterial endophthalmitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart disease during pregnancy with no previous history of cardiovascular disease is uncommon; however, its prevalence has increased over the past decades as more women delay their pregnancy. Heart disease during pregnancy bears a worse prognosis than in non-pregnant women for unclear reasons. Here, we propose to study what makes the heart in late pregnancy be more vulnerable to heart disease and to find potential therapeutic targets for the treatment of pregnant women who are at higher risk of cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use disorder (OUD) is a major epidemic in the United States, and despite a severe impact on women, very little information is known regarding mechanisms underlying OUD in females or sex-specific differences in the development, expression, and molecular mechanisms of OUD. Thus, the goal of this F30 application is to fill these research gaps using a novel rat model of OUD with fentanyl, and in doing so, provide foundational information on sex differences in OUD that can be used to refine the use of already approved treatments for OUD in women versus men as well as guide the development of new sex-specific treatments for OUD. These studies will also address gaps in my training and facilitate my development as an independent physician scientist specializing in substance use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative CNS barrier breakdown occurs in a wide variety of CNS diseases, from acute brain injury or infection to neurodegenerative disorders like Alzheimer’s Disease, disrupting ion balance needed for neuronal function and exposing the cerebrospinal (CSF) fluid and brain tissue to blood contents and circulating, peripheral immune cells that upon entry can irreparably damage the CNS. As a result, barrier breakdown can have long lasting or permanent motor, behavioral and cognitive deficits in patients. This proposal focuses on an understudied and poorly understood part of the CNS barrier system, the arachnoid barrier in the meninges; our studies of this barrier will provide key insight into its development, function in regulating normal ionic, protein and cellular content of the CSF and its vulnerability in diseases like bacterial meningitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Type 2 diabetes can be treated with various glucose-lowering medications, but guidance to match each drug to the pathophysiology affecting an individual patient is lacking. We plan to leverage the DNA samples and data of consented 4,730 participants in the Glycemia Reduction Approaches in Diabetes: A Comparative Effectiveness (GRADE) Study to conduct a genome-wide association study, in which we will identify genetic determinants of drug response, of glycemic traits relevant to specific modes of action, of side effects, and of diabetic complications. This pharmacogenomic resource will also enable the testing of polygenic scores constructed from established genetic variants for association with drug response endpoints, as a way to advance precision medicine in diabetes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Media literacy education (MLE) is an effective approach to sexual and relationship health promotion for young adult community college students, but little is understood regarding the incremental impact 0f MLE above traditional sexual health programming, the mechanisms underlying MLE’s impact on health outcomes, or the long-term impact of MLE on sexual and relationship health behaviors. The purpose of this project is to conduct a three-arm randomized control trial with long-term follow-up to isolate the effects of MLE on health outcomes, examine potential mediators of MLE’s health effects, and evaluate the immediate and long-term impact of a MLE sexual and relationship health promotion program for community college students, Media Aware Sexual Health for Young Adults (MASH-YA). This project has the potential to advance theory and inform the development of future MLE health promotion programs, as well as to shift the paradigm towards community colleges implementing evidence-based sexual and relationship health programming.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The donor lung supply is inadequate to meet the ever-increasing need of patients awaiting transplant. Compounding this problem, the US lung transplant system does not consider all known donor and patient information available at time of an organ offer, missing the opportunity to maximize best use of organs and survival gained from each transplant. This research will contribute to the development of a system that will use all known data at the time of an organ offer to find the best donor and patient match improving utilization of available organs and maximizing transplant patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to decipher how two conserved output pathways from the retina to the brain cooperate to control gaze and mediate high-acuity binocular vision in a complex behavior (i.e., predation). Insights into the organization and function of visual pathways in health facilitate the identification of early disorganization and dysfunction in common diseases of the retina and the brain. In addition, knowledge about the function of specific pathways in visually guided behaviors establishes benchmarks for comparing competing strategies for vision restoration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Arenaviruses, such as Junín and Lassa, cause severe life-threatening hemorrhagic fevers and are recognized as Category A priority pathogens and important targets for vaccine development. Despite use of the classically derived live-attenuated Candid#1 strain of Junín virus in Argentina to protect against Argentine hemorrhagic fever, this vaccine has not been licensed in the US in part due to concerns regarding the stability of attenuation, which relies on a single mutation in the virus envelope glycoprotein (GPC). In this proposal, we will capitalize on our understanding of GPC structure and function to design and characterize recombinant Candid#1 (rCan) viruses that enhance the genetic and phenotypic stability of attenuation, with the long-term goal of developing a safe and effective second-generation rCan vaccine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to establish a Summer Institute in Biostatistics and Data Science at the University of Cal- ifornia, Irvine. The institute will attract new students to the ﬁelds of Biostatistics and Biomedical Data Science. Students will be trained in methodology and computing and will apply this training to a data analysis project under guidance of biostatistics and biomedical science co-mentors. The investigators will make a concerted effort to recruit students from groups underrepresented in the biomedical and mathe- matical sciences. Students will receive career guidance, including advice about graduate school application process. 1

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because results from this study are expected to lead to improved regenerative medicine-based therapies for muscle damage after injury to the shoulder tendons. This is relevant to the NIH's mission as this research provides new methodologies that will lead directly to better treatments for rotator cuff injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hematopoiesis is the process by which blood cells form and replenishes the various cell types present in blood through differentiation of blood-forming stem and progenitors. Hematopoiesis requires a series of progressive cell fate decisions, which can go awry in diseases such as anemias. Here, the studies proposed are focused on how individual cells make these fate decisions to form specific cell types including red blood cells and platelets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance: Heart failure (HF), a progressive disease with a poor prognosis, is characterized by inflammation and the expansion of tissue-injurious macrophages in the heart; however, the specific macrophage populations and pathways responsible for cardiac injury, dysfunction, and fibrosis remain unclear. We will test a novel hypothesis for the pathogenesis of inflammation in HF - that it is driven in large part by macrophages in the failing heart expressing the protein CD206 and a subunit of the receptor for interleukin-4 (IL-4Ra). We further propose that therapeutically targeting these CD206+IL-4Ra+ macrophages represents a novel and effective approach to alleviating cardiac inflammation and reversing adverse cardiac remodeling in HF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE >200k people in the U.S. undergo cardiac catheterization for their stable coronary artery disease (CAD) each year to stratify risk of major adverse cardiac events in a patient population having a wide range of outcomes, with annual mortality rates varying by a factor of 6 between “low risk” and “high risk” stable CAD patients. Current imaging and non-imaging techniques for risk stratification and prediction of adverse events (such as myocardial infarction) based on independent indicators such as lesion structure and plaque composition are largely unsuccessful. By leveraging recent advances in ultrasound transducer array design, data reconstruction, high frame rate image formation, and catheter design, this project will develop an ultrasound imaging catheter designed to characterize the comprehensive coronary enviornment based on the full mechanics and hemodynamics surronding the stenosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity increases the risk of death from endometrial cancer and predisposes to high levels of insulin; however, it is unclear if these findings are directly linked. The growth of endometrial cancer cells is stimulated by insulin via the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway. This proposal will target the PI3K pathway in human endometrial cancer using a combination of dietary and pharmacologic strategies that reduce insulin together with small molecule inhibitors of PI3K to prevent the growth of endometrial cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By 2030, approximately 20% of the US population is expected to be 65 years and older, and so there is an urgent need for better understanding of the physiological changes and mechanisms that underlie normal and pathological aging. This research training grant will provide annual support for 5 pre-doctoral students and 3 postdoctoral fellows, and will represent an educational cornerstone of the OHSU Healthy Aging Alliance – an organization that involves basic and clinical researchers, health care providers, and also elderly representatives from the local community. The proposed Neuroscience of Aging, Neurodegeneration and Alzheimer's Disease program will thus provide trainees with a “bench-to-bedside” framework in which to conduct their research, and will better prepare them for future research careers that focus on the development of safe and effective therapies for aging-related neurological disorders.
PROJECT_TERMS: Aging;Alzheimer's Disease;Nerve Degeneration;Neurosciences
PROJECT_TITLE: Neuroscience of Aging, Neurodegeneration and Alzheimer's Disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Optogenetics is a powerful technique for modulating precisely selected neural circuits, but despite having numerous research and therapeutic applications, achieving neuromodulation that significantly impacts behavior in primates has proved challenging. Here we develop new optogenetic expression and stimulation techniques to achieve this goal in freely behaving primates. This will allow us to better study and develop translational therapies targeting the neural circuitry underlying a variety of neurological and psychiatric disorders in human populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD), including mild cognitive impairment (MCI), are becoming among the most prevalent causes of disability, death and healthcare costs worldwide. Sleep and circadian rhythm disturbances are common among individuals with MCI as well as their spouses/ partners and may increase risk of the development of ADRD in both patients and partners. This is the first study to systematically investigate sleep as a shared health behavior within couples in which one member has MCI, and the degree to which sleep and circadian disturbances impact both partners health and well-being, including cognitive decline and risk for ADRD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multidrug-resistant pathogens pose a serious public health problem that requires creative solutions. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Public health relevance statement) Inexpensive, reversible, and long-acting contraceptives for men are needed to help address world population growth and medical issues associated with unplanned pregnancy. The blood-testis barrier (BTB) and blood- epididymal barrier (BEB) pose major obstacles in developing male contraceptives, as these drugs must pass through these barriers to reach their targets. This work will facilitate the identification and development of new male contraceptives by determining how chemical features of a small molecule influence its transfer from the blood and accumulation behind these barriers.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative A stroke causes significant disruption in the ability of individuals to participate in functional activities that are associated with every-day living. Clinical guidelines recommend rehabilitation to address functional deficits, but the cost of that rehabilitation in skilled nursing and inpatient rehabilitation facilities is becoming increasingly unsustainable. The goal of this project is to examine whether a high intensity home-based rehabilitation approach can be successfully implemented and contribute to functional outcomes similar to those that are achieved in those costly facilities.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Evaluating the Implementation of High Intensity Home-Based Rehabilitation Following Stroke

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Loss of salivary gland function is a devastating condition. Millions of people lose salivary gland function from autoimmune disease or cancer radiation treatment, and therapies to promote gland repair are needed. Repair of salivary gland tissues requires re-growth of blood vessels that can support salivary gland tissue as it heals from damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women are twice as likely as men to experience psychiatric conditions involving dysregulation of emotional learning and memory, such as posttraumatic stress disorder and anxiety disorders. This project will test the novel hypothesis that this divergent vulnerability is conferred by female-specific engagement of a brain circuit that strengthens emotional memory. Elucidation of this circuit will lead to new gender-specific treatments for fear-based mental illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thousands of patients with non-breast/non-gastric cancer have tumors bearing amplification or mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase ERBB2/HER2, but lack effective, targeted treatment options. We hypothesize that the presence of HER2 genomic alterations increase the internalization rate of the receptor, a characteristic that can be exploited by a new class of therapeutics called antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs) to effectively treat these orphan diseases. In this proposal, we will utilize different preclinical models and samples from patients treated with anti-HER2 ADCs to uncover the biological variables that determine sensitivity to these agents, identify potential biomarkers for clinical responses, and determine whether irreversible HER2 kinase inhibitors such as neratinib can further enhance the efficacy of ADCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Sports-related concussion is a significant public health problem with approximately two to four million injuries occurring each year in the United States of America. Novel neuroimaging techniques play a critical role in elucidating underlying pathophysiological changes of the brain and serve as noninvasive markers for brain injury and recovery. The goal of this project is to advance clinical utility of novel neuroimaging methods via individualized analytic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The set of genes that cause Alzheimer’s disease (AD) are still far from clear. We propose to interrogate the contribution of these repeats to disease pathogenesis and their mechanism of action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although genetic studies of complex human traits have been tremendously successful in identifying thousands of genomic risk regions that harbor variants increasing risk, Unfortunately, the vast majority include individuals of European ancestry making the transferability to individuals with mixed ancestries (e.g., African Americans) challenging. In this proposal we develop and apply new statistical and experimental methods to build admixture-aware polygenic risk scores for complex traits. We leverage a unique data set of >230,000 admixed individuals whose genotypes are linked to electronic health records to develop and calibrate PRS in admixed populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer is a leading cause of death in the United States, and this study seeks to identify novel vulnerabilities of a class of particularly lethal tumors, including glioblastoma and prostate cancer. When cancers delete the tumor suppressor gene PTEN, they frequently co-delete a neighboring gene called ATAD1, which is important for mitochondrial protein quality control. We will investigate how loss of ATAD1 may make cancers more likely to activate intracellular signaling pathways that result in cell death, and how this trait could be targeted in cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Activation of brown adipose tissue (BAT) increases energy expenditure and facilitates futile cycling of fuels including glucose, fatty acids and amino acids, thereby improving energy and glucose homeostasis. Together with the beneficial effects of BAT on cardiometabolic health, studies in humans and in rodents made BAT a subject of research efforts to understand and treat obesity and related disorders. However, while BAT is composed of heterogenous adipocyte populations, the understanding of adipocyte heterogeneity and its significance in metabolic physiology and disease has been limited. The results obtained from this study will reveal the physiological function of a distinct adipocyte subpopulation in whole-body energy and glucose metabolism, leading to the identification of poteintial therapeutic target for the treatment of obesity and its associated metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontitis is a prevalent oral inflammatory disease that leads to destruction of the tooth-supporting tissues and has a significant public health impact and economic burden. Interleukin-22 is a functionally versatile cytokine which mediates one-way communication from immune cells to tissues and specifically it regulates inflammation, stem cell function and tissue regeneration. This project investigates the precise role of IL-22 in periodontitis aiming to develop IL-22-targeted autotherapies that can promote periodontal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A subset of adult and pediatric leukemias has rearrangements of the AF10 gene, which are associated with dismal survival outcomes. However, there are no clinically effective therapies targeting the rearranged AF10 gene. The overall objective of this application is to uncover mechanisms of oncogenesis in acute myeloid leukemia with AF10 gene rearrangements using genetic, proteomic and pharmacological approaches, which could lead to newer and safer targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Esophageal cancer rates are increasing in the United States, and surveillance of Barrett’s esophagus (BE) may prevent esophageal cancer. I propose to develop and evaluate an artificial intelligence algorithm capable of diagnosing cancer within BE at the time of endoscopy using confocal high-resolution microendoscopy (cHRME), a novel technology capable of cellular imaging of the esophagus. This algorithm would provide an immediate, accurate computer-assisted diagnosis, which would allow this technology to be widely used during BE surveillance in community and low-resource settings with substantial public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because nicotine addiction remains the number one cause of preventable death. The high concentration of nicotine, different nicotine formulations, and addition of flavors to only electronic cigarettes may exacerbate nicotine addiction and increase risks for nicotine-related diseases and disorders. Understanding the neurobiological and neurophysiological changes specific to these unique constituents will dramatically increase our understanding of their role in nicotine addiction and risks toward lifelong addictions to nicotine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Although cancer immunotherapy has revolutionized the treatment of advanced cancers, it only benefits patients with immunologically “hot” tumors, partly because we have not taken advantage of anti-cancer innate immunity. We recently identified cGAMP as a key danger signal that cancer cells send to our innate immune system in response to intrinsic DNA damage, and we have also uncovered how cancers overcome this detection by overexpressing the enzyme that degrades this signal. Here we propose to fully characterize the effects of extracellular cGAMP on cancer development and to develop strategies to selectively prevent its degradation in tumors, with the goal of identifying targeted anti-cancer immunotherapies with minimal side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a deadly disease that affects premature infants with a weakened intestinal barrier, exaggerated immune response, and an abnormal intestinal microbiota. We are examining a factor called IMP1 that is important in intestinal development, including impacting intestinal barrier function, the immune system, and extracellular vesicle (EV)-mediated communication. Results from our study will identify new therapeutic targets for NEC through a deeper understanding of IMP1 and its role in intestinal barrier maintenance and function.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Tropical Medicine Research Center (TMRC) Program comprises a set of institutes that conduct research on neglected tropical diseases for the development of prevention and therapeutic strategies. As the TMRC Program Coordinating Center (CC), RTI International will provide the administrative, communication, logistical, and operational resources to maximize the scientific productivity and public health impact of the TMRC research. These benefits will be realized by increasing coordination, collaboration, and information sharing among these diverse TMRCs and between the TMRCs and external stakeholders.
