IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The nervous system depends on long projections called axons that connect nerve cells across the human body. This project will identify new factors that control the vulnerability of axons to self-destruction in response to stress or damage. Insights from this project will identify new avenues for protecting axon function and improving clinical outcome in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As preterm infant survival continues to improve, uncertainty regarding the best treatment for hemodynamically significant patent ductus arteriosus (HSPDA) can have serious public health implications for this vulnerable population. A novel, US Food and Drug Administration approved duct occluder (ADO-II AS) now offers clinicians a minimally-invasive option for closing HSPDA, but its effectiveness in improving important patient outcomes, relative to supportive, noninterventional HSPDA management, is unknown. This project is relevant to NIH’s mission to understand the processes of human growth and development by determining via a multicenter randomized trial, whether percutaneous HSPDA closure using ADO-II AS improves cardiopulmonary and neurodevelopmental outcomes as compared to supportive, non-invasive therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: Diabetes mellitus accelerates cognitive decline in the growing aging population, and thus, development of specific therapeutic strategies to address DM induced cognitive impairment is of major clinical importance. Exosomes are naturally occurring nano extracellular vesicles that mediate intercellular communication by transferring their biomolecule content to recipient cells. Our preliminary data suggest that healthy cerebral endothelial cell-derived exosomes have potential for improving cognitive function in the aged DM rats. We therefore propose to develop a novel exosomes based therapy for DM-induced cognitive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: NARRATIVE Surgery is common in elders and appropriate postoperative pain management is critical, as poor management can impair recovery, lead to increased morbidity and decreased quality of life. The proposed research will develop evidence needed to identify elder patients at high risk for adverse postoperative pain outcomes. Models will be developed at a tertiary academic health center, validated at the Veterans Health Administration and disseminated to the community via a publicly available website and open source libraries.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Identifying Optimal Pain Management for Elders

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: In this proposal, noninvasive imaging biomarkers of glutamatergic system changes in Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathology are developed and evaluated. Specifically, magnetic resonance imaging biomarkers of synapse loss and changes in astrocytic density will be evaluated longitudinally in mouse models that recapitulate the human AD. Results from this work will contribute to the mechanistic understanding of the AD onset and progression and lead to validated and clinically translatable biomarkers that can facilitate the development and evaluation of the efficacy of disease modifying therapies and thereby contribute to enhanced diagnosis and management of patients in the AD spectrum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medical errors are the 3rd leading cause of death in the United States behind cancer and cardiovascular disease and the largest proportion of medical errors involve medications. These dispensing errors occur approximately 2,400,000 times every year in the United States alone and can result in patient safety issues and add unnecessarily to the already strained healthcare system.The objectives of this proposal are to: 1) design interpretable machine intelligence to double-check dispensed medication images in real-time; 2) evaluate changes in pharmacy staff trust due to the long-term use of interpretable machine intelligence; and 3) determine the effect of interpretable machine intelligence on long-term pharmacy staff work performance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed research is to understand the principles that permit nervous systems to distinguish external from internally-generated sensory stimuli. Here I propose to develop a small circuit model of this process using the antennal mechanosensory system of the fruit fly. The insights gained from a tractable genetic circuit model will enable us to understand how these mechanisms fail in disease, supporting the BRAIN Initiative’s mission to understand the neural circuit basis of a critical brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is a neglected tropical disease which is fatal if left untreated. Majority of VL cases in the world are reported from Eastern Africa, particularly Ethiopia, Sudan, and Kenya. The goal of this project is to study the risk factors that are associated with transmission of this infection in these high endemic countries, understand the ecology and behavior of sand flies which transmit this disease and identify potential host and parasite factors responsible for disease progression and pathogenesis. These studies will provide critical data required for developing control and prevention strategies for elimination of VL from Eastern Africa.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER

PHR: Project Narrative. Implementation science (ImS) is key to addressing the persistent challenges to HIV elimination in Uganda, but research capacity is still limited. Building on existing partnerships between Makerere University (MU), its affiliated HIV programs and the University of California, San Francisco, we have established a pioneer ImS Research Training Program at MU, built a strong foundation for ImS in Uganda, and influenced practices along the cascade of HIV care. The Program focus of the next period is to create sustained growth of the ImS research environment at MU and the application of ImS to HIV research and service delivery on a larger scale in Uganda. 1|Page

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Urinary tract obstruction (UTO) during fetal development is the most common cause of chronic kidney disease in children. Research now suggests that a specialized cell population -- called renal urothelium – shields the kidney from injury during UTO. By enhancing our understanding of renal urothelium and its protective actions, we can develop new ways to detect and treat kidney injury in children with UTO.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Addiction to tobacco products is exceedingly common in the United States, and nicotine withdrawal and subsequent relapse is a significant contributor to the addiction process. The goal of this project is to leverage our well-qualified research team, our innovative tools, and our incisive methods to identify mechanisms that support tobacco addiction. By identifying these mechanisms, our project will promote the development of new and more effective strategies to help people quit smoking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Huntington's disease (HD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that presents with progressive motor, psychiatric, and cognitive symptoms leading to early disability and mortality. No treatments to delay the onset or slow the disease progression exist yet. This project will provide fundamental insights into the role of the glymphatic system in HD and may reveal a mechanistic basis for identifying new therapeutics as well as potential biomarkers for HD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: The proposed study addresses insomnia and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), issues of critical importance that are related to Veterans’ social and occupational functioning and overall health. Insomnia is associated with a host of poor functional outcomes, and has long-term ramifications for Veterans’ health and wellbeing as they mature. Given that poor sleep is one of the most common concerns among Veterans, a behavioral treatment that directly addresses insomnia in this group is of utmost importance to the VA. Veterans report serious barriers to seeking care in mental health clinics, where behavioral insomnia treatment is most commonly provided, and that those most in need are least likely to seek services. Consequently, this treatment is designed to respond to all of these issues by examining the rehabilitative efficacy of a brief video- and telephone-facilitated treatment for insomnia for Veterans with PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New therapeutic strategies to enhance immunotherapy responses are desperately needed for small cell lung cancer (SCLC), a largely immune “cold” cancer for which outcomes have remained virtually unchanged for thirty years. Our preliminary data indicate that DNA damaging therapies (such as PARP inhibitors) may induce changes in the immune microenvironment that are distinct between SCLC subtypes or other biomarker-defined groups. This proposal will investigate therapeutic vulnerabilities of distinct SCLC subtypes to combinations of DNA damaging agents or replication stress targeting with immune checkpoint blockade and has the potential to be rapidly translated into effective, biomarker-driven approaches for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic kidney disease is an enormous and growing public health burden, and significant gaps in guideline- recommended care delivery exist for patients with DKD. This project aims to design and pilot an intervention of targeted, proactive, electronic nephrology consultation to improve care delivery for primary care patients with diabetic kidney disease in an urban public health system, with special attention toward minimizing racial and ethnic disparities. Through this proposal, insights gained from key stakeholders across multiple health delivery systems, as well as preliminary data and implementation experience, will inform the design and implementation of larger system-scale interventions for improving care delivery for diabetic kidney disease and preventing its complications, including cardiovascular disease, kidney disease progression, and kidney failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research aims to understand why some retinal ganglion cells survive degeneration when their neighbors perish, and to leverage these differences into new treatments for retinal ganglion cell degenerating diseases like glaucoma and optic neuropathy. We will focus on pathways related to cellular homeostasis, which are associated with multiple forms of age related neurodegeneration. The outcome will advance our understanding of neurodegeneration in retinal ganglion cells and begin the development of novel treatment strategies for these blinding diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An estimated 3.9 million fractures occur in the US with an annual economic burden of $116.9 billion in combined medical expenses and work loss. Management of pain arising from orthopedic fractures remains a challenge, as common analgesic medications either interfere with healing or possess potential for addiction. Completion of this proposal will establish a new therapeutic strategy for the care of pain due to orthopedic surgery and fractures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diagnosis of brain cancers requires high-risk neurosurgery to obtain tissue. Tumor cells shed DNA into the blood circulation and molecular analysis of this DNA may obviate the need for invasive surgeries. The work proposed here aims to demonstrate that methylation profiling of circulating DNA can accurately diagnose, discriminate, monitor response to treatment, and detect early tumor recurrence in both primary and metastatic CNS tumors, leading to a paradigm-shift in patient management.

These data will be shared with the scientific community to address a comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Follicular lymphoma (FL) is the second most common form of non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, and is characterized by recurrent mutations in genes that encode histone modifying enzymes. Mutations in the histone acetyltransferase, CREBBP, are present in approximately two thirds of cases and are acquired as an early event in disease evolution. Here we aim to investigate the molecular mechanisms by which CREBBP mutations alter the epigenome of FL and cooperate with other histone modifying enzymes such as EP300 and EZH2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative My research agenda is to conduct patient-oriented research that advances understanding of overuse of healthcare among older adults. With the collaboration of junior investigators and other mentees, I will conduct research to understand how health care systems limit the harmful overuse of healthcare resources by their Medicare beneficiaries through their delivery of high quality primary care. The second set of projects involves development of tools to help clinicians to communicate more clearly with patients about heterogeneity of treatment effect in order to reduce the use of healthcare resources in patients unlikely to benefit from their use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Post-traumatic headache (PTH) is the most common consequence of traumatic brain injury, and is frequently chronic and refractory to typical pain treatments. Autonomic and sensory dysfunction have been recognized in PTH and represent key, objectively measurable candidate disease markers. This proposal will use an innovative, multimodal approach to sensory and autonomic testing to identify clinically meaningful biomarkers for use in PTH diagnosis, disease monitoring, and the development of non-addictive treatments with the goal of reducing the overall health burden of PTH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Public Health Statement  Laparoscopic surgery has continued to evolve and is now the gold standard approach for the majority of abdominal operations, offering numerous clinical benefits to patients. The current paradigm has many drawbacks in the visualization of the surgical field, causing lower operative efficiency. Our goal is to overcome these drawbacks and create a new paradigm in laparoscopic visualization by developing a flexible-view, immersive, three-dimensional imaging system. As a result, laparoscopic operative efficiency will be significantly improved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Conclusions drawn from a model system are only as valid as the understanding of that model system. Our plan to more clearly define the ability of an autologous, fully humanized mouse system to model human biology, immune-biology, and treatment response and toxicity would allow investigators to appropriately and robustly use this system for future, hypothesis-driven cancer research. It fulfils a critical translational gap in modeling human cancers in the context of an intact immune system. Our plan to rigorously validate this model, utilizing the NCI Oncology Models Forum to facilitate collaborations and make these models widely available, will create a tremendous resource for the oncology research community moving forward.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gender diverse youth (GDY) who identify as Black, Indigenous, or People of Color (BIPOC), and those living in rural communities are more likely to experience mental health concerns than their peers. Additionally, GDY experience barriers to receiving care to affirm their identities, which has been shown to improve mental health. The goals of this study are to 1) better understand BIPOC and rural GDY’s care needs, 2) design a platform to support community providers in delivering care to GDY, and 3) conduct a study to explore the impact that use of this platform has on youth, their families, and their community providers.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Using telehealth to improve access to gender-affirming care for BIPOC and rural gender diverse youth

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Efforts to combat obesity with diet and exercise have not reversed the steady climb of body weight in western cultures over the last decades. This proposal aims to fight obesity by understanding and ultimately controlling fat tissue development and growth. The findings will highlight therapeutic targets against obesity, which affects up to 30% of the United States population and contributes to diabetes and other debilitating metabolic disorders including hypertension and heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Tau pathology (tauopathy) is a prevailing hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and multiple other neurodegenerative diseases. This proposal aims to understand how USP11, multi-functional enzyme known to remove ubiquitin conjugates from proteins, contribute to tauopathy in brain. This proposal will allow us to determine if USP11 enzymatic activity and associated molecular mechanisms represent promising targets to mitigate tau pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need to identify the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying cerebrovascular function in both healthy and disease states associated with aging. The studies in this proposal will investigate how the brain endothelial cell enriched enzyme, tissue nonspecific alkaline phosphatase (TNAP), protects against the loss of cerebral function. The results will identify a potential therapeutic target that may be used improve cerebrovascular function and functional recovery in age-related disorders.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abnormal development of oligodendrocytes contributes to the pathophysiology of a number of neurological diseases and disorders such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), multiple sclerosis (MS), and glioblastoma, the deadliest of brain cancers. The proposed study utilizes advanced genetic techniques to investigate the mechanism of oligodendrocyte precursor cell development in the brains of mice. Results from these studies may offer new insights into pathological conditions such as demyelination, neuronal degeneration, and CNS cancers, while also providing an entry point to develop therapeutic means to combat these debilitating diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Aberrant expression of PRMT5 is frequently observed in triple negative breast cancer (TNBC). This project will dissect the critical role of TRAF6/PRMT5/ULK1 axis in regulating PRMT5 activation, autophagy induction, and TNBC progression, and determine the synergistic effect of PRMT5 and autophagy inhibitors in TNBC. TNBC cell culture models, xenograft mouse models and de-identified breast cancer patient samples will be used in the proposed studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: People with HIV (PWH) are living longer due to effective antiretroviral therapy drugs (ART), but they have higher cardiovascular risk and sudden death, and while the mechanism is not clear, we hypothesize that ART increases cardiovascular risk by inducing cardiac fibrosis, leading to sudden death in PWH. Our proposal focuses on illuminating the mechanism(s) of HIV-ART-mediated organ fibrosis and dysfunction using HIV mouse models. The results from the investigation may provide evidence for novel strategies to prevent or slow organ fibrosis in PWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) is a spectrum of liver disorders ranging from hepatic steatosis to steatohepatitis with varying degrees of fibrosis and cirrhosis. ALD is a major cause of morbidity, mortality, and health care costs in the US and worldwide. However, there is no FDA-approved therapy for any stage of ALD. The overall goal of this project is to test the therapeutic efficacy of s-EH inhibition at different stages of ALD severity, and to provide a mechanistic foundation for using s-EH inhibition as a novel therapy for alcohol-induced liver pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Changes in alternative splicing are an important feature of cardiac remodeling and heart failure. This project will employ mass spectrometry and computational methods to decipher how alternative splicing networks rewire cardiac protein composition, structure, and function. The results may provide insights into disease mechanisms by revealing how alternative splicing regulates cardiac gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Investigations at cortical layer level in neuroscience not only advance our understanding of the cortical micro-circuitry in vivo in health and disease, but also help bridge the gap between macroscopic (e.g., conventional fMRI, behavior) and microscopic (e.g., extracellular recordings) measures of brain function. In this project, we will develop a whole-brain layer-specific imaging sequence tool in humans, for achieving fMRI at high resolution (£800 µm isotropic), high specificity (not being spatially biased with unspecific vein signals as in BOLD), high sensitivity (robust measurement at layer-level resolution), high spatial accuracy (layer fMRI analysis in native fMRI space to avoid blurring and errors arising from registration), whole brain coverage, and eventually extending layer fMRI to more flexible connectivity- based experiment designs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hearing loss affects more than 35 million adults and children in the United States and genetic variants play a major role in the survival of sensory cell within the inner ear. This project is directed at understanding how TMPRSS3, a protein that cuts other proteins, regulates the critical protein links around the sensory cells. The results may help us design strategies for treating inherited deafness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will determine how gut bacteria, known as the gut microbiome, can influence the health benefits of regular physical exercise. We will test whether specific types of gut bacteria can act in conjunction with exercise training to enhance improvements in metabolic health in mouse models of disease with high blood sugar levels. We anticipate this work will lead to development of a “probiotic” treatment to improve health and the response to exercise training in people with metabolic diseases like type 1 and type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Published and preliminary results demonstrate that vitamin D can increase the immune defenses of gingival cells against the bacteria associated with periodontal disease. Here we propose to examine the role of vitamin D in periodontal disease in a mouse model, and to study the mechanism by which this occurs. The results will support the development of vitamin D as a therapy for periodontal disease and other oral infections.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Mali is a low-income country in Sub-Saharan West Africa where the incidence of mycobacterial infections, primarily tuberculosis, remains high driven in a large part by the persistence of the HIV epidemic with TB being the main cause of death in HIV-infected adults and children. The overarching goal of this research training program, “Building the Next Generation of Researchers in HIV/TB Diagnostics in Mali”, is to strengthen the scientific capacity to develop and implement diagnostic and monitoring technologies to address the HIV and TB epidemics. Through this program, we will achieve the overall goal of training the next generation of scientists and leaders in diagnostics of HIV and mycobacterial diseases in Mali and the region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE 20-25% of AML have very high expression of a gene called Meningioma-1 (MN1), and most of these patients have a very poor prognosis, thus substantially contributing to over 10,000 deaths from AML/year in the US. We hypothesize that MN1 causes AML primarily by stabilizing gene regulatory hubs via intrinsically disordered, “sticky” domains. Dissecting how MN1 achieves this will yield fundamental insights into gene regulation and may point the way towards novel and innovative therapies targeting intrinsically disordered domains.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Access to high-quality auditory input is crucial to the development of spoken language in children with hearing loss. Additional understanding of the perceptual consequences of Auditory Neuropathy and Cochlear Hearing Loss in school-age children is a first step to developing future audiologic treatments and optimizing best practices for maximizing speech perception outcomes in these populations. The proposed project aims to evaluate spectral and temporal resolution abilities and their relationship to phonological processing and speech perception in children with Auditory Neuropathy and Cochlear Hearing Loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although HIV infection can be controlled by daily lifelong adherence to expensive antiretroviral ARV therapies, it cannot presently be cured. While infected cells often hide from the immune system in latency, converging evidence supports that these may also be seen by cytotoxic T-cells but are able to resist being killed. This proposal will address the unmet need of identifying and overcoming mechanisms of cell-intrinsic resistance to cytotoxic T-cells in persistent HIV reservoirs, with the aim of developing new therapeutic approaches to curing infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current half-life of a lung allograft is unacceptably short, and all recipients encounter significant complications, both from allograft rejection and from immunosuppression-associated toxicities. Given these issues, the ultimate goal of lung transplant is immune tolerance-induction, which promises life-long graft acceptance without chronic immunosuppression, and with maintenance of protective immunity against viruses and other infections. The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because it aims to improve clinical outcomes for patients that are undergoing lung transplantation, by discovering new strategies to induce immune tolerance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on optimizing the therapeutic potential of STING agonists for the treatment of triple negative breast cancer where there is a critical need. The major barrier to the clinical realization of STING agonists for solid malignancies is the transient nature of the drug in the tumor microenvironment, and as such we propose a multifaceted approach to better retain the drug by using a PEGylated breast biopsy marker system and by inhibiting cell intrinsic degradation through targeting Rab7 and TREX1. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to fostering fundamental creative discoveries, innovative research strategies, and their applications as a basis for ultimately protecting and improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will determine the degree to which cannabis use alters antiretroviral therapy (ART) pharmacokinetics (PK) among persons living with HIV (PLWH). In particular, the study will focus on effects relating to blood-brain barrier (BBB) permeability, CSF PK, and ART efficacy and neurotoxicity. As a result of this project, we aim to further understand the factors that may affect the persisting presence of HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This collaborative study between Johns Hopkins University, the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control, Makerere University, the Ugandan Ministry of Health and the University of Florida Emerging Pathogen Institute builds on the findings from our earlier RO1 study of the “Epidemiology and Ecology of Cholera in Africa” which concluded that cholera outbreaks result from the “spread” of genetic lineages rather than from strains “emerging from the environment” like it does in Bangladesh. It also builds on the innovative molecular and GIS technologies developed during the earlier grant period to support a detailed study of transmission of the genetic lineages. The project will assist countries identify and stop cholera transmission, leading to a “cholera elimination scorecard” by which countries can monitor progress toward national elimination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Project Narrative The consequences of irradiation- and/or Cisplatin (IR/CisP)-induced neurotoxicity, often irreversible and permanent neurological deficits, represent a daunting challenge when treating patients with cancer. This proposal aims to determine the mechanisms protecting neurons from IR/CisP-induced cytotoxicity, with the overarching goal to provide evidence supporting novel strategies to decrease their neurotoxicity, while maintaining therapy efficacy and improving patient quality of life. We expect this study to lay the foundation for future research investigating the targeting of the CDK5/SIRT2-CSB signaling axis as a novel strategy to alleviate and/or prevent neurotoxicity in cancer patients who need IR/CisP therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although smoking is the leading cause of premature non-communicable death in the United States and contributes to millions of hospitalizations annually, most hospitalized smokers are rarely prescribed any kind of smoking cessation medication to help them quit. In this project, we will employ a nurse practitioner-led, hospital-based tobacco treatment team to prescribe effective medications, counsel patients on how to use them properly, and manage a text messaging system with the goal to maximize medication use, adherence, and smoking cessation. We anticipate demonstrating the effectiveness, feasibility, acceptability, cost- effectiveness, and sustainability of this program, so that, in the future, more hospitals will be able to capture the “teachable moment” of hospitalization to help smokers quit permanently.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Steroid resistant nephrotic syndrome (SRNS) is a leading cause of chronic kidney disease in the first three decades of life1. Renal biopsies typically reveal focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), and these children are unresponsive to standard steroid therapy and invariably progress to end-stage renal disease. This career development grant will explore the pathogenic mechanisms by which human mutations in the novel disease genes NOS1AP and TRIM8 cause SRNS/FSGS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will use transcriptomic data from plasma to model a predictive tool for Alzheimer Disease using bioinformatics and machine learning approaches. This is an innovative approach, a cost-effective and minimally invasive biomarker for Alzheimer Disease, which is critical for early detection (preclinical), diagnosis, disease intervention and monitoring. If successful, the results will lead to a breakthrough in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Colorectal cancer is one of the most prevalent malignancies and a deadly form of cancer. Colorectal tumors at advanced stages often progress after initial treatment and become resistant to current therapies. The proposed studies will develop a new class of anticancer agents for targeting proteins that are essential for colorectal cancer cell growth and survival. In the long run, these studies may lead to new and improved therapies against colorectal cancer and other types of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Chemistry and Pharmacology of Iboga Alkaloids There is an urgent need for the development of novel therapeutics for substance use disorders (SUDs). Ibogaine, the major psychoactive alkaloid of the African plant Tabernanthe iboga, represents an important prototype for this purpose. We propose to create and systematically examine novel ibogaine analogs in terms of synthetic methods and pharmacology, and provide new pharmacological probes for research relevant to SUDs and related psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PHS Relevance Statement Colorectal cancer (CRC) prevails as the third most common and deadliest cancer worldwide, affecting both men and women. Despite scientific breakthroughs, gaps in knowledge remain due to the multiple accumulation of molecular alterations occurring at onset and during disease progression. This study will investigate the role of the transcription factor STAT2 as a signaling mediator in the communication exchange between cancer cells and fibroblasts in the tumor microenvironment to accelerate disease progression.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE New perinatal HIV infections continue and an estimated 1.7 million children are living with HIV. The goal of our research program is to address the limited understanding of how the host environment and immune system influences HIV reservoir establishment and maintenance in children. Our critical focus on virus-host interactions, with experiments designed to perturb these interactions in a preclinical model, will inform pediatric-specific approaches to cure perinatal HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Affecting tens of millions of individuals in the United States alone, age-related high frequency hearing loss results in difficulty understanding speech and problems hearing environmental sound. Due to limitations in high frequency bone conduction testing, clinicians have assumed that presbycusis is due to sensorineural dysfunction, but emerging evidence suggests conductive pathology contributes to presbycusis. Our goal is to define the structural and functional consequences of aging on the ossicular chain and to develop non-invasive methods to identify and localize conductive presbycusis in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to decipher how a conserved retinal interneuron detects visual threats, generates divergent threat representations downstream, and how these representations guide innate defensive behaviors. Insights into the organization and function of visual pathways in health, facilitate identification of early disorganization and dysfunction in common diseases of the retina and the brain. In addition, knowledge about the function of specific pathways in visually guided behaviors establishes benchmarks for comparisons of competing strategies for vision restoration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) is an understudied chronic inflammatory disease with increasing prevalence, incidence, healthcare costs, and burdens to quality of life. As clinical equipoise exists between effective medication and dietary therapies, complex decision making around treatments and chronic disease management is challenging for patients and providers, and understanding the drivers of decision making and applying shared decision making are critical gaps in patient-centered EoE care. This proposal aims to leverage patient and provider experiences and preferences to develop and test a multilevel decision support intervention that will help patients with EoE and their physicians share information to support informed decision making in selecting treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Experiments in this proposal center on congenital Neurocutaneous melanocytosis (NCM) that comprises a spectrum of neoplastic abnormalities involving pigment cells in the brain and skin, for which we know little about the origin, underlying genetics and developmental biology. We focus on the oncogene NRAS Q61K which has recently been shown to be a driver in human NCM patients and aim to decipher the mechanisms underlying the cellular and molecular etiology of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Robey, Ellen, A): Narrative: The non-classical MHC-1 molecules MHC-E play key, but poorly understood, functions in immune protection and immune regulation. We propose to investigate the factors that determine the function of the mouse MHC- E molecule, Qa-1 in homeostasis and during viral infection.
